Subject:      Public Art Opportunity for So Cal Artists
Comments: To: AFTAPUBART-l@culturemail.org
MIME-Version: 1.0

This message is in MIME format. Since your mail reader does not understand
this format, some or all of this message may not be legible.

------_=_NextPart_000_01C4ABFD.8E7585DE
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="iso-8859-1"


> The City of Ventura is looking to commission an artist or artist team to
> design and fabricate public art for the new Promontory Point Park. Design
> and construction of a park in the Montalvo neighborhood on a three-acre
> site presents an excellent opportunity to integrate public art
> enhancements as functional or interactive amenities. Possible artist
> designed components include sculptural elements, recreational equipment,
> land form elements, and seating.
>
> Please see attached RFQ for all pertinent information regarding the
> project. For further information please contact:
>
> Denise Sindelar
> City of Ventura
> Public Art Project Manager
> (805) 658-4793
> dsindelar@ci.ventura.ca.us
>
>
>  <<PromPtRFQ.pdf>>
>
>
>

Subject:      Portable Works Collection: guidelines
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
              boundary="----_=_NextPart_001_01C4B075.D9C9623E"

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B075.D9C9623E
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello,
Arlington County's Public Art Program is considering expanding its
portable works collection. In doing so, we would like to develop
guidelines to help structure the program as well as outline the process
through which works of art are collected/purchased. If any of you have
developed guidelines for a portable works collection and are willing to
share them with me, that would be wonderful.=20
=20
Sincerely,=20
Caroline Danforth
Public Art Assistant
Arlington, Virginia
=20

Reply-To:     Marc Folk <mfolk@ACGT.ORG>

------=_NextPart_000_0037_01C4B066.2C1457E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

The Art in Public Places Committee of the Arts Commission of Greater =
Toledo has convened a Design Review Board to acquire a work of public =
art to be located at Walbridge Park in Toledo, Ohio.  This public art =
component is a part of Mayor Jack Ford's mission to recreate Walbridge =
Park as Toledo's first "Destination Park".  All submissions must be =
postmarked by October 22, 2004.  Proposals postmarked after this date =
will not be considered for review.  To obtain a prospectus and detailed =
supplemental information please log on to www.walbridgepark.acgt.org or =
contact the Arts Commission of Greater Toledo at 419-254-2787.

Marc D. Folk
Artistic Director
Arts Commission of Greater Toledo
1838 Parkwood Ave., Ste. 120
Toledo, OH 43624
419-254-2787 ph
419-254-2790 fax
mfolk@acgt.org

Date:         Tue, 12 Oct 2004 14:51:15 -0400
Reply-To:     Ann Wykell <Ann.Wykell@STPETE.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Ann Wykell <Ann.Wykell@STPETE.ORG>
Subject:      QUERY - NEIGHBORHOODS VS. DOWNTOWN
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I am trying to collect informal data on the ratio of percent for art projects for downtowns compared to neighborhood sites.  For example - in St. Petersburg we have placed art at 25 sites, five of them downtown.  I would like to know if this is high, low or              fairly typical of other per cent for art programs.  Thanks for any help with this.

Ann Wykell
Manager of Cultural Affairs
City of St. Petersburg
(727)551-3250
ann.wykell@stpete.org
=========================================================================
Date:         Tue, 12 Oct 2004 15:30:06 -0600
Reply-To:     "Saunders, Heather" <Heather.Saunders@CALGARY.CA>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         "Saunders, Heather" <Heather.Saunders@CALGARY.CA>
Subject:      Examples of projects in 2million range
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hello All,

I am looking for examples of public art projects around the 2 million
dollar mark - not including project management costs or maintenance
reserve. Legacy/ celebration projects are ideal :-).

Can you send me the name of the project, location, pics if you have any
and the budget?

Thanks in advance,
Heather

Heather Saunders
Public Art Program
City of Calgary #63
Tel:  403.268.5270
Fax:  403.268.5280




NOTICE -
This communication is intended ONLY for the use of the person or entity named above and may contain information that is confidential or legally privileged. If you are not the intended recipient named above or a person responsible for delivering messages or communications to the intended recipient, YOU ARE HEREBY NOTIFIED that any use, distribution, or copying of this communication or any of the information contained in it is strictly prohibited. Date:         Tue, 12 Oct 2004 15:26:42 -0700
Reply-To:     Meagan ATIYEH <Meagan.Atiyeh@STATE.OR.US>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
Comments:     RFC822 error: <W> Incorrect or incomplete address field found and
              ignored.
From:         Meagan ATIYEH <Meagan.Atiyeh@STATE.OR.US>
Subject:      PAN:Regional calls in conflict with federal law?
Comments: To: aftapubart-l@culturemail.org
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

All,

The Oregon Arts Commission has been administering Oregon's Percent for Art Program using a combination of RFQ's open to all, nationally, regionally (OR, WA, ID, MT, AK) and Oregon only--based on the project scope and desires of the selection committee.

Our Attorney General's Office has now raised concern that regional opportunities may be in discord with the following Federal law/statute:

Commence Clause (Dormant Commerce Clause)
Privileges and Immunities Clause of the U.S. Constitution
Equal Protection Clause

Anyone have any experience with such issues? Please also reply if your program offers regionally limited opportunities.

Thank you,
Meagan Atiyeh
Visual Arts Coordinator
Oregon Arts Commission
(503) 986-0084
=========================================================================
Date:         Tue, 12 Oct 2004 13:32:17 -0700
Reply-To:     "Jones, Brooke" <Brooke.Jones@SANJOSECA.GOV>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         "Jones, Brooke" <Brooke.Jones@SANJOSECA.GOV>
Subject:      Re: QUERY - NEIGHBORHOODS VS. DOWNTOWN
Comments: To: Ann Wykell <Ann.Wykell@STPETE.ORG>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

Hi Ann,
We are currently in the process of doing several neighborhood projects, but
in terms of completed (or soon to be completed) works we have 121 public art
projects.  61 of those pieces are in the downtown area and 60 are in the
neighborhoods.

I hope this helps!
Brooke Jones, Public Art Program Coordinator
Office of Cultural Affairs
365 S. Market Street
San Jose, CA 95113
p 408-277-2809
f  408-277-3160
www.sanjoseculture.org/pub_art

I am trying to collect informal data on the ratio of percent for art

Date:         Tue, 12 Oct 2004 17:47:07 -0600
Reply-To:     liz & shel <lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         liz & shel <lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM>
Subject:      Re: Finalist fees
Comments: To: Ann Wykell <Ann.Wykell@STPETE.ORG>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I find it is a mixed blessing to be named a finalist for a project. On the
one hand, glad to be in the running and have an opportunity to develop an
idea for a public space.  On the other hand you spend days or even weeks
doing research, drawings models, etc and are usually paid a pittance for
your time. I suspect that other artists wouldn't mind seeing final project
fees be slightly lower inorder to pay finalists more for proposals.  What
does everyone else think?

Shel Neymark
=========================================================================
Date:         Tue, 12 Oct 2004 14:52:16 -1000
Reply-To:     Kathleen Meehan <kmeehan777@EARTHLINK.NET>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Kathleen Meehan <kmeehan777@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Finalist fees
Comments: To: liz & shel <lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM>
In-Reply-To:  <003401c4b0b5$c9524e00$b70b1341@10acu>
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v619)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I agree wholeheartedly with Shel. From an artist's perspective, I would
MUCH rather see the budget lowered to allow for Finalist Proposal Fees
that are reasonable for an artist's time, and have travel costs can be
fair to the artist.

Also, limiting the number of finalists to no more than THREE will save
money in the project budget,  and save everyone time and energy.

Kathleen Meehan
911048 Kekuilani Lp, N1301
Kapolei, HI 96707
808-722-2249
kmeehan777@earthlink.net
KathleenMeehan.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Kathleen Meehan [mailto:kmeehan777@EARTHLINK.NET]
Sent: Tuesday, October 12, 2004 7:52 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: Finalist fees

I agree wholeheartedly with Shel. From an artist's perspective, I would
MUCH rather see the budget lowered to allow for Finalist Proposal Fees
that are reasonable for an artist's time, and have travel costs can be
fair to the artist.

Also, limiting the number of finalists to no more than THREE will save
money in the project budget,  and save everyone time and energy.

Kathleen Meehan
911048 Kekuilani Lp, N1301
Kapolei, HI 96707
808-722-2249
kmeehan777@earthlink.net
KathleenMeehan.com

Date:         Wed, 13 Oct 2004 08:41:32 -0800

Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Sandy Gillespie <sandy_gillespie@EED.STATE.AK.US>
Subject:      Re: Regional calls in conflict with federal law?
Comments: To: "Finck, Irene" <Irene.Finck@OAC.STATE.OH.US>
In-Reply-To:  <705A4EFEFF671B4DB18DFAE44493166E44E7AE@ODNEXCH.em.ohio.gov>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

Alaska offers regional calls when the amount is less than $50K. Shipping and
travel expenses make it counterproductive to go Outside on a small budget.

Sandy Gillespie
Visual and Literary Arts Program Director
Alaska State Council on the Arts
411 West 4th Avenue, Suite 1E

From: AFTA Public Art discusion list

Sent: Wednesday, October 13, 2004 5:13 AM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: Regional calls in conflict with federal law?


The Ohio program also offers regionally limited opportunities.

Irene M. Finck
Program Coordinator
Percent for Art Program
Office of Individual Creativity
Ohio Arts Council
727 East Main Street
Columbus, Ohio 43205-1796
614/466-2613
Fax:  614/466-4494

-----Original Message-----
From: AFTA Public Art discusion list
[mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org] On Behalf Of Meagan ATIYEH
Sent: Tuesday, October 12, 2004 6:27 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: PAN:Regional calls in conflict with federal law?

All,

The Oregon Arts Commission has been administering Oregon's Percent for
Art Program using a combination of RFQ's open to all, nationally,
regionally (OR, WA, ID, MT, AK) and Oregon only--based on the project
scope and desires of the selection committee.

Our Attorney General's Office has now raised concern that regional
opportunities may be in discord with the following Federal law/statute:

Commence Clause (Dormant Commerce Clause)
Privileges and Immunities Clause of the U.S. Constitution
Equal Protection Clause

Anyone have any experience with such issues? Please also reply if your
program offers regionally limited opportunities.

Thank you,
Meagan Atiyeh
Visual Arts Coordinator
Oregon Arts Commission
(503) 986-0084
=========================================================================
Date:         Wed, 13 Oct 2004 12:42:51 -0600
Reply-To:     "Minette, Kathryn" <KMinette@LVR.STATE.NM.US>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         "Minette, Kathryn" <KMinette@LVR.STATE.NM.US>
Subject:      Re: Finalist fees
Comments: To: liz & shel <lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"

Depending on the scope and budget of the project we usually state in the
prospectus that there will be up to 5 finalists for the larger project
amounts and/or those that utilize a national call or 3 finalists for a
smaller project budgets or a statewide call. We use the following method to
determine compensation for the finalists.  We encourage artists to spend at
least $500 on a maquette and then determine travel in the following way:
50-100 miles round trip for a site visit/presentation are paid an additional
$100.
100 - 300 are paid an additional $250
300 - 800    "  "       "       "  $500
800 - ? "       "       "       "  $750

If the maximum number of finalists are not selected, the remaining dollar
amount is put back into the project budget.

Kathryn Minette
Art in Public Places Program Manager
New Mexico Arts Division
P.O. Box 1450
Santa Fe, NM  87504-1450
Phone 505/827-6490
   In State 800/879-4278
Fax   505/827-6043
Web site www.nmarts.org

-----Original Message-----
From: liz & shel [mailto:lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM]
Sent: Tuesday, October 12, 2004 5:47 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: Finalist fees


I find it is a mixed blessing to be named a finalist for a project. On the
one hand, glad to be in the running and have an opportunity to develop an
idea for a public space.  On the other hand you spend days or even weeks
doing research, drawings models, etc and are usually paid a pittance for
your time. I suspect that other artists wouldn't mind seeing final project
fees be slightly lower inorder to pay finalists more for proposals.  What
does everyone else think?

Shel Neymark

  </FONT></U></P><BR>
  <P><FONT face=3DGeneva color=3D#050000 size=3D2>4445 Volta Place, NW =

  <P><FONT face=3DGeneva color=3D#050000 size=3D2>Washington, DC 20007 =

  size=3D2>volta45@starpower.net</FONT></U><FONT face=3DGeneva =
color=3D#050000 size=3D2>=20

Date:         Wed, 13 Oct 2004 13:28:15 -0700
Reply-To:     Hamp SIMMONS <Hamp-Simmons@CI.SANTA-MONICA.CA.US>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Hamp SIMMONS <Hamp-Simmons@CI.SANTA-MONICA.CA.US>
Subject:      Use of Chrome in Outdoor Projects
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Does anyone have any experience using chrome plating in an outdoor public art project?  I know that chrome itself does not corrode but we have concerns about the work being scratched or etched upon which would expose the metal beneath the chrome to the elements.  If anyone has any experience with chrome works, I'd love to hear about it.  Thanks!



Hamp Simmons
Cultural Affairs Coordinator
City of Santa Monica
310/458.8350

Date:         Wed, 13 Oct 2004 16:20:14 -0500
Reply-To:     Porter Arneill <Porter_Arneill@KCMO.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Porter Arneill <Porter_Arneill@KCMO.ORG>
Subject:      Facilitating Artist Selection Panels - Request for stories from
              the field
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: multipart/alternative;
              Boundary="0__=09BBE5BFDFE391BB8f9e8a93df938690918c09BBE5BFDFE391BB"
Content-Disposition: inline

--0__=09BBE5BFDFE391BB8f9e8a93df938690918c09BBE5BFDFE391BB
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable






Dear Fellow Public Art Facilitators:

The topic of panel facilitation has sparked some interesting responses.=

Since my post on this list about a month ago, I've spoken with several
folks who've shared some humorous, interesting and even agonizing stori=
es
related to their experiences facilitating public art selection panels. =
 I'm
curious to hear more and willing to collect and share them collectively=
 as
"case studies."

I know there are a lot of horror stories out there (I've lived a few
myself) but, in the interest of sharing creative resolutions to issues =
in
the field for the benefit of others, I'm looking for stories that inclu=
de
an interesting and/or innovative resolution or outcome--even after the
fact.  What experience can you share that might help someone else avoid=
 or
resolve a problem in the future?

For example: How was the overbearing, retentive panelist taught to
understand the bigger picture (or how did you work around them)?  How w=
as
the engineer's rigid concept of decorative art ON a bridge finessed to
accept the integration of innovative art IN the bridge?  How did you ge=
t
the liberal and the conservative to agree to disagree (or did they agre=
e)?
How was the city council member convinced that the arrows in the floor
wouldn't be a safety risk by leading people into the walls?  How did yo=
u
convince the fundamentalist Christian that not all snakes are necessari=
ly
evil?  How did the failed panel process last year lead to a flawless pa=
nel
process this year?

If you have a story you'd like to share, please email it to me as a Wor=
d
(.doc) attachment or in the body of an email.  While I appreciate clear=

diction, I'm not looking for perfectly written papers--a well conveyed
description, one page or less, is fine.  Please change the names in you=
r
story to "protect the innocent."  I may ask for revisions if necessary.=


I will certainly ask for permission and credit the author if any of the=
se
stories are published.

Depending on the number of stories I receive, I may put something toget=
her
for next year's PAN conference too.  I think it's cathartic to learn of=
 the
travails of others in the field.  (I know it makes me feel better.)
Hopefully, by sharing, we can improve upon our own wisdom and facilitat=
ion
skills.

Thanks,
Porter
.......................................................................=
.......................................

Porter Arneill
Director, Municipal Art Commission
City Hall, 17th Floor
414 E. 12th Street
Kansas City, MO  64106
O-816-513-2538
C-816-564-1280
F-816-513-2523
www.kcmo.org/pubworks.nsf/web/art=

<html><body>
<p>Dear Fellow Public Art Facilitators:<br>
<br>
The topic of panel facilitation has sparked some interesting responses.=
  Since my post on this list about a month ago, I've spoken with severa=
l folks who've shared some humorous, interesting and even agonizing sto=
ries related to their experiences facilitating public art selection pan=
els.  I'm curious to hear more and willing to collect and share them co=
llectively as &quot;case studies.&quot;  <br>
<br>
I know there are a lot of horror stories out there (I've lived a few my=
self) but, in the interest of sharing creative resolutions to issues in=
 the field for the benefit of others, I'm looking for stories that incl=
ude an interesting and/or innovative resolution or outcome--even after =
the fact.  What experience can you share that might help someone else a=
void or resolve a problem in the future?  <br>
<br>
For example: How was the overbearing, retentive panelist taught to unde=
rstand the bigger picture (or how did you work around them)?  How was t=
he engineer's rigid concept of decorative art ON a bridge finessed to a=
ccept the integration of innovative art IN the bridge?  How did you get=
 the liberal and the conservative to agree to disagree (or did they agr=
ee)?  How was the city council member convinced that the arrows in the =
floor wouldn't be a safety risk by leading people into the walls?  How =
did you convince the fundamentalist Christian that not all snakes are n=
ecessarily evil?  How did the failed panel process last year lead to a =
flawless panel process this year?   <br>
<br>
If you have a story you'd like to share, please email it to me as a Wor=
d (.doc) attachment or in the body of an email.  While I appreciate cle=
ar diction, I'm not looking for perfectly written papers--a well convey=
ed description, one page or less, is fine.  Please change the names in =
your story to &quot;protect the innocent.&quot;  I may ask for revision=
s if necessary.  <br>
<br>
I will certainly ask for permission and credit the author if any of the=
se stories are published.<br>
<br>
Depending on the number of stories I receive, I may put something toget=
her for next year's PAN conference too.  I think it's cathartic to lear=
n of the travails of others in the field.  (I know it makes me feel bet=
ter.)  Hopefully, by sharing, we can improve upon our own wisdom and fa=
cilitation skills.<br>
<br>
Thanks,<br>

Date:         Wed, 13 Oct 2004 17:53:20 -1000
Reply-To:     Kathleen Meehan <kmeehan777@EARTHLINK.NET>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Kathleen Meehan <kmeehan777@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Finalist fees
Comments: To: Kitty Pheney <kpheney@CRT.STATE.LA.US>
In-Reply-To:  <34A476CC23A0C04A803C99400CDB78680275595F@mercury.crt.state.la.us>
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v619)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

When analyzing how much is fair for a proposal fee, let's look at what
is involved:  For a successful finalist proposal on a project with
budget of $100,000 or more, for instance, an artist spends weeks
studying blueprints,  finalizing the design concept, talking to
fabricators, material suppliers, and engineers, and building
preliminary foamcore models until the idea is resolved,

Then the artist builds a final model, tweaking it or rebuilding it
sometimes, then paints it. If the artist is fabricating his/her own
work, samples must be made; if not, the artist must get samples from
the suppliers.  Meanwhile, the budget is being addressed, and if costs
are too high, minor modifications must be made to model or concept.
During this time, a finalist written proposal is being put together,
and an oral presentation is prepared using slides or storyboards.

The model and written proposals are then packed up and shipped, or
taken with artist to the meeting with selection committee, where artist
has traveled on his own time, often staying overnight.  The three weeks
(minimum time) that an artist spends preparing the proposal are much
more than 8 hour days, and the finalist fee also includes all materials
used for preliminary design concept, samples, preliminary model, final
model, shipping container, etc. In addition, the artist has used
telephone, faxes, auto, gasoline, etc.,  For all this, a fee of $1500
plus travel is the very least that should be considered; some programs
pay $2500-$3500, but not enough of them.  In contrast, consider the
fees architects and landscape architects receive for similar finalist
work.

If a budget is $100,000, most finalists would rather have the budget
reduced to $85,000-$90,000 and be paid $2500-$3500 plus travel
expenses, and have only two others to compete against,  as respect for
the intense work they have done.

Kathleen Meehan
911058 Kekuilani Lp, N1301
Kapolei, HI 96707
808-722-2249
kmeehan777@earthlink.net
KathleenMeehan.com
=========================================================================
Date:         Thu, 14 Oct 2004 09:57:48 -0700
Reply-To:     Zola Mumford <ZMUMFOR@CO.PIERCE.WA.US>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Zola Mumford <ZMUMFOR@CO.PIERCE.WA.US>
Subject:      Chrome in Outdoor Projects/Electropolished steel
Comments: To: Hamp-Simmons@CI.SANTA-MONICA.CA.US
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

A bit tangential, but related to metal artwork:

Although none of the public art projects commissioned by the Pierce
County (WA state) Arts & Cultural Services Division have used chrome, we
are now working with an artist, Ries Niemi, who gets beautiful results
from electropolished steel.

The electropolished steel finish is just as brilliant and reflective as
chrome, is stainless, does not rust or fade, is easy to clean, and is
permanent. He has worked in this particular medium for several years,
and frequently uses textures in both high and low relief. It looks
wonderful.

Not being a metal artist myself, I don't know if electropolishing or
any similar specialized technologies can be used to protect chrome.



Zola Mumford - Public Art Program Specialist
Pierce County Arts & Cultural Services Division
Dept. of Community Services
3611 South D Street - Suite 200
Tacoma WA 98418
phone: (253) 798-3797
Fax: (253) 798-6604
zmumfor@pierce.co.wa.us
------------------------------------------
http://www.piercecountywa.org/pc/services/arts/arts.htm

Date:         Thu, 14 Oct 2004 15:45:46 -0700
Reply-To:     Jang <Jang@CONFLUENCEPROJECT.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Jang <Jang@CONFLUENCEPROJECT.ORG>
Subject:      Endowment agreements
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
              boundary="----_=_NextPart_001_01C4B23F.8B945C3A"

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B23F.8B945C3A
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Greeting Public Art colleagues:
=20
The Confluence Project incorporates seven site-specific large-scale
artworks along key confluences of rivers, ecosystems, and Native
American and Euro-American cultures within Washington and Oregon along
the Columbia River Basin in the Pacific Northwest. Each site design will
include both landscape elements and integrated art works.  The
Confluence Project is raising $20 million to complete this project in
alignment with the Lewis and Clark Bicentennial, 2004-06.
=20
As part of our strategic planning, we are raising funds for a $2 million
conservation endowment.  We are in the process of considering the best
scenario for the long-term care of this integrated series of public
artworks, as our organization will officially sunset after the
dedication of the sites.
=20
We are interested in reviewing potential models for the long-term
jurisdiction and management of the endowment.  Since these public art
pieces are to be sited on a variety of public lands including local,
state, federal, and multiple public owners in both Washington and
Oregon, whatever legal document and oversight that is established must
consider numerous organizational perspectives.
=20
So, if you have examples of endowment or trust models that might be
appropriate for our consideration, please accept our appreciation for
your input.
=20
Thank you!
=20
=20
Jan
=20
=20
=20
Janet L. Gallimore
Confluence Project
janG@confluenceproject.org
360-693-0123=20
=20

Narrow";

Project</span></font><span =

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

AMERICANS FOR THE ARTS LAUNCHES THE ARTS ACTION FUND

=20

On October 5th, Americans for the Arts announced that is launching a =
major
new initiative to involve individual citizens in advocacy for the arts =
and
arts education.=20

The creation of the Americans for the  <http://www.artsactionfund.org> =
Arts
Action Fund adds a new dimension to arts advocacy in the United States =
by
providing a vehicle through which any citizen can help ensure that all
Americans have the opportunity to appreciate, value, and participate in =
the
arts. Later this month, the Arts Action Fund will release a =
Congressional
Report Card highlighting the voting records of Members of the U.S. House =
of
Representatives on high-priority arts legislation. In November, a =
national
citizens=92 membership campaign will be launched to encourage Americans =
to
join and support the Arts Action Fund.=20

=93In our work with arts organizations throughout the United States, we =
see
enormous public enthusiasm for the arts and arts education that is not
reflected in government decisions and school curricula,=94 said Robert =
L.
Lynch, president and CEO of Americans for the Arts. =93It is time that =
elected
officials heard from the public when it comes to the arts and arts
education. This new citizens=92 membership initiative will harness the =
power
of individual citizens, joined together through the Arts Action Fund, =
and
put it to work to ensure that the arts are a vital presence in every
community and every public school in the nation.=94

Over the past two years, 40% of the funding for state arts councils has =
been
eliminated; several states have practically eliminated arts funding; and =
the
share of private giving has declined by over 40% in the last decade. In
1992, the arts received 8.4 percent of all charitable giving.  By 2003, =
it
had dropped to 5.4 percent.  If the arts maintained their 8.4 percent =
share
of total giving in 2003 ($240.72 billion), they would have received =
$20.22
billion instead of $13.11 billion=97a $7 billion difference. The Arts =
Action
Fund is intended in part to help reverse that pattern.

The Arts Action Fund will initially focus on four primary areas of =
activity:


*       Communicating with the Media and Candidates for Office=97providing a
leading voice on the importance and benefits of the arts to the media =
and
candidates for office: hosting candidate forums, participating in town =
hall
meetings, sponsoring advertisements, and helping shape candidates=92 =
positions
and party platforms impacting the arts;
*       Advocacy Training at the State and Local Levels=97involving Americans
for the Arts=92 extensive arts advocacy infrastructure and network at =
the
state and local levels to help educate, train and connect individual =
arts
advocates to local organizations;
*       Evaluating Members of Congress=97assessing and rating the voting
records of Members of Congress on high-priority arts issues;
*       Providing a Voice for the Public=97aggressively petitioning to shape
public policy at the federal level for the arts and arts education;

For more information, visit:  <http://www.artsactionfund.org/>
www.artsactionfund.org.

=20

The Washington Post published an article about the new initiative titled
=93Arts Group to Use Lilly Funds for Advocacy Initiative=94 by =
Jacqueline
Trescott on October 5th.  To read the article visit:=20
 <http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A7336-2004Oct4.html>
http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A7336-2004Oct4.html=20

=20

=20

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

NATIONAL MURAL NEWS

=20

******MURAL MISSPELLING: LIVERMORE, CA

=20

The new public library in Livermore, CA has a mural by artist Maria =
Alquilar
at the entry.  To its great dismay, the library realized after =
installation
that several of the names in the mural are misspelled, including =
Einstein,
Michelangelo, and Vincent Van Gogh. =20


Only those of you who have never left out the =93L=94 in public can cast =
stones,
but administrators across the country may want to place a mandatory =
spell
check in the review process for any work with text.=20

=20

Two stories about the project:


=20
<http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/state/20041006-1509-ca-librarymispell=
ing
s.html>
<http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/state/20041006-1509-ca-librarymispell=
ing
s.html>

=20

And=20

=20

 <http://www.kesq.com/Global/story.asp?s=3D2394370>
http://www.KESQ.com/Global/story.asp?s=3D2394370
=20

=20

*****CITY WIDE MURAL: PHILADELPHIA, PA

=20

To celebrate their 20th anniversary, Mural Arts, a nonprofit =
organization in
Philadelphia, PA, commissioned artist Meg Saligman to develop a =
city-wide
mural that combines found text and fine art.  The centerpiece of the =
project
is a 5,000 sq. ft. mural on the eastbound side of the Schuylkill =
Expressway
at the Girard Avenue Bridge. Figures bound out of trompe l=92oeil =
signage
directing drivers to Central Philly, where they can begin the treasure =
hunt.
Nineteen satellite murals are hidden throughout the city. Murals are
site-specific and reflect the history and people through images and =
sound
bites recorded at each site. All murals display the Passing Through =
logo,
which resembles an Interstate sign.=20

=20

For the first time since its inception 20 years ago the Mural Arts =
Program
is using

the internet to document the process of Passing Through as murals pop up
throughout

the city. Take the scenic route =96 http://www.passingthrough.org. =
=93Passing
Through is a

pioneering project for the Mural Arts Program, especially meaningful in =
our
twentieth

anniversary year,=94 says Jane Golden, Director of the Mural Arts =
Program.
=93Although

there are a number of mural series throughout the city loosely connected =
by
theme,

artist or sponsor, Passing Through is Mural Arts Program=92s first truly
citywide project.=94

=20

Passing Through murals are located in Fishtown, Rittenhouse Square, the

Italian Market, North Philadelphia, Penn=92s Landing, Strawberry =
Mansion,
Queen Village,

Fairhill, Northern Liberties, Old City, Port Richmond, and on South =
Street,
Girard

Avenue, and Columbus Boulevard.

=20

For more information about the project, visit www.passingthrough.org
<http://www.passingthrough.org/> .  For more information about Mural =
Arts,
visit www.muralarts.org.

=20

******ARE MURALS ART OR ADVERTISING? PORTLAND, OR

=20

In 1998 Clear Channel sued the city of Portland, OR over its sign code,
claiming that its distinction between signs and murals was =
unconstitutional
because it regulated speech based on content.  Since the lawsuit, the =
city
combined murals and signs, placing a size limit and implementing a
permitting process, and the numbers of murals has decreased.  The debate =
was
revived last year when two businesses were given fines for
larger-than-allowed murals. Wooden boards now cover up all but 200 =
square
feet of one of the murals.   Mayor Vera Katz has a proposal to have the
murals reviewed by the Regional Arts and Culture Council by a panel of
artists and advocates that currently gather once a month to review =
public
art proposals. One mural expert will be added to the panel, Kuhn said, =
and
the group will consider projects based on a set of criteria such as =
context,
scale, diversity, community support and originality. =20

=20

For more information about the debate, read the article =93Katz Plans =
Way Out
of Mural Mire=94 by Jennifer Anderson in the Portland Tribune on October =
1st.


=20

Visit: http://www.portlandtribune.com/archview.cgi?id=3D26378

=20

*****EPA MURAL CONTROVERSEY: WASHINGTON, DC


On September 22, 2004 Cybercast News Service reported that The Lawyers
Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, on behalf of Native American EPA
employees, used the opening event of the National Museum of the American
Indian as a backdrop to renew a four year old effort to protest murals
located at the Environmental Protection Agency, on the grounds that they
"perpetuate stereotypes of Native Americans as savages, murderers and =
sexual
predators." The General Services Administration, who owns the work, is =
not
advocating for their removal, citing the National Historic Preservation =
Act,
and seeks to have their historical content better explained to promote
understanding of the work.=20

=20

To read the article, visit:=20
=20
<http://www.cnsnews.com/ViewNation.asp?Page=3D%5CNation%5Carchive%5C20040=
9%5CN
AT20040922a.html>
http://www.cnsnews.com/ViewNation.asp?Page=3D%5CNation%5Carchive%5C200409=
%5CNA
T20040922a.html=20

=20

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

NUEVOS RICOS =3D USA  AND THE FOREST: NEW YORK, NY

=20

On November 11th, Creative Time will premier Nuevos Ricos =3D USA, a =
one-night
cathartic dance performance curated by Carlos Amorales. Location, time, =
and
bands will be announced on www.creativetime.org on October 20.=20

=20

The record label Nuevos Ricos was founded in 2003 by long time =
collaborators
Carlos Amorales and Julian Lede to serve as a platform for combining =
their
ideas about performance, visual arts, music, spectacle and political
engagement.

=20

In addition to the Nuevos Ricos performance, Creative Time presents The
Forest, the first public project in the United States by Carlos Amorales =
in
Creative Time=B9s 59th Minute: Video Art on the Times Square =
Astrovision.
Presented in conjunction with the month-long Mexico Now festival, The =
59th
Minute project will include a talk at the Guggenheim Museum on November =
10.

=20

The Forest, created in 2003, represents Amorales=92 first foray into the =
realm
of animation.

Shifting from the performance arena where he gained international =
attention
for his Devil

Dances and Amorales vs. Amorales wrestling performances, the artist =
utilizes
a bold

graphic medium to expand upon the live action aspects of his previous =
work.
The result

is a new virtual performance.=20

=20

The piece opens with a troupe of Amorales' signature character=97a =
masked
wrestler

dressed in a business suit=97engaged in a series of visually arresting,
syncopated

rhythmic movements that are at once humorous and ominous. The sequence
continues

with silhouetted archetypal images of a flock of large black crows, the
forest, a writhing

woman, and a plane slowly descending from the sky. The dreamlike =
alternates
with the

menacing, and the rapid, repetitive succession of the symbols create a
pervasive sense

of apprehension and foreboding in the viewer. The imagery is drawn from
Amorales=92

archive, replete with Mexican iconography, including symbols taken from =
his
previous

apocalyptic installations combined with universal icons of pop culture.

Typical of the performances in which Amorales physically challenges the =
role
between

the public and the performer, in viewing The Forest, the spectator must
actively

participate with the work by interpreting the images based on his own
associations and

experiences. The animation is purposely designed to confound any attempt =
at
linear

narrative analysis, instead engaging visitors to free associate and =
explore
the concepts

of identity and the language of art. The animation, with its frenzied =
pace
and stark

broadly drawn imagery, thrives in the chaotic atmosphere of Times =
Square.

The 59th Minute airs daily in Times Square on the NBC Astrovision by
Panasonic on the

last minute of every hour from 6:00 a.m. =96 1:00 a.m., except between =
7:00 =96
9:00 a.m.

and 6:00 =96 7:00 p.m. at 43rd Street and the intersection of Broadway =
and 7th
Avenue.

www.creativetime.org/programs/59thMinute .

=20

For more information, and for details about the artist talk, visit
www.creativetime.org <http://www.creativetime.org/> .

=20

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

STONE CANOE SCULPTURES AND PUBLIC ART DAM WARNINGS: SWANTON, VT

=20

=20

National Parks Service Project

=20

For Immediate Release: October 4, 2004

=20

Contact:        Kate Williams, Northern Forest Canoe Trail / (802) =
496-2285

/ kate@northernforestcanoetrail.org

              Liesel Fenner, New England Foundation for the Arts / (617)
951-0010 / lfenner@nefa.org

=20

WHAT:   Community Celebration and Ribbon Cutting Ceremony:

        Stone Canoe Sculptures and Public Art Dam Warnings

=20

WHEN:   Saturday, October 16, 2004 10:00 AM - Noon

WHERE:  Marble Mill Park, Swanton, VT

WHO:    Evan W. Haynes, sculptor, North Yarmouth, ME; Stephen Dignazio,

        poet, Bethlehem, NH; Ron Smith, furniture-maker/sculptor =
Bethlehem,

        NH; with the Town of Swanton, and the Northern Forest Canoe =
Trail

=20

On Saturday October 16th, the ribbon will be cut on =93Stone Sculptures =
and
Public Art Dam Warnings=94  at Marble Mill Park in Swanton VT.  The =
project is
a collaboration of artist Evan W. Haynes, poet Stephen Dignazio, artist =
Ron
Smith with the Town of Swanton.  The project is part of the Art & =
Community
Landscapes, a partnership of New England Foundation for the Arts, =
National
Park Service, and the National Endowment for the Arts, with additional
support from the Vermont Arts Council and the LEF Foundation.

=20

The Stone Canoe Sculpture  is an installation of =91Swanton Red=92 local =
marble
carved into 15 individual stone seats that placed together, form the =
outline
of a canoe. This new amenity to the park will create a permanent seating =
and
gathering area along the Missisquoi River. The artwork has been in
development for over two years with partner organization the Northern =
Forest
Canoe Trail, in collaboration with the Town of Swanton.

=20

The Stone Canoe idea developed through the site=92s history as a portage =
and
fishing site as well as the location of the former Barney Marble Mill =
that
cut the locally quarried =91Swanton Red=92 marble. The Stone Canoe pays =
homage
to the historical use of the river as a transportation corridor and to =
the
natural resources that have provided life for the community of Swanton.

=20

In addition to the Stone Canoe Sculpture, the dedication will celebrate =
the
Swanton Dam Warnings, bright orange floating barrels with paddles that
rotate in the river current. The practical need for dam warnings and =
signage
directing paddlers inspired the artists to create ten polystyrene cast
orange barrels that were floated and strung across the Missisquoi River =
in
July. On the barrels=92 paddles, the artists added colorful text that on =
the
upstream side warned canoeists of the upcoming Swanton Dam.

=20

Viewed from downstream, the paddle text included written lines from a =
poem
that would change as the paddles rotated in the river current. The =
poetry
could be viewed by passersby on the nearby Route 78 bridge.

=20

The Swanton Stone Canoe and Dam Warnings are second and third in a =
series of
a large-scale public art projects including The Richford Project, an
on-going exhibition of photographs taken by Richford residents. Select
photographs as well as the series of "Postcards from the Trail" will be
exhibited at the Swanton Historical Society on October 16.

=20

Together these elements compose an Art & Community Landscapes =
environmental
public art project that is part of the developing Northern Forest Canoe
Trail, whose mission is to celebrate the rich human heritage and diverse
natural environment of the Northern Forest by establishing and =
stewarding a
water trail tracing historic Native American travel routes across New =
York,
Vermont, Qu=E9bec, New Hampshire, and Maine.

=20

For more information visit www.nefa.org

=20

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

JOB OPPORTUNITY: FORT WORTH, TX

=20

Fort Worth Public Art (Arts Council of Fort Worth & Tarrant County)

Public Art Project Manager

=20

Fort Worth Public Art has an immediate opening for an experienced Public =
Art
Project Manager.  This newly-created position will report to the Public =
Art
Director and will manage multiple public art projects generated by the =
2%
allocation from the $273.5 million 2004 CIP, as well as 2% allocations =
from
the city=92s Water and Sewer Fund, which generates over $500,000 =
annually for
public art.  The ideal candidate will have:

1.       1.       Bachelor=92s or Master=92s Degree in Art, Art History =
or
related field

2.       2.       A minimum of 3 years public art project management
experience =20

3.       3.       Knowledge of contemporary visual art and public art /
urban design issues  =20

4.       4.       Proven ability to work effectively with community =
members=20

5.       5.       An innovative approach to public art projects

=20

DEADLINE for applications is Monday, October 25, 2004, 5:00 p.m.   For
complete job description and application information please email
<mailto:mpeters@fwpublicart.org> mpeters@fwpublicart.org

+++++++++++++++++++++

ARTIST OPPORTUNITIES

=20

****Tacoma, WA
City of Tacoma
Deadline: November 1, 2004

=20

The City of Tacoma Park Office of Housing & Community Development is
accepting proposals for the Carroll Avenue Sidewalk Art Project.  The
project budget is $10,000. =20

=20

The selected artwork is to be located along one side of the Carroll =
Avenue
sidewalk and installed at ground level.  It must be essentially flush =
with
the surface of the sidewalk to avoid the creation of a tripping hazard.  =


=20

The area in which the selected artwork is to be installed is best =
described
as a slightly undulating 6-inch ribbon or strip, 800-feet in length that =
is
broken up by driveways and intersecting streets and private walks.  The
selected artwork will be located along the sidewalk, nearest the =
residences.
The sidewalk, to be constructed of poured white concrete, will be =
4-inches
thick.

=20

More detailed information and a copy of the Request for Proposal can be
found on the City's web site at www.cityoftakomapark.org

=20

Questions should be addressed to Sara Anne Daines, City of Takoma Park, =
7500
Maple Avenue, Takoma Park, MD 20912, (301) 891-7224, SaraD@takomagov.org =


=20

=20

****Longmont, CO
Longmont=92s Art in Public Places Program
Deadline: October 26, 2004 at 4:00 pm

=20

Longmont's Art in Public Places (AIPP) Commission is accepting =
applications
from artists or teams of artists who wish to be considered for Thompson
Park, a neighborhood park in Longmont=92s Historic Westside =
Neighborhood,
located in the central part of Longmont.  AIPP is a program of the City =
of
Longmont which is administered under the Longmont Museum & Cultural =
Center.=20

=20

The AIPP Commission is seeking artwork for this park which will take =
into
account the neighborhood, the history of the area, the many trees, the
cultural diversity surrounding this park, the age diversity of the =
visitors
to the park, as well as the seasonal changes that occur in the park =
itself.
The piece or pieces must work within the park and the neighborhood, as =
well
as add to the diversity of the current AIPP collection. =20

=20

For complete details, visit the program=92s website:=20

http://www.ci.longmont.co.us/museum/aipp/index.htm

 =20

 =20

****Austin, TX
The University of Texas at Austin

Deadline: November 15, 2004, 5:00 pm

=20

=20

The University of Texas at Austin Cesar Chavez Statue Committee and The
University of Texas System Board of Regents invite three-dimensional =
visual
artists to apply for consideration in the development of a commemorative
outdoor bronze statue in honor of the late Cesar E. Chavez.  The =
University
of Texas at Austin=92s student body voted on the initiative, which was =
later
approved by the Board of Regents, to apply student fees to the =
construction
of a statue on the main campus of The University of Texas at Austin.  A
total budget of $400,000 has been authorized toward the construction of =
the
sculpture and an endowed scholarship in Cesar Chavez=92s name.

=20

For complete details, visit:  <http://www.cesarchavezstatue.org/>
http://www.cesarchavezstatue.org

=20

****Austin, TX

The University of Texas at Austin

Deadline: November 15, 2004, 5:00 pm


The University of Texas at Austin Barbara Jordan Statue Project =
Committee
and The University of Texas System Board of Regents invite three =
dimensional
visual artists to apply for consideration in the development of a
commemorative outdoor bronze statue in honor of the late Barbara Jordan. =
The
University of Texas at Austin's student body and the Board of Regents =
have
authorized $400,000 toward the construction of the sculpture and an =
endowed
scholarship in Ms. Jordan's name.


For complete details, visit: http://www.barbarajordanstatue.org


+++++++++++++++++++++++


The PAN Weekly is a benefit of membership in Americans for the Arts.=20

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =

Manager<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Americans for the Arts<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++<o:p></o:p></span></fon=
t></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>AMERICANS FOR THE ARTS LAUNCHES THE ARTS ACTION =
FUND<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>On October 5<sup>th</sup>, Americans for the Arts =
announced
that is launching a major new initiative to involve individual citizens =
in
advocacy for the arts and arts education. <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal =
style=3D'mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto'><font
size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The creation
of the Americans for the <a href=3D"http://www.artsactionfund.org"><font
color=3Dblack><span style=3D'color:windowtext'>Arts Action =
Fund</span></font></a>
adds a new dimension to arts advocacy in the <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:country-region
 w:st=3D"on">United States</st1:country-region></st1:place> by providing =
a
vehicle through which any citizen can help ensure that all Americans =
have the
opportunity to appreciate, value, and participate in the arts. Later =
this
month, the Arts Action Fund will release a Congressional Report Card
highlighting the voting records of Members of the U.S. House of =
Representatives
on high-priority arts legislation. In November, a national =
citizens&#8217;
membership campaign will be launched to encourage Americans to join and =
support
the Arts Action Fund. <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal =
style=3D'mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto'><font
size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>&#8220;In
our work with arts organizations throughout the <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:country-region
 w:st=3D"on">United States</st1:country-region></st1:place>, we see =
enormous
public enthusiasm for the arts and arts education that is not reflected =
in
government decisions and school curricula,&#8221; said Robert L. Lynch,
president and CEO of Americans for the Arts. &#8220;It is time that =
elected
officials heard from the public when it comes to the arts and arts =
education.
This new citizens&#8217; membership initiative will harness the power of
individual citizens, joined together through the Arts Action Fund, and =
put it
to work to ensure that the arts are a vital presence in every community =
and
every public school in the nation.&#8221;<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal =
style=3D'mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto'><font
size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Over the
past two years, 40% of the funding for state arts councils has been =
eliminated;
several states have practically eliminated arts funding; and the share =
of
private giving has declined by over 40% in the last decade. In 1992, the =
arts
received 8.4 percent of all charitable giving.&nbsp; By 2003, it had =
dropped to
5.4 percent.&nbsp; If the arts maintained their 8.4 percent share of =
total
giving in 2003 ($240.72 billion), they would have received $20.22 =
billion
instead of $13.11 billion&#8212;a $7 billion difference. The Arts Action =
Fund
is intended in part to help reverse that =
pattern.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal =
style=3D'mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto'><font
size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The Arts
Action Fund will initially focus on four primary areas of activity: =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<ul type=3Ddisc>
 <li class=3DMsoNormal =
style=3D'mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3'><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
     10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Communicating with the Media and =
Candidates for
     Office&#8212;providing a leading voice on the importance and =
benefits of
     the arts to the media and candidates for office: hosting candidate =
forums,
     participating in town hall meetings, sponsoring advertisements, and
     helping shape candidates&#8217; positions and party platforms =
impacting
     the arts;<o:p></o:p></span></font></li>
 <li class=3DMsoNormal =
style=3D'mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3'><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
     10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Advocacy Training at the State and Local
     Levels&#8212;involving Americans for the Arts&#8217; extensive arts
     advocacy infrastructure and network at the state and local levels =
to help
     educate, train and connect individual arts advocates to local
     organizations;<o:p></o:p></span></font></li>
 <li class=3DMsoNormal =
style=3D'mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3'><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
     10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Evaluating Members of =
Congress&#8212;assessing
     and rating the voting records of Members of Congress on =
high-priority arts
     issues;<o:p></o:p></span></font></li>
 <li class=3DMsoNormal =
style=3D'mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3'><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
     10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Providing a Voice for the
     Public&#8212;aggressively petitioning to shape public policy at the
     federal level for the arts and arts =
education;<o:p></o:p></span></font></li>
</ul>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>For more information, visit: <a
href=3D"http://www.artsactionfund.org/"><font color=3Dblack><span =
style=3D'color:
windowtext'>www.artsactionfund.org</span></font></a>.<o:p></o:p></span></=
font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>The Washington Post published an article about the =
new
initiative titled &#8220;Arts Group to Use Lilly Funds for Advocacy =
Initiative&#8221;
by Jacqueline Trescott on October 5<sup>th</sup>.=A0 To read the article =
visit: <br>
<a =
href=3D"http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A7336-2004Oct4.html=
"
title=3D"http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A7336-2004Oct4.htm=
l"><font
color=3Dblack><span =
style=3D'color:windowtext'>http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/=
A7336-2004Oct4.html
</span></font></a><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++<o:p></o:p></span></fon=
t></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>NATIONAL MURAL NEWS<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>******MURAL MISSPELLING: <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City
 w:st=3D"on">LIVERMORE</st1:City>, <st1:State =
w:st=3D"on">CA</st1:State></st1:place><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>The new public library in <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City
 w:st=3D"on">Livermore</st1:City>, <st1:State =
w:st=3D"on">CA</st1:State></st1:place>
has a mural by artist Maria Alquilar at the entry.=A0 To its great =
dismay, the
library realized after installation that several of the names in the =
mural are
misspelled, including Einstein, Michelangelo, and Vincent Van Gogh.=A0 =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><br>
Only those of you who have never left out the &#8220;L&#8221; in public =
can
cast stones, but administrators across the country may want to place a
mandatory spell check in the review process for any work with text. =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Two stories about the =
project:<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><br>
</span></font><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
Arial'><a
href=3D"http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/state/20041006-1509-ca-library=
mispellings.html"
title=3D"http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/state/20041006-1509-ca-librar=
ymispellings.html"><font
color=3Dblack><span =
style=3D'color:windowtext'>&lt;http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/state/2=
0041006-1509-ca-librarymispellings.html&gt;</span></font></a><o:p></o:p><=
/span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>And <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><a =
href=3D"http://www.kesq.com/Global/story.asp?s=3D2394370"
target=3D"_blank" =
title=3D"http://www.kesq.com/Global/story.asp?s=3D2394370"><font
color=3Dblack><span =
style=3D'color:windowtext'>http://www.KESQ.com/Global/story.asp?s=3D23943=
70</span></font></a><br>
&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>*****CITY WIDE MURAL: <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City w:st=3D"on">PHILADELPHIA</st1:City>,
 <st1:State =
w:st=3D"on">PA</st1:State></st1:place><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>To celebrate their =
20<sup>th</sup>
anniversary, Mural Arts, a nonprofit organization in <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City
 w:st=3D"on">Philadelphia</st1:City>, <st1:State =
w:st=3D"on">PA</st1:State></st1:place>,
commissioned artist Meg Saligman to develop a city-wide mural that =
combines
found text and fine art. =A0<font color=3Dblack><span =
style=3D'color:black'>The
centerpiece of the project is a 5,000 sq. ft. mural on the eastbound =
side of
the Schuylkill Expressway at the <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName =
w:st=3D"on">Girard</st1:PlaceName>
 <st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Avenue</st1:PlaceName> <st1:PlaceType =
w:st=3D"on">Bridge</st1:PlaceType></st1:place>.
Figures bound out of trompe l&#8217;oeil signage directing drivers to =
Central
Philly, where they can begin the treasure hunt. Nineteen satellite =
murals are
hidden throughout the city. Murals are site-specific and reflect the =
history
and people through images and sound bites recorded at each site. All =
murals
display the Passing Through logo, which resembles an Interstate sign. =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p=
></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>For the
first time since its inception 20 years ago the Mural Arts Program is =
using<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>the
internet to document the process of Passing Through as murals pop up =
throughout<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>the
city. Take the scenic route &#8211; </span></font><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblue
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:blue'>http://www.passin=
gthrough.org.
</span></font><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial;color:black'>&#8220;Passing Through is =
a<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>pioneering
project for the Mural Arts Program, especially meaningful in our =
twentieth<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>anniversary
year,&#8221; says Jane Golden, Director of the Mural Arts Program.
&#8220;Although<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>there
are a number of mural series throughout the city loosely connected by =
theme,<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>artist
or sponsor, Passing Through is Mural Arts Program&#8217;s first truly =
citywide
project.&#8221;<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p=
></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>Passing
Through </span></font><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>murals are =
located in
Fishtown, <st1:Street w:st=3D"on"><st1:address w:st=3D"on">Rittenhouse =
Square</st1:address></st1:Street>,
the<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>Italian
Market, North Philadelphia, Penn&#8217;s Landing, <st1:PlaceName =
w:st=3D"on">Strawberry</st1:PlaceName>
<st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Mansion</st1:PlaceType>, <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName
 w:st=3D"on">Queen</st1:PlaceName> <st1:PlaceType =
w:st=3D"on">Village</st1:PlaceType></st1:place>,<o:p></o:p></span></font>=
</p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =

face=3DArial><span =

Northern Liberties, <st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Old</st1:PlaceName> =
<st1:PlaceType
w:st=3D"on">City</st1:PlaceType>, Port <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:City =
w:st=3D"on">Richmond</st1:City></st1:place>,
and on <st1:Street w:st=3D"on"><st1:address w:st=3D"on">South =
Street</st1:address></st1:Street>,
Girard<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span =

and <st1:Street w:st=3D"on"><st1:address w:st=3D"on">Columbus =
Boulevard</st1:address></st1:Street>.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =

face=3DArial><span =

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =

more information about the project, visit <a
href=3D"http://www.passingthrough.org/">www.passingthrough.org</a>. =
=A0For more
information about Mural Arts, visit =
www.muralarts.org.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>******ARE MURALS ART OR ADVERTISING? <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City
 w:st=3D"on">PORTLAND</st1:City></st1:place>, =
OR<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>In 1998 <span class=3Dstory-copy1><font color=3Dblack
face=3DArial><span style=3D'font-family:Arial'>Clear Channel sued the =
city of <st1:place
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City w:st=3D"on">Portland</st1:City></st1:place>, OR =
over its sign
code, claiming that its distinction between signs and murals was
unconstitutional because it regulated speech based on content.=A0 Since =
the
lawsuit, the city combined murals and signs, placing a size limit and
implementing a permitting process, and the numbers of murals has =
decreased.=A0 The
debate was revived last year when two businesses were given fines for
larger-than-allowed murals. Wooden boards now cover up all but 200 =
square feet
of one of the murals. =A0=A0Mayor Vera Katz has a proposal to have the =
murals
reviewed by the Regional Arts and Culture Council by a panel of artists =
and
advocates that currently gather once a month to review public art =
proposals.
One mural expert will be added to the panel, Kuhn said, and the group =
will
consider projects based on a set of criteria such as context, scale, =
diversity,
community support and originality.=A0 =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span class=3Dstory-copy1><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span class=3Dstory-copy1><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>For more information about =
the
debate, read the article &#8220;Katz Plans Way Out of Mural Mire&#8221; =
by Jennifer
Anderson in the Portland Tribune on October 1<sup>st</sup>.=A0 =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span class=3Dstory-copy1><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span class=3Dstory-copy1><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack face=3DArial><span

href=3D"http://www.portlandtribune.com/archview.cgi?id=3D26378">http://ww=
w.portlandtribune.com/archview.cgi?id=3D26378</a><o:p></o:p></span></font=

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span class=3Dstory-copy1><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack face=3DArial><span

nt></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span class=3Dstory-copy1><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>*****</span></font></span><f=
ont
size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>EPA MURAL
CONTROVERSEY: <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:City =
w:st=3D"on">WASHINGTON</st1:City>, <st1:State
 w:st=3D"on">DC</st1:State></st1:place><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><br>
On September 22, 2004 Cybercast News Service reported that The Lawyers
Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, on behalf of Native American EPA
employees, used the opening event of the National Museum of the American =
Indian
as a backdrop to renew a four year old effort to protest murals located =
at the
Environmental Protection Agency, on the grounds that they =
&quot;perpetuate
stereotypes of Native Americans as savages, murderers and sexual
predators.&quot; The General Services Administration, who owns the work, =
is not
advocating for their removal, citing the National Historic Preservation =
Act,
and seeks to have their historical content better explained to promote
understanding of the work. <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>To read the article, visit: <br>

href=3D"http://www.cnsnews.com/ViewNation.asp?Page=3D%5CNation%5Carchive%=

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++<o:p></o:p></span></font>=
