<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>NUEVOS RICOS =3D <st1:country-region =
w:st=3D"on">USA</st1:country-region>=A0
AND THE FOREST: <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:City w:st=3D"on">NEW =
YORK</st1:City>, <st1:State
 w:st=3D"on">NY</st1:State></st1:place><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>On November 11<sup>th</sup>, Creative Time will =
premier
Nuevos Ricos =3D <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:country-region =
w:st=3D"on">USA</st1:country-region></st1:place>,
a one-night cathartic dance performance curated by Carlos Amorales. =
Location,
time, and bands will be announced on <a =
href=3D"www.creativetime.org"><font
color=3Dblack><span =
style=3D'color:windowtext'>www.creativetime.org</span></font></a>
on October 20. <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The record label Nuevos =
Ricos was
founded in 2003 by long time collaborators Carlos Amorales and Julian =
Lede to
serve as a platform for combining their ideas about performance, visual =
arts,
music, spectacle and political engagement.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>In addition to the Nuevos =
Ricos
performance, Creative Time presents The Forest, the first public project =
in the
<st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:country-region w:st=3D"on">United =
States</st1:country-region></st1:place>
by Carlos Amorales in Creative Time=B9s 59th Minute: Video Art on the =
Times
Square Astrovision. Presented in conjunction with the month-long Mexico =
Now
festival, The 59th Minute project will include a talk at the <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName
 w:st=3D"on">Guggenheim</st1:PlaceName> <st1:PlaceType =
w:st=3D"on">Museum</st1:PlaceType></st1:place>
on November 10.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><i><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:italic'>The =
Forest</span></font></i><font
size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>, created in
2003, represents Amorales&#8217; first foray into the realm of =
animation.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Shifting from the =
performance arena
where he gained international attention for his <i><span =
style=3D'font-style:
italic'>Devil<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><i><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:italic'>Dances =
</span></font></i><font
size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>and <i><span
style=3D'font-style:italic'>Amorales vs. Amorales </span></i>wrestling =
performances,
the artist utilizes a bold<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>graphic medium to expand =
upon the
live action aspects of his previous work. The =
result<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>is a new virtual =
performance. <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The piece opens with a =
troupe of
Amorales' signature character&#8212;a masked =
wrestler<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>dressed in a business
suit&#8212;engaged in a series of visually arresting, =
syncopated<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>rhythmic movements that are =
at once
humorous and ominous. The sequence =
continues<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>with silhouetted archetypal =
images
of a flock of large black crows, the forest, a =
writhing<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>woman, and a plane slowly =
descending
from the sky. The dreamlike alternates with =
the<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>menacing, and the rapid, =
repetitive
succession of the symbols create a pervasive =
sense<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>of apprehension and =
foreboding in
the viewer. The imagery is drawn from =
Amorales&#8217;<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>archive, replete with =
Mexican
iconography, including symbols taken from his =
previous<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>apocalyptic installations =
combined
with universal icons of pop culture.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Typical of the performances =
in which
Amorales physically challenges the role =
between<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>the public and the =
performer, in viewing
<i><span style=3D'font-style:italic'>The Forest, </span></i>the =
spectator must
actively<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>participate with the work =
by
interpreting the images based on his own associations =
and<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>experiences. The animation =
is
purposely designed to confound any attempt at =
linear<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>narrative analysis, instead =
engaging
visitors to free associate and explore the =
concepts<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>of identity and the =
language of art.
The animation, with its frenzied pace and =
stark<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>broadly drawn imagery, =
thrives in
the chaotic atmosphere of <st1:place w:st=3D"on">Times =
Square</st1:place>.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><i><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:italic'>The 59th =
Minute </span></font></i><font
size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>airs daily
in <st1:place w:st=3D"on">Times Square</st1:place> on the NBC =
Astrovision by
Panasonic on the<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>last minute of every hour =
from 6:00
a.m. &#8211; 1:00 a.m., except between 7:00 &#8211; 9:00 =
a.m.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>and 6:00 &#8211; 7:00 p.m. =
at <st1:Street
w:st=3D"on"><st1:address w:st=3D"on">43rd =
Street</st1:address></st1:Street> and the
intersection of Broadway and <st1:Street w:st=3D"on"><st1:address =
w:st=3D"on">7th =
Avenue</st1:address></st1:Street>.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>www.creativetime.org/program=
s/59thMinute
.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>For more information, and for details about the =
artist talk,
visit <a =
href=3D"http://www.creativetime.org/">www.creativetime.org</a>.<o:p></o:p=
></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =

Celebration and
Ribbon Cutting Ceremony:<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0 Stone =
Canoe Sculptures and
Public Art Dam Warnings<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>WHEN:=A0=A0 Saturday, =
October 16, 2004
10:00 AM - Noon<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>WHERE:=A0 <st1:PlaceName =
w:st=3D"on">Marble</st1:PlaceName>
<st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Mill</st1:PlaceName> <st1:PlaceType =
w:st=3D"on">Park</st1:PlaceType>,
<st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:City w:st=3D"on">Swanton</st1:City>, =
<st1:State =
w:st=3D"on">VT</st1:State></st1:place><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>WHO:=A0=A0=A0 Evan W. =
Haynes, sculptor, <st1:place
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City w:st=3D"on">North Yarmouth</st1:City>, <st1:State =
w:st=3D"on">ME</st1:State></st1:place>;
Stephen Dignazio,<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0 poet, =
<st1:City w:st=3D"on">Bethlehem</st1:City>,
<st1:State w:st=3D"on">NH</st1:State>; Ron Smith, =
furniture-maker/sculptor <st1:place
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City =
w:st=3D"on">Bethlehem</st1:City></st1:place>,<o:p></o:p></span></font></p=
>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0 NH; =
with the Town of <st1:place
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City w:st=3D"on">Swanton</st1:City></st1:place>, and =
the Northern
Forest Canoe Trail<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>On Saturday October =
16<sup>th</sup>,
the ribbon will be cut on &#8220;Stone Sculptures and Public Art Dam =
Warnings&#8221;=A0
at <st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Marble</st1:PlaceName> <st1:PlaceName =
w:st=3D"on">Mill</st1:PlaceName>
<st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Park</st1:PlaceType> in <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City
 w:st=3D"on">Swanton</st1:City> <st1:State =
w:st=3D"on">VT.</st1:State></st1:place>=A0
The project is a collaboration of artist Evan W. Haynes, poet Stephen =
Dignazio,
artist Ron Smith with the Town of <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:City =
w:st=3D"on">Swanton</st1:City></st1:place>.=A0
The project is part of the Art &amp; Community Landscapes, a partnership =
of New
England Foundation for the Arts, National Park Service, and the National =
Endowment
for the Arts, with additional support from the Vermont Arts Council and =
the LEF
Foundation.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The Stone Canoe =
Sculpture=A0 is an
installation of &#8216;Swanton Red&#8217; local marble carved into 15
individual stone seats that placed together, form the outline of a =
canoe. This
new amenity to the park will create a permanent seating and gathering =
area
along the <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName =
w:st=3D"on">Missisquoi</st1:PlaceName>
 <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">River</st1:PlaceType></st1:place>. The =
artwork has
been in development for over two years with partner organization the =
Northern
Forest Canoe Trail, in collaboration with the Town of <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City
 =
w:st=3D"on">Swanton</st1:City></st1:place>.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The Stone Canoe idea =
developed
through the site&#8217;s history as a portage and fishing site as well =
as the
location of the former Barney Marble Mill that cut the locally quarried
&#8216;Swanton Red&#8217; marble. The Stone Canoe pays homage to the =
historical
use of the river as a transportation corridor and to the natural =
resources that
have provided life for the community of =
Swanton.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>In addition to the Stone =
Canoe
Sculpture, the dedication will celebrate the Swanton Dam Warnings, =
bright
orange floating barrels with paddles that rotate in the river current. =
The
practical need for dam warnings and signage directing paddlers inspired =
the
artists to create ten polystyrene cast orange barrels that were floated =
and
strung across the <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName =
w:st=3D"on">Missisquoi</st1:PlaceName>
 <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">River</st1:PlaceType></st1:place> in July. =
On the
barrels&#8217; paddles, the artists added colorful text that on the =
upstream
side warned canoeists of the upcoming Swanton =
Dam.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Viewed from downstream, the =
paddle
text included written lines from a poem that would change as the paddles
rotated in the river current. The poetry could be viewed by passersby on =
the
nearby Route 78 bridge.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The Swanton Stone Canoe and =
Dam
Warnings are second and third in a series of a large-scale public art =
projects
including The Richford Project, an on-going exhibition of photographs =
taken by
Richford residents. Select photographs as well as the series of =
&quot;Postcards
from the Trail&quot; will be exhibited at the Swanton Historical Society =
on
October 16.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Together these elements =
compose an
Art &amp; Community Landscapes environmental public art project that is =
part of
the developing Northern Forest Canoe Trail, whose mission is to =
celebrate the
rich human heritage and diverse natural environment of the Northern =
Forest by
establishing and stewarding a water trail tracing historic Native =
American
travel routes across New York, Vermont, Qu=E9bec, New Hampshire, and =
Maine.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>For more information visit =
<a
href=3D"www.nefa.org"><font color=3Dblack><span =
style=3D'color:windowtext'>www.nefa.org</span></font></a><o:p></o:p></spa=
n></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++<o:p></o:p></span></font>=
</p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>JOB OPPORTUNITY: <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:City =
w:st=3D"on">FORT
  WORTH</st1:City>, <st1:State =
w:st=3D"on">TX</st1:State></st1:place><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Fort Worth Public Art (Arts Council of <st1:place =
w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName
 w:st=3D"on">Fort Worth &amp; Tarrant</st1:PlaceName> <st1:PlaceType =
w:st=3D"on">County</st1:PlaceType></st1:place>)<o:p></o:p></span></font><=
/p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Public Art Project =
Manager<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoBodyText3><strong><b><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-weight:normal'>Fort =
Worth Public
Art</span></font></b></strong><strong><b><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-weight:normal'> =
</span></font></b></strong><font
size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>has an
immediate opening for an experienced Public Art Project Manager.=A0 This
newly-created position will report to the Public Art Director and will =
manage
multiple public art projects generated by the 2% allocation from the =
$273.5
million 2004 CIP, as well as 2% allocations from the city&#8217;s Water =
and
Sewer Fund, which generates over $500,000 annually for public art.=A0 =
The ideal
candidate will have:<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoBodyText3 =
style=3D'margin-left:75.0pt;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:

</span></font></span></span></font><![endif]><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span

bsp;&nbsp;
Bachelor&#8217;s or Master&#8217;s Degree in Art, Art History or related =
field<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoBodyText3 =

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><em><i><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:normal'><o:p>&nbsp=

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The City of Tacoma Park =
Office of
Housing &amp; Community Development is accepting proposals for the =
Carroll Avenue
Sidewalk Art Project.=A0 The project budget is $10,000.=A0 =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The selected artwork is to =
be
located along one side of the <st1:Street w:st=3D"on"><st1:address =
w:st=3D"on">Carroll
  Avenue</st1:address></st1:Street> sidewalk and installed at ground =
level.=A0 It
must be essentially flush with the surface of the sidewalk to avoid the
creation of a tripping hazard.=A0 <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The area in which the =
selected
artwork is to be installed is best described as a slightly undulating =
6-inch
ribbon or strip, 800-feet in length that is broken up by driveways and
intersecting streets and private walks.=A0 The selected artwork will be =
located
along the sidewalk, nearest the residences.=A0 The sidewalk, to be =
constructed of
poured white concrete, will be 4-inches =
thick.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fo=
nt></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-autospace:none'><font size=3D2 =
face=3DArial><span

and a copy
of the Request for Proposal can be found on the City's web site at <a

style=3D'color:windowtext'>www.cityoftakomapark.org</span></font></a><o:p=

<p class=3DMsoNormal><st1:City w:st=3D"on"><font size=3D2 =

 =

City><font

Public Places (AIPP) Commission is accepting applications from artists =
or teams
of artists who wish to be considered for <st1:PlaceName =
w:st=3D"on">Thompson</st1:PlaceName>
<st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Park</st1:PlaceType>, a neighborhood park in =
<st1:City
w:st=3D"on">Longmont</st1:City>&#8217;s Historic Westside =
Neighborhood,=A0 located
in the central part of <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:City =
w:st=3D"on">Longmont</st1:City></st1:place>.=A0
AIPP is a program of the City of <st1:City =
w:st=3D"on">Longmont</st1:City> which
is administered under the <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName =
w:st=3D"on">Longmont</st1:PlaceName>
 <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Museum &amp; Cultural</st1:PlaceType> =
<st1:PlaceType
 w:st=3D"on">Center</st1:PlaceType></st1:place>. =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>The AIPP Commission is seeking artwork for this park =
which
will take into account the neighborhood, the history of the area, the =
many
trees, the cultural diversity surrounding this park, the age diversity =
of the
visitors to the park, as well as the seasonal changes that occur in the =
park
itself.=A0 The piece or pieces must work within the park and the =
neighborhood, as
well as add to the diversity of the current AIPP collection.=A0 =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

 of <st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Texas</st1:PlaceName></st1:place> at =
Austin Cesar
Chavez Statue Committee and The University of Texas System Board of =
Regents
invite three-dimensional visual artists to apply for consideration in =
the
development of a commemorative outdoor bronze statue in honor of the =
late Cesar
E. Chavez.=A0 The <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">University</st1:PlaceType> =
of <st1:PlaceName
w:st=3D"on">Texas</st1:PlaceName> at <st1:City =
w:st=3D"on">Austin</st1:City>&#8217;s
student body voted on the initiative, which was later approved by the =
Board of
Regents, to apply student fees to the construction of a statue on the =
main
campus of The University of Texas at <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:City =
w:st=3D"on">Austin</st1:City></st1:place>.=A0
A total budget of $400,000 has been authorized toward the construction =
of the
sculpture and an endowed scholarship in Cesar Chavez&#8217;s =
name.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<h2 style=3D'text-align:justify'><b><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack =
face=3DArial><span

<st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on"><span =

an
class=3Dbaseboldred1><b><font color=3Dblack><span =

Committee</span></font></b></span></span></font></b><font

to apply for consideration in the development of a commemorative outdoor =

at <st1:City w:st=3D"on">Austin</st1:City>'s student body and the Board =

<h2 style=3D'text-align:justify'><b><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:windowtext;font-weight:=
normal'>+++++++++++++++++++++++<o:p></o:p></span></font></b></h2>

<h2 style=3D'text-align:justify'><b><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:windowtext;font-weight:=
normal'>The
PAN Weekly is a benefit of membership in Americans for the Arts. =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></b></h2>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoBodyText3><em><i><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:normal'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></fon=
t></i></em></p>

<p class=3DMsoBodyText3><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>=A0<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:Arial'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

=========================================================================
Date:         Fri, 15 Oct 2004 14:12:11 -0500
Reply-To:     Laurel Butler <laurel.butler@ARTS.STATE.TX.US>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Laurel Butler <laurel.butler@ARTS.STATE.TX.US>
Subject:      Call for Artists - Cesar Chavez Sculpture at the University of
              Texas at Austin
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
              boundary="=====================_21647656==_.ALT"

--=====================_21647656==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

The University of Texas at Austin invites 3-dimensional visual artists with
a history of creating and executing large-scale outdoor works to apply for
consideration in the development of an outdoor bronze statue in honor of
the late Cesar Chavez on the campus of the University in Austin, TX.

Initial review will be made based on past work.  In the first phase of the
project, three to five artists will be invited to develop maquettes for the
proposed statue. Each of the selected artists will receive $5,000 to
produce a maquette, which will become the property of the University of
Texas at Austin.  Selected artists will be expected to travel to Austin and
present their concept orally to the committee.

Submissions must be received by November 15, 2004.  Please go to
http://www.cesarchavezstatue.org for specific submission guidelines.


--=====================_21647656==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/html; charset="us-ascii"

<html>
<font face="CG Omega">The University of Texas at Austin invites
3-dimensional visual artists with a history of creating and executing
large-scale outdoor works to apply for consideration in the development
of an outdoor bronze statue in honor of the late Cesar Chavez on the
campus of the University in Austin, TX.<br>
<br>
Initial review will be made based on past work.&nbsp; In the first phase
of the project, three to five artists will be invited to develop
maquettes for the proposed statue. Each of the selected artists will
receive $5,000 to produce a maquette, which will become the property of
the University of Texas at Austin.&nbsp; Selected artists will be
expected to travel to Austin and present their concept orally to the
committee.<br>
<br>
Submissions must be received by November 15, 2004.&nbsp; Please go to
<a href="http://www.cesarchavezstatue.org/" eudora="autourl">http://www.cesarchavezstatue.org</a>
for specific submission guidelines.<br>
</font><br>
</html>

Date:         Fri, 15 Oct 2004 15:06:05 -0500
Reply-To:     Laurel Butler <laurel.butler@ARTS.STATE.TX.US>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Laurel Butler <laurel.butler@ARTS.STATE.TX.US>
Subject:      Call for Artists - Barbara Jordan Sculpture at the University of
              Texas at Austin
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
              boundary="=====================_1493734==_.ALT"

--=====================_1493734==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

The University of Texas at Austin invites 3-dimensional visual artists with
a history of creating and executing large-scale outdoor works to apply for
consideration in the development of an outdoor bronze statue in honor of
the late Barbara Jordan on the campus of the University in Austin, TX.

Initial review will be made based on past work.  In the first phase of the
project, three to five artists will be invited to develop maquettes for the
proposed statue. Each of the selected artists will receive $5,000 to
produce a maquette, which will become the property of the University of
Texas at Austin.  Selected artists will be expected to travel to Austin and
present their concept orally to the committee.

Submissions must be received by November 15, 2004.  Please go to
http://www.barbarajordanstatue.org for specific submission guidelines.

--=====================_1493734==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/html; charset="us-ascii"

<html>
<font face="CG Omega">The University of Texas at Austin invites
3-dimensional visual artists with a history of creating and executing
large-scale outdoor works to apply for consideration in the development
of an outdoor bronze statue in honor of the late Barbara Jordan on the
campus of the University in Austin, TX.<br>
<br>
Initial review will be made based on past work.&nbsp; In the first phase
of the project, three to five artists will be invited to develop
maquettes for the proposed statue. Each of the selected artists will
receive $5,000 to produce a maquette, which will become the property of
the University of Texas at Austin.&nbsp; Selected artists will be
expected to travel to Austin and present their concept orally to the
committee.<br>
<br>
Submissions must be received by November 15, 2004.&nbsp; Please go to
<a href="http://www.barbarajordanstatue.org/" eudora="autourl">http://www.barbarajordanstatue.org</a>
for specific submission guidelines.</font><br>
</html>

--=====================_1493734==_.ALT--
=========================================================================
Date:         Fri, 15 Oct 2004 17:34:29 -0500
Reply-To:     Kitty Pheney <kpheney@CRT.STATE.LA.US>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Kitty Pheney <kpheney@CRT.STATE.LA.US>
Subject:      Call for Artists-Please distribute
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Please distribut the following information regarding two new commissions through the Louisiana Percent for Art Program.
Thank you for your assistance,
Kitty

Kitty Pheney
Percent for Art Program Director
Louisiana Division of the Arts
1051 N. Third Street
Baton Rouge, LA 70802
225. 342. 8180
225. 342. 8173 Fax
kpheney@crt.state.la.us

Louisiana Percent for Art Program
2 Calls to Artists
This Call is not limited to Louisiana artists
Application Deadline: November 26, 2004
        The LaSalle Building, Baton Rouge

1. Six Exterior Niches Commission                $64,000
                                                 2. Interior Wall Commission (29' x 10')         $30,000


        Description of Commissions:
        1. Call for 6 Exterior Niches Commission
        The Percent for Art Program for the state of Louisiana, administered through the Louisiana Division of the Arts (LDOA), seeks an artist to create site specific works to fit within six existing niches in the building faade of the LaSalle Building located in downtown Baton Rouge. There are three niches above the East entrance to the building, and three niches above the North entrance. Each niche is 5'4" x 5'4", with a uniform top to bottom 12" depth. The sides are 6" deep with a 6" side step. The artist is asked to address each niche, but is not required to do so in the same fashion. For example, one niche may be completely filled with an artwork, while another niche may be occupied by a smaller work. The artist's budget for the commission is $64,000.00, and includes all costs such as travel, material, fabrication and installation, as well as engineering and conservation consultations. Artists are encouraged to visit the site before submitting their application. The physical address is 617 North Third Street. The pieces must be permanent in nature, and require very little long-term maintenance. All appropriate media will be considered for this commission. The fabrication of the artwork will be done off-site by the artist. The artist is also responsible for installing the work in the niches.

1.      Call for Interior Wall Commission (29' x 10')
The Percent for Art Program for the state of Louisiana, administered through the LDOA, seeks an artist to create a site-specific permanent indoor wall piece for the main wall of the caf in the LaSalle Building located at 617 North Third Street in downtown Baton Rouge.  Because the caf has many windows facing Third Street, this piece will be viewable from both the inside and the outside of the caf. The total space available for the piece is 29' x 10', but the artist may designate smaller dimensions of the finished work or works.  The artist's budget for the commission is $30,000.00, and includes all costs such as travel, material, fabrication, installation, as well as engineering and conservation consultation costs.  The work must be permanent in nature, and require very little long-term maintenance. All appropriate media will be considered for this commission (not limited to 2-D). However, 3-D applicants should keep in mind that the wall was not constructed to bear an exceptional amount of weight. Artists are encouraged to visit the site before submitting their application. The fabrication of the work will be done off-site by the artist. The artist will be responsible for installing the work(s) on the wall when completed.

*Application Deadline                   November 26, 2004

The Call for Artists as well as images of the building and grounds are accessible for view on the Louisiana Division of the Arts website: www.crt.state.la.us/arts under the Percent for Art link.
=========================================================================

Reply-To:     liz & shel <lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         liz & shel <lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM>
Subject:      Re: Finalist fees
Comments: To: Kitty Pheney <kpheney@CRT.STATE.LA.US>
MIME-Version: 1.0

              boundary="----=_NextPart_000_000A_01C4B427.951BD550"

------=_NextPart_000_000A_01C4B427.951BD550
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Regarding finalist fees, I was asked what I consider a low fee.  I am =
presently a finalist for a $28,500 project, about 90 miles from home. =
The fee is $250 for the proposal plus $100 for travel.  The theme for =
the work is very specific. I needed to go out and draw and photograph in =
nature, interview experts and do some reading.  After a site visit, =
drawing in my studio, mounting my drawings, preparing a written =
proposal, organizing the proper photos and going to present my proposal =
to the committee, I have a minimum of 40 hours of time into it, though =
probably more.  Was it enjoyable? Absolutely. Though even $500 would be =
low for that much time spent, it should be the minimum paid for any =
proposal. I agree with Kathleen that at least $1500 should be paid for =
any proposal that requires a maquette.



Shel Neymark

  ----- Original Message -----=20
  From: Kitty Pheney=20
  To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org=20
  Sent: Wednesday, October 13, 2004 2:08 PM
  Subject: Re: Finalist fees


  I think that sounds reasonable. I would still like to hear from an =
artist what they consider a reasonable fee for the creation of a =
proposal (do not include travel considerations). Thank you for any =
responses.

  Kitty Pheney=20
  Percent for Art Program Director=20
  Louisiana Division of the Arts=20
  1051 N. Third Street=20
  Baton Rouge, LA 70802=20

    On Oct 13, 2004, at 2:42 PM, Minette, Kathryn wrote:=20



    Depending on the scope and budget of the project we usually state in =
the=20

    prospectus that there will be up to 5 finalists for the larger =
project=20

    amounts and/or those that utilize a national call or 3 finalists for =
a=20

    smaller project budgets or a statewide call. We use the following =
method to=20

    determine compensation for the finalists. We encourage artists to =
spend at=20

    least $500 on a maquette and then determine travel in the following =
way:=20

    50-100 miles round trip for a site visit/presentation are paid an =
additional=20

    $100.=20

    100 - 300 are paid an additional $250=20

    300 - 800 " " " " $500=20

    800 - ? " " " " $750=20



    If the maximum number of finalists are not selected, the remaining =
dollar=20

    amount is put back into the project budget.=20



    Kathryn Minette=20

    Art in Public Places Program Manager=20

    P.O. Box 1450=20

    Santa Fe, NM 87504-1450=20

    -----Original Message-----=20

    From: liz & shel [mailto:lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM]=20

    Sent: Tuesday, October 12, 2004 5:47 PM=20

    To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org=20

    Subject: Re: Finalist fees=20




    I find it is a mixed blessing to be named a finalist for a project. =
On the=20

    one hand, glad to be in the running and have an opportunity to =
develop an=20

    idea for a public space. On the other hand you spend days or even =
weeks=20

    doing research, drawings models, etc and are usually paid a pittance =
for=20

    your time. I suspect that other artists wouldn't mind seeing final =
project=20

    fees be slightly lower inorder to pay finalists more for proposals. =
What=20

    does everyone else think?=20



    Shel Neymark=20

          Public Art List Serve <aftapubart-l@culturemail.org>,
          "Public Art Maine (E-mail)" <MACpublic@lists.state.me.us>,
          renee Piechocki <rpiechocki@artsusa.org>,
          Sparkle Hurst <shurst@crt.state.la.us>,
          Tri State Sculpture <tristatesculptors@main.nc.us>,
          Urban Arts Institute <christina.lanzl@massart.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----_=_NextPart_001_01C4B51A.93E694C8"

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B51A.93E694C8
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


Please distribute the following Call for Artists. Thank you

Call to Artists: THE LASALLE BUILDING=20
This Call is not limited to Louisiana artists

The Percent for Art Program for the state of Louisiana, administered =
through the Louisiana Division of the Arts, has issued a call to artists =
for two projects for the LaSalle Building in downtown Baton Rouge.  The =
deadline for applications is Nov. 26th.=20

1.      Six Exterior Niches Commission   $64,000
2.      Interior Wall Commission (29' x 10')      $30,000

Call for 6 Exterior Niches Commission
Seeking an artist to create site specific works to fit within six =
existing niches in the building fa=E7ade of the LaSalle Building located =
in downtown Baton Rouge. There are three niches above the East entrance =
to the building, and three niches above the North entrance. Each niche =
is 5'4" x 5'4", with a uniform top to bottom 12" depth. The sides are 6" =
deep with a 6" side step. The artist is asked to address each niche, but =
is not required to do so in the same fashion. For example, one niche may =
be completely filled with an artwork, while another niche may be =
occupied by a smaller work. The artist's budget for the commission is =
$64,000 and includes all costs such as travel, material, fabrication and =
installation, as well as engineering and conservation consultations. =
Artists are encouraged to visit the site before submitting their =
application. The physical address is 617 North Third Street. The pieces =
must be permanent in nature, and require very little long-term =
maintenance. All appropriate media will be considered for this =
commission. The fabrication of the artwork will be done off-site by the =
artist. The artist is also responsible for installing the work in the =
niches.=20

Call for Interior Wall Commission (29' x 10')
Seeking an artist to create a site-specific permanent indoor wall piece =
for the main wall of the caf=E9 in the LaSalle Building located at 617 =
North Third Street in downtown Baton Rouge.  Because the caf=E9 has many =
windows facing Third Street, this piece will be viewable from both the =
inside and the outside of the caf=E9. The total space available for the =
piece is 29' x 10', but the artist may designate smaller dimensions of =
the finished work or works.  The artist's budget for the commission is =
$30,000 and includes all costs such as travel, material, fabrication, =
installation, as well as engineering and conservation consultation =
costs.  The work must be permanent in nature, and require very little =
long-term maintenance. All appropriate media will be considered for this =
commission (not limited to 2-D). However, 3-D applicants should keep in =
mind that the wall was not constructed to bear an exceptional amount of =
weight. Artists are encouraged to visit the site before submitting their =
application. The fabrication of the work will be done off-site by the =
artist. The artist will be responsible for installing the work(s) on the =
wall when completed.

The complete call to artists is available online at =
<http://www.crt.state.la.us/arts/PercentforArt/LaSalleBuilding.htm>. To =
view images of the LaSalle Building, visit on the Web at =
<http://www.crt.state.la.us/arts/PercentforArt/LaSalleBldg_files/frame.ht=
m>. For more information, contact: Kitty Pheney or Judyth Demarest, =
Louisiana Division of the Arts, P. O. Box 44247, Baton Rouge, LA  =
70804-4247; or call (225) 342-8180; e-mail at kpheney@crt.state.la.us =
<mailto:kpheney@crt.state.la.us> or jdemarest@crt.state.la.us =
<mailto:jdemarest@crt.state.la.us>; or on the Web at =
<http://www.crt.state.la.us/arts/percentforart.htm>.=20

 <<Call for Artists_DED.doc>>=20
Kitty Pheney
Percent for Art Program Director
Louisiana Division of the Arts
1051 N. Third Street
Baton Rouge, LA 70802
225. 342. 8180
225. 342. 8173 Fax
kpheney@crt.state.la.us

Date:         Mon, 18 Oct 2004 12:17:41 -0700
Reply-To:     greg.esser@PHOENIX.GOV
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         greg.esser@PHOENIX.GOV
Subject:      Two Great Position Openings in Phoenix - Please Spread the Word!
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="=_alternative 0069FD1207256F31_="

This is a multipart message in MIME format.
--=_alternative 0069FD1207256F31_=
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

The Phoenix Office of Arts and Culture currently has two position
openings: Senior Public Art Project Manager and Public Art Project
Manager.  Links to more detailed job descriptions and on-line applications
are available below:

PUBLIC ART PROJECT MANAGER
Salary Range: $43,368 - $64,730 annualized.
Recruitment Dates: October 18, 2004 - October 29, 2004.
http://phoenix.gov/JOBS/adminjob.html#41210

SENIOR PUBLIC ART PROJECT MANAGER
Salary Range: $47,819 - $71,406 annualized.
Recruitment Dates: October 18, 2004 - October 29, 2004.
http://phoenix.gov/JOBS/adminjob.html#06040M

The application deadline is October 29, 2004.  The eligible lists for
these positions will remain effective for one year and we anticipate
having the opportunity to hire from at least one of the lists within the
coming year.

Thanks!

Greg Esser
Director, Public Art Program
phoenix.gov/arts
(602) 262-4637 phone
(602) 262-6914 fax

--=_alternative 0069FD1207256F31_=
Content-Type: text/html; charset="us-ascii"

Subject:      Visual Artist Nick Pace?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hello everyone -

Do any of you know of an American Indian visual artist called - Nick
Pace from California? He works in oils. I have a library bond project
manager looking for his contact information.

------------------------------------
Broward Cultural Division
Greta M. Willis

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B55D.51E3493C
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello,
=20
I am looking for some numbers regarding percent for art programs.=20
=20
If anyone who works for a percent for art program could let me know what
percentage (1/2%, 1%, 2%, etc) is designated for your public art
program, that would be wonderful. Also, if you could designate from what
fund this percentage is taken from (e.i. CIP budget), that would be very
useful.=20
=20
Thanks!
Caroline Danforth
Public Art Assistant
Arlington, Virginia
=20
Dept. of Parks, Recreation & Cultural Resources
Cultural Affairs Division
2100 Clarendon Blvd. Suite 414
Arlington, VA 22201
=20
703 228 3771 tel
703 228 3328 fax

Hi Caroline,
I was looking for this exact information recently.  I put together a quick
and dirty spreadsheet, which might be useful for you rather than trying to
collect all of the data again - yuck!  Take care.  (I can't say this is
absolutely accurate, but I think it's pretty close)

Brooke Jones, Public Art Program Coordinator
a: Office of Cultural Affairs
    365 S. Market Street
    San Jose, CA 95113
p: 408-277-2809
f:  408-277-3160
www.sanjoseculture.org/pub_art <http://www.sanjoseculture.org/pub_art>


-----Original Message-----
From: Caroline Danforth [mailto:Cdanforth@ARLINGTONVA.US]
Sent: Monday, October 18, 2004 2:56 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: percent for art programs


Hello,

I am looking for some numbers regarding percent for art programs.

If anyone who works for a percent for art program could let me know what
percentage (1/2%, 1%, 2%, etc) is designated for your public art program,
that would be wonderful. Also, if you could designate from what fund this
percentage is taken from (e.i. CIP budget), that would be very useful.

Thanks!


Caroline Danforth
Public Art Assistant
Arlington, Virginia

Dept. of Parks, Recreation & Cultural Resources
Cultural Affairs Division
2100 Clarendon Blvd. Suite 414
Arlington, VA 22201

703 228 3771 tel
703 228 3328 fax

-----Original Message-----
From: Caroline Danforth [mailto:Cdanforth@ARLINGTONVA.US]
Sent: Monday, October 18, 2004 2:56 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: percent for art programs

Hello,



I am looking for some numbers regarding percent for art programs.



If anyone who works for a percent for art program could let me know what
percentage (1/2%, 1%, 2%, etc) is designated for your public art program,
that would be wonderful. Also, if you could designate from what fund this
percentage is taken from (e.i. CIP budget), that would be very useful.



Thanks!

Caroline Danforth

Public Art Assistant

Arlington, Virginia



Dept. of Parks, Recreation & Cultural Resources

Cultural Affairs Division

2100 Clarendon Blvd. Suite 414

Arlington, VA 22201

703 228 3328 fax

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in'><font size=3 face="Century Gothic"><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Century Gothic"'>I am looking for some
numbers regarding percent for art programs. </span></font></p>

</div>

<div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in'><font size=3 face="Times New Roman"><span
style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></font></p>

</div>

<div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in'><font size=3 face="Century Gothic"><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Century Gothic"'>If anyone who works for a
percent for art program could let me know what percentage&nbsp;(1/2%, 1%, 2%,
etc) is designated for your public art program, that would be wonderful. Also,
if you could designate from what fund this percentage is taken from (e.i. CIP
budget), that would be very useful. </span></font></p>

</div>

Date:         Mon, 18 Oct 2004 16:52:14 -0700
Reply-To:     Dana Springs <DSprings@SANDIEGO.GOV>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Dana Springs <DSprings@SANDIEGO.GOV>
Subject:      Consistency in Applications
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="=_24041C2E.3B5B088D"

This is a MIME message. If you are reading this text, you may want to
consider changing to a mail reader or gateway that understands how to
properly handle MIME multipart messages.

--=_24041C2E.3B5B088D
Content-Type: text/plain;
 charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi PAN,
=20
We are in the process of exploring methods for achieving more consistency =
in the applications we receive in response to our RFQs.
=20
As an example of the inconsistency we typically face, we'll receive =
applications in which one artist has provided 20 slides of a single art =
project while another artist provides 20 slides of 20 different art =
projects. And some artists include images of proposals while other artists =
show images of only realized projects.
=20
Does anyone have image and image annotation list submittal requirements =
that go beyond just specifying the maximum number of images permitted? Or =
what do you ask for that goes beyond what we ask for? Our language is =
listed below (view this email in html for best results):
=20
=D8      Digital Images: A maximum of 20 digital images of past work. =
Please closely observe the following guidelines for the submittal of =
digital images: =A7         Submit a maximum of 20 images on a CD or =
DVD.=A7         Only submit .jpg images, not .tif or other image =
formats.=A7         Only submit images with maximum dimensions of 800 x =
600 pixels and minimum dimensions of 720 x 480 pixels.=A7         Load the =
images into a Power Point slide show presentation. Digital images not =
submitted in a Power Point presentation will not be reviewed.=A7         =
Label CD or DVD with the artist's name. (Please do not include the name of =
the artist's gallery, assistant or representative on the label.)=A7        =
 Number each image to correspond to the annotated image list.=A7         =
Commission is not responsible for distortion or alteration of images as =
they appear on monitors or are projected. =D8      Slides: A maximum of 20 =
slides (35mm) of past work may be submitted in lieu of digital images. (If =
more than 20 slides are submitted, only a random selection of 20 slides =
will be reviewed.) Please closely observe the following guidelines for the =
submittal of slides: =A7         Submit slides in a clear plastic slide =
sheet. (Top loading sheets are more desirable than side loading sheets.)=A7=
         Clearly label EACH slide with the artist's name. (Please do not =
include the name of the artist's gallery, assistant or representative on =
the label.) =A7         Label EACH slide to clearly indicate which side of =
the slide is the TOP.=A7         Number EACH slide to correspond to the =
annotated image list.=A7         Larger transparencies and prints will not =
be reviewed. =A7         Do not send original slides as the Commission is =
not responsible for loss or damage. =D8      Annotated Image List: If =
digital images in a Power Point are submitted, image annotations should be =
incorporated into the Power Point in lieu of a printed image annotation =
list. Panelists have found this method to be highly effective in learning =
about artists' work when reviewing numerous applications. Otherwise, =
please submit printed information (two pages maximum) with artist's name, =
email address, telephone number, title of artwork, medium, date artwork =
was created, size and corresponding image number. If you are submitting =
images of past work that cannot be understood plainly through imagery =
alone (such as installations, integrated artwork or team work), please =
submit brief descriptions for each work that you believe needs further =
explanation. Where appropriate, please be sure to specify what your =
contributions, as the artist, were for projects involving teams, integrated=
 artwork or collaborations with architects, etc. Handwritten materials =
will not be reviewed. (15 copies)
=20
Thank you in advance for anything you can share on this topic.=20
=20
=20
=20
=20
=20
Dana W. Springs
Public Art Project Coordinator
Commission for Arts and Culture
Mail Station 652
1010 Second Avenue, Suite 555
San Diego, CA 92101
(619) 533-3614
(619) 533-3788 fax
dsprings@sandiego.gov=20



--=_24041C2E.3B5B088D

style=3D"mso-list: Ignore">=A7<SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&=
nbsp;&nbsp;=20
</SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Commission is =
not=20
responsible for distortion or alteration of images as they appear on =
monitors or=20
are projected.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DMsoNormal=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 0.75in; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in 9.0pt 1.5in =
1.75in 139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:=
p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DLevel1=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 0.5in; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25in; mso-list: l3 =
level1 lfo1; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in 9.0pt list .5in left 1.5in 1.75in =
139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Wingdings; mso-fareast=
-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings"><SPAN=20
style=3D"mso-list: Ignore">=D8<SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;=20
</SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><B><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Slides</SPAN></=
B><B=20
style=3D"mso-bidi-font-weight: normal"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">:</SPAN></B><SP=
AN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"> A maximum of =
20=20
slides (35mm) of past work may be submitted <B=20
style=3D"mso-bidi-font-weight: normal"><U>in lieu of digital images</U></B>=
. (If=20
more than 20 slides are submitted, only a random selection of 20 slides =
will be=20
reviewed.) Please closely observe the following guidelines for the =
submittal of=20
slides:<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DLevel1=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0in; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in =
9.0pt 1.5in 1.75in 139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:=
p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DMsoNormal=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 1in; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25in; mso-list: l1 =
level2 lfo2; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in 9.0pt .5in list 1.0in left 1.5in =
1.75in 139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Wingdings; mso-fareast=
-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings"><SPAN=20
style=3D"mso-list: Ignore">=A7<SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&=
nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Submit slides =
in a=20
clear plastic slide sheet. (Top loading sheets are more desirable than =
side=20
loading sheets.)<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DLevel1=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 1in; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25in; mso-list: l1 =
level2 lfo2; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in 9.0pt list 1.0in left 1.5in 1.75in =
139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Wingdings; mso-fareast=
-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings"><SPAN=20
style=3D"mso-list: Ignore">=A7<SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&=
nbsp;&nbsp;=20
</SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Clearly =
label=20
<U>EACH</U> slide with the </SPAN><U><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">artist=92s</SPAN></U><SPAN=20=

style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"> name. (Please =
do not=20
include the name of the artist=92s gallery, assistant or representative on =
the=20
label.) <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DLevel1=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 1in; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25in; mso-list: l1 =
level2 lfo2; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in 9.0pt list 1.0in left 1.5in 1.75in =
139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Wingdings; mso-fareast=
-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings"><SPAN=20
style=3D"mso-list: Ignore">=A7<SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&=
nbsp;&nbsp;=20
</SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Label =
<U>EACH</U>=20
slide to clearly indicate which side of the slide is the=20
<U>TOP</U>.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DLevel1=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 1in; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25in; mso-list: l1 =
level2 lfo2; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in 9.0pt list 1.0in left 1.5in 1.75in =
139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Wingdings; mso-fareast=
-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings"><SPAN=20
style=3D"mso-list: Ignore">=A7<SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&=
nbsp;&nbsp;=20
</SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Number =
<U>EACH</U>=20
slide to correspond to the annotated image list.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DLevel1=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 1in; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25in; mso-list: l1 =
level2 lfo2; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in 9.0pt list 1.0in left 1.5in 1.75in =
139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Wingdings; mso-fareast=
-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings"><SPAN=20
style=3D"mso-list: Ignore">=A7<SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&=
nbsp;&nbsp;=20
</SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Larger =
transparencies=20
and prints will not be reviewed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DLevel1=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 1in; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25in; mso-list: l1 =
level2 lfo2; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in 9.0pt list 1.0in left 1.5in 1.75in =
139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Wingdings; mso-fareast=
-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings"><SPAN=20
style=3D"mso-list: Ignore">=A7<SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&=
nbsp;&nbsp;=20
</SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Do not send =
original=20
slides as the Commission is not responsible for loss or=20
damage.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=3DLevel1=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 0.25in; TEXT-INDENT: 0in; tab-stops: -1.0in =
-.5in 9.0pt 1.5in 1.75in 139.5pt 2.5in"><B=20
style=3D"mso-bidi-font-weight: normal"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:=
p></SPAN></B></P>
<P class=3DLevel1=20
style=3D"MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt 0.5in; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25in; mso-list: l2 =
level1 lfo5; tab-stops: -1.0in -.5in 9.0pt list .5in left 1.5in 1.75in =
139.5pt 2.5in"><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Wingdings; mso-fareast=
-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings"><SPAN=20
style=3D"mso-list: Ignore">=D8<SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;=20
</SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><B><SPAN=20
style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Annotated =
Image=20
List:</SPAN></B><SPAN style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 11pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: =
Arial">=20
If digital images in a Power Point are submitted, image annotations should =
be=20
incorporated into the Power Point in lieu of a printed image annotation =
list.=20
Panelists have found this method to be highly effective in learning =
about=20
artists=92 work when reviewing numerous applications. Otherwise, please =
submit=20
printed information (two pages maximum) with artist=92s name, email =
address,=20
telephone number, title of artwork, medium, date artwork was created, size =
and=20
corresponding image number. If you are submitting images of past work =
that=20
cannot be understood plainly through imagery alone (such as installations,=
=20
integrated artwork or team work), please submit <U>brief</U> descriptions =
for=20
each work that you believe needs further explanation. Where appropriate, =
please=20
be sure to specify what your contributions, as the artist, were for =
projects=20
involving teams, integrated artwork or collaborations with architects, =
etc.=20
Handwritten materials will not be reviewed. <B=20
style=3D"mso-bidi-font-weight: normal">(15 copies)</B><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P=
></DIV>

<DIV>Thank you in advance for anything you can share on this topic.&nbsp;</=

Subject: percent for art programs
=20
Hello,
=20
I am looking for some numbers regarding percent for art programs.=20
=20
If anyone who works for a percent for art program could let me know what
percentage (1/2%, 1%, 2%, etc) is designated for your public art
program, that would be wonderful. Also, if you could designate from what
fund this percentage is taken from (e.i. CIP budget), that would be very
useful.=20
=20
Thanks!
Caroline Danforth
Public Art Assistant
Arlington, Virginia

Cultural Affairs Division
2100 Clarendon Blvd. Suite 414
Arlington, VA 22201

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3D"Century =

what fund this percentage is taken from (e.i. CIP budget), that would be
very useful.=20

>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D3 color=3Dblack face=3D"Times New =
Roman"><span

2% -- For
more info visit <a =

Contact Kerry Kennedy at (954) 357-8005. <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

Subject:      Re: percent for art programs
Comments: To: Caroline Danforth <Cdanforth@ARLINGTONVA.US>

------=_NextPart_000_002A_01C4B5BF.A78886E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

For the State of Nebraska Public Art Program:

1% of captial expenditures for new construction in excess of $500,000 and
remodeling or renovation of public buildings in excess of $250,000 must be
set aside for the acquisition of art. (Neb. Rev. Statute Section 82-317,
orig. passed in 1978.)

Thanks,
LMT

Lisa Marie Tubach
Communications Manager/
Public Art Manager
Nebraska Arts Council
3838 Davenport
Omaha, NE  68131
800/341-4067
402/595-2122 (Omaha)
402/595-2334 (FAX)
http://www.nebraskaartscouncil.org

  -----Original Message-----
  From: AFTA Public Art discusion list
[mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org]On Behalf Of Caroline Danforth
  Sent: Monday, October 18, 2004 4:56 PM
  To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
  Subject: percent for art programs


  Hello,

  I am looking for some numbers regarding percent for art programs.

  If anyone who works for a percent for art program could let me know what
percentage (1/2%, 1%, 2%, etc) is designated for your public art program,
that would be wonderful. Also, if you could designate from what fund this
percentage is taken from (e.i. CIP budget), that would be very useful.

  Thanks!
  Caroline Danforth
  Public Art Assistant
  Arlington, Virginia

  Dept. of Parks, Recreation & Cultural Resources
  Cultural Affairs Division
  2100 Clarendon Blvd. Suite 414
  Arlington, VA 22201

  703 228 3771 tel
  703 228 3328 fax

>>> "Jones, Brooke" <Brooke.Jones@SANJOSECA.GOV> 10/18/04 03:20PM >>>
Hi Caroline,
I was looking for this exact information recently.  I put together a
quick
and dirty spreadsheet
=========================================================================
Date:         Tue, 19 Oct 2004 10:29:12 -0700
Reply-To:     Kristen Zaremba <Kristen.Zaremba@SFGOV.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Kristen Zaremba <Kristen.Zaremba@SFGOV.ORG>
Subject:      Re: percent for art programs
Comments: To: Kitty Pheney <kpheney@CRT.STATE.LA.US>
In-Reply-To:  <34A476CC23A0C04A803C99400CDB7868027A3C0B@mercury.crt.state.la.us>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII

Another thank you to Brooke for compiling this list! Two comments:
San Francisco's Public Art Program, which was not included in the
spreadsheet, but which I think most of you know, operates off a flat 2% for
art enrichment ordinance, so please add us to your lists!

Also, I know that the Public Art Network conducted a survey, in addition to
their Public Art Directory, which compiled detailed data of this sort a
year or two ago. I don't know if there is a means to upload this list to
the PAN site, but perhaps Renee can chime in?

Kristen

***************************************************************
The Arts Commission has a new website! Please visit:
www.sfartscommission.org

Kristen Zaremba, Project Manager

25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 240, San Francisco, CA 94102
Tel: 415-252-3296 / Fax: 415-252-2595

-----Original Message-----
From: Kristen Zaremba [mailto:Kristen.Zaremba@SFGOV.ORG]
Sent: Tuesday, October 19, 2004 10:29 AM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: percent for art programs


Another thank you to Brooke for compiling this list! Two comments:
San Francisco's Public Art Program, which was not included in the
spreadsheet, but which I think most of you know, operates off a flat 2% for
art enrichment ordinance, so please add us to your lists!

Also, I know that the Public Art Network conducted a survey, in addition to
their Public Art Directory, which compiled detailed data of this sort a
year or two ago. I don't know if there is a means to upload this list to
the PAN site, but perhaps Renee can chime in?

Kristen

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B608.F39B2D7C
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello.  Do any of you have art galleries associated with your programs?  =
We have a city art gallery here in Palm Desert and I am looking for a =
new lighting system.  We currently have an antiquated monorail lighting =
system.  I like the mechanics of the monorail system, but this one tends =
to short out.  If you have a system with which you are happy, would you =
mind forwarding me information on it?  Thanks.

Deborah Schwartz
Public Art Coordinator
City of Palm Desert
760 346 0611

Subject: Gallery Lighting



Hello.  Do any of you have art galleries associated with your programs?  We
have a city art gallery here in Palm Desert and I am looking for a new
lighting system.  We currently have an antiquated monorail lighting system.
I like the mechanics of the monorail system, but this one tends to short
out.  If you have a system with which you are happy, would you mind
forwarding me information on it?  Thanks.

Deborah Schwartz
Public Art Coordinator
City of Palm Desert

Date:         Tue, 19 Oct 2004 13:20:51 -0600
Reply-To:     Karen Bubb <KBubb@CITYOFBOISE.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Karen Bubb <KBubb@CITYOFBOISE.ORG>
Subject:      Roadway Art Programs
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Dear Colleagues,

Our county highway district has expressed interest in voluntarily
allocating 1-2% of their capital budget for art to be integrated into
roadway projects. They have asked us, the public art department for the
City of Boise, to create a plan for implemenation and to manage the
program. To that end I seek examples of programs or projects
specifically designed for roadways--freeways as well as residential
streets, traffic circles, crosswalks, etc. I'm also interested in
articles, plans, or books on the topic.

Many thanks. PAN rocks.

Karen Bubb

Public Arts Manager
Boise City Arts Commission
PO Box 500
Boise, ID 83701-0500
208/433-5677
=========================================================================
Date:         Tue, 19 Oct 2004 17:19:45 -0400
Reply-To:     Dian Magie <dmagie@CRAFTCREATIVITYDESIGN.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Dian Magie <dmagie@CRAFTCREATIVITYDESIGN.ORG>
Subject:      Re: Roadway Art Programs
Comments: To: KBubb@CityofBoise.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

We are in the final stages (I hope) of "On the Road Again...CREATIVE
TRANSPORTATION DESIGN" a project with a NEA Design grant that includes a
publication with 22 essays by transportation engineers, DOT directors,
artists, administrators etc. accompanied by a CD with 200+ images in 22
categories of surface transportation (from bike racks to bridges), and
there is also a traveling exhibit.  Contact me if you want more
information or go on our website for the PAN card if you have a project
that should be included.  I have talked to many of you as I'm tracking
down images that really should be included. The images for the exhibit
will be posted on our website in November.

The Center for Craft, Creativity and Design
A regional center of The University of North Carolina
dmagie@craftcreativitydesign.org
phone: 828-890-2050    fax 828-890-2060
www.craftcreativitydesign.org
mailing address: PO Box 1127, Hendersonville, NC 28793
location: 1181 Broyles Rd, Hendersonville, NC 28791



-----Original Message-----
From: Karen Bubb [mailto:KBubb@CITYOFBOISE.ORG]
Sent: Tuesday, October 19, 2004 3:21 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Roadway Art Programs


Dear Colleagues,

Our county highway district has expressed interest in voluntarily
allocating 1-2% of their capital budget for art to be integrated into
roadway projects. They have asked us, the public art department for the
City of Boise, to create a plan for implemenation and to manage the
program. To that end I seek examples of programs or projects
specifically designed for roadways--freeways as well as residential
streets, traffic circles, crosswalks, etc. I'm also interested in
articles, plans, or books on the topic.

Many thanks. PAN rocks.

Karen Bubb

Public Arts Manager
Boise City Arts Commission
PO Box 500
Boise, ID 83701-0500
208/433-5677

Hi Brooke -
This is such a great resource - thank you!
After looking through your updated version I realized our agency is listed
as King County Public Art Program. We have recently changed our name to
"4Culture" and function as a municipal corporation. We're still receive our
% for art funds through King County however.

Thanks again!
Heather

Heather Dwyer
Public Art 4Culture
TEL 206 296.8676
FAX 206 296.8629
506 Second Avenue
Suite 200
Seattle, WA 98104
 <http://www.4culture.org>

Subject: Re: percent for art programs


Hi again everyone,
I had lots of updates come back to me, so I've attached a new version of the
spreadsheet.  I realized after adding the SF program that I hadn't even put
my own program, San Jose, on there!  So, hopefully this is a little more
complete.  Thanks to everyone for getting back to me with corrections.

Cheers,
Brooke

Date:         Wed, 20 Oct 2004 09:42:07 -0400
Reply-To:     "Serber, Diane" <DSerber@DASNY.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         "Serber, Diane" <DSerber@DASNY.ORG>
Subject:      Re: percent for art programs
Comments: To: "Jones, Brooke" <Brooke.Jones@SANJOSECA.GOV>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Dear Brooke:

Thanks for your excellent spreadsheet.  I do have a correction:  NYS Dormitory Authority's Percent for Art funding on Line 145 is not 1% (would that it were!)  It is 1% to 1/2% (sliding scale) w/ a $400,000 cap.  I believe NYC's program on Line 147 is the same.

Diane Serber, FAIA
Associate Architect - Art Acquisition
Dormitory Authority of the State of New York

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 From the artists' perspective:  It would be greatly appreciated if the
public art administration commmunity
would formulate a standard method for electronic rfq submissions:
 powerpoint or pdf or?  file sizes, formats etc.
This is the moment to do this, before there are a hundred different
guidelines in place which will make it that
much harder an artist to comply.
-Mike Mandel

Altman, Mary L wrote:

> Colleagues:
>
>
>
> We are considering moving from slide to electronic visual RFQ
> submissions. Any insights or guidelines you could forward to me would
> be appreciated.
>
>
>
> Thanks again.
>
>
>
> Mary
>
>

> Mary Altman

From the artists' perspective: &nbsp;It would be greatly appreciated if the public
art administration commmunity<br>
would formulate a standard method for electronic rfq submissions: &nbsp;powerpoint
or pdf or? &nbsp;file sizes, formats etc.<br>
This is the moment to do this, before there are a hundred different guidelines
in place which will make it that<br>
much harder an artist to comply.<br>
-Mike Mandel<br>

Reply-To:     Julia Moore <jmoore@BLACKBURNARCHITECTS.COM>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Julia Moore <jmoore@BLACKBURNARCHITECTS.COM>

Comments: To: mike mandel <mike@thecorner.net>

              boundary="----_=_NextPart_001_01C4B6C1.29D9F5F0"
