Content-Type: text/plain

Oh, hardly me.  I'm glad to request a move towards standardization but I
don't know enough about digital images to define those standards.  I know
enough to do what I need to do and wish that some of the experts on this
list will chime in so I can expand my own knowledge.  Right now I request
jpgs and I put them into my own PowerPoint for consistency, and scan slides.



Julia Muney Moore

Public Art Administrator--New Indianapolis Airport (opens 2008)

Blackburn Architects

3388 Founders Rd

Indianapolis, IN  46268

317.875.5500 x230

FAX 317.875.0544

jmoore@blackburnarchitects.com

  _____

From: mike mandel [mailto:mike@thecorner.net]
Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 11:09 AM
To: Julia Moore
Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions



Powerpoint (Microsoft) and pdf (supported by most graphic designs apps) are
the two standards.
They're dual platform readable.  Powerpoint probably a little easier for
those not computer savvy to learn to create.
But I don't care what the standard is, as long as there is one.  I hate all
the busy work putting together packets for the rfq, and slides are expensive
to make continually and time consuming to prepare.  So, as long as there is
some standard, I'll be happy to conform to it.  But I'd like to see someone
in your community take the lead on this issue and build a consensus.
Maybe it's you?
-M.

Julia Moore wrote:



Mike-in your opinion, what would you like to see as a starting point?
(keeping in mind that a large number of artists haven't yet been able to let
go of exclusively slide documentation and haven't yet been convinced of the
desirability of digital submissions)



One other group that is also grappling with this issue is the art fair
industry.  They are trying to accelerate to all-digital submissions and
jurying (and a standardized submission format and website to do it) and are
encountering a lot of rocks in their path.  I've been following it rather
closely for ideas.  For information visit the digital information section of
the website of the NAIA (National Association of Independent Artists):
http://www.naia-artists.org/resources/digital.htm
<http://www.naia-artists.org/resources/digital.htm>



The process the industry is trying to use and which NAIA is endorsing is
called "Zapplication":  http://www.zapplication.org/
<http://www.zapplication.org/>   Unfortunately there is some conflict of
interest here, because the NAIA has a financial interest in the success of
Zapplication as do two of its most vocal members (Larry Berman and Chris
Maher).  I would like to see a bit more free-market competition going on in
that area in order to make the technology easier to use.  Here's some more
information as given out by an art fair:

http://www.uptownminneapolis.com/art-fair/index.php?module=pagemaster
<http://www.uptownminneapolis.com/art-fair/index.php?module=pagemaster&PAGE_
user_op=view_page&PAGE_id=29&MMN_position=28:17>
&PAGE_user_op=view_page&PAGE_id=29&MMN_position=28:17



I feel that digital RFQ selection processes are extremely desirable both for
archival and procedural reasons and I too would like public art
administrators to jointly develop a set of common principles, definitions
and methods.  I agree with Mike-now is the time before everyone gets too
invested in their own systems to change what they do.



Julia Muney Moore

Public Art Administrator--New Indianapolis Airport (opens 2008)

Blackburn Architects

3388 Founders Rd

Indianapolis, IN  46268

317.875.5500 x230

FAX 317.875.0544

jmoore@blackburnarchitects.com <mailto:jmoore@blackburnarchitects.com>

  _____

From: mike mandel [mailto:mike@THECORNER.NET <mailto:mike@THECORNER.NET> ]
Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 10:08 AM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org <mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org>
Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions



From the artists' perspective:  It would be greatly appreciated if the
public art administration commmunity
would formulate a standard method for electronic rfq submissions:
powerpoint or pdf or?  file sizes, formats etc.
This is the moment to do this, before there are a hundred different
guidelines in place which will make it that
much harder an artist to comply.
-Mike Mandel

Altman, Mary L wrote:




Colleagues:



We are considering moving from slide to electronic visual RFQ submissions.
Any insights or guidelines you could forward to me would be appreciated.



Thanks again.



Mary



Mary Altman

Public Arts Administrator

Minneapolis Community Planning

and Economic Development

210 City Hall

Minneapolis, MN 55415

612-673-3006

mary.altman@ci.minneapolis.mn.us <mailto:mary.altman@ci.minneapolis.mn.us>

<div class=3DSection1>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'>Oh, hardly me.&nbsp; I&#8217;m =
glad to
request a move towards standardization but I don&#8217;t know enough =
about
digital images to define those standards.&nbsp; I know enough to do =
what I need
to do and wish that some of the experts on this list will chime in so I =
can
expand my own knowledge.&nbsp; Right now I request jpgs and I put them =
into my
own PowerPoint for consistency, and scan =
slides.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>=

<p class=3DMsoNormal><b><font size=3D2 face=3DTahoma><span =

<b><span style=3D'font-weight:bold'>Subject:</span></b> Re: Electronic
Submissions</span></font><font face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

</div>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D3 face=3DVerdana><span =
style=3D'font-size:12.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D3 face=3DVerdana><span =
style=3D'font-size:12.0pt'>Powerpoint
(Microsoft) and pdf (supported by most graphic designs apps) are the =
two
standards.<br>
They're dual platform readable. &nbsp;Powerpoint probably a little =
easier for
those not computer savvy to learn to create.<br>
But I don't care what the standard is, as long as there is one. &nbsp;I =
hate
all the busy work putting together packets for the rfq, and slides are
expensive to make continually and time consuming to prepare. &nbsp;So, =
as long
as there is some standard, I'll be happy to conform to it. &nbsp;But =
I'd like
to see someone in your community take the lead on this issue and build =
a
consensus.<br>
Maybe it's you?<br>
-M.<br>
<br>
Julia Moore wrote:<br>
<br>
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'><u1:SmartTagType =

1:SmartTagType>Mike&#8212;in
your opinion, what would you like to see as a starting point? (keeping =
in mind
that a large number of artists haven&#8217;t yet been able to let go of
exclusively slide documentation and haven&#8217;t yet been convinced of =
the
desirability of digital =
submissions)<u1:p></u1:p></span></font><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'><u1:p>&nbsp;</u1:p></span></font><o=
:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'>One other group that is also =
grappling
with this issue is the art fair industry.&nbsp; They are trying to =
accelerate
to all-digital submissions and jurying (and a standardized submission =
format
and website to do it) and are encountering a lot of rocks in their =
path.&nbsp;
I&#8217;ve been following it rather closely for ideas.&nbsp; For =
information
visit the digital information section of the website of the NAIA =
(National
Association of Independent Artists):&nbsp; <a
href=3D"http://www.naia-artists.org/resources/digital.htm">http://www.na=
ia-artists.org/resources/digital.htm</a><u1:p></u1:p></span></font><o:p>=
</o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'><u1:p>&nbsp;</u1:p></span></font><o=
:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'>The process the industry is trying =
to use
and which NAIA is endorsing is called &#8220;Zapplication&#8221;:&nbsp; =
<a
href=3D"http://www.zapplication.org/">http://www.zapplication.org/</a> =
&nbsp;Unfortunately
there is some conflict of interest here, because the NAIA has a =
financial
interest in the success of Zapplication as do two of its most vocal =
members
(Larry Berman and Chris Maher).&nbsp; I would like to see a bit more
free-market competition going on in that area in order to make the =
technology
easier to use.&nbsp; Here&#8217;s some more information as given out by =
an art
fair:&nbsp; <u1:p></u1:p></span></font><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'><a
href=3D"http://www.uptownminneapolis.com/art-fair/index.php?module=3Dpag=
emaster&amp;PAGE_user_op=3Dview_page&amp;PAGE_id=3D29&amp;MMN_position=3D=
28:17">http://www.uptownminneapolis.com/art-fair/index.php?module=3Dpage=
master&amp;PAGE_user_op=3Dview_page&amp;PAGE_id=3D29&amp;MMN_position=3D=
28:17</a><u1:p></u1:p></span></font><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'><u1:p>&nbsp;</u1:p></span></font><o=
:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'>I feel that digital RFQ selection
processes are extremely desirable both for archival and procedural =
reasons and
I too would like public art administrators to jointly develop a set of =
common
principles, definitions and methods.&nbsp; I agree with Mike&#8212;now =
is the
time before everyone gets too invested in their own systems to change =
what they
do.<u1:p></u1:p></span></font><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D3 face=3DVerdana><span =
style=3D'font-size:12.0pt'>From
the artists' perspective: &nbsp;It would be greatly appreciated if the =
public
art administration commmunity<br>
would formulate a standard method for electronic rfq submissions:
&nbsp;powerpoint or pdf or? &nbsp;file sizes, formats etc.<br>
This is the moment to do this, before there are a hundred different =
guidelines
in place which will make it that<br>
much harder an artist to comply.<br>
-Mike Mandel<br>

From: AFTA Public Art discusion list =
[mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org]On Behalf Of mike mandel
Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 10:08 AM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions


From the artists' perspective:  It would be greatly appreciated if the =
public art administration commmunity
would formulate a standard method for electronic rfq submissions:  =
powerpoint or pdf or?  file sizes, formats etc.
This is the moment to do this, before there are a hundred different =
guidelines in place which will make it that
much harder an artist to comply.
-Mike Mandel

Altman, Mary L wrote:


Colleagues:



We are considering moving from slide to electronic visual RFQ =
submissions. Any insights or guidelines you could forward to me would be =
appreciated.



Thanks again.



Mary

=========================================================================
Date:         Wed, 20 Oct 2004 13:39:26 -0400
Reply-To:     Barbara Mercer <Barbara.Mercer@ARTSANDSCIENCE.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Barbara Mercer <Barbara.Mercer@ARTSANDSCIENCE.ORG>
Subject:      Re: Electronic Submissions
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
              boundary="----_=_NextPart_001_01C4B6CB.BE85A564"

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B6CB.BE85A564
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

PROS
Storage is so much easier (on a cd)
Slides carousels and projects are getting harder to obtain (and =
maintain)
CONS
Size of file - if you have 200 applicants for a project, 2000 .jpg's on =
PowerPoint is going to be a large file.  You'd have to separate into =
smaller files.  Then navigation could be an issue when your committee =
wants to review the shortlisted candidates. =20
Platform - Mac vs. PC?  This is why you would need to get .jpgs instead =
of PP presentation. =20
Cost and availability to artist - if you are trying to reach out to =
local or regional artists, you have to be concerned if they have the =
appropriate hardware and software to meet your submittal requirements. =20
=20
If any of you have successfully navigated these rapids I'd be interested =
in your feedback.
=20
Barbara Mercer
Associate Vice President, ASC Public Art Program
Charlotte, NC
704.372.9667 x232 (voice)
704.372.8210 (fax)
=20
=20
-----Original Message-----
From: Altman, Mary L [mailto:Mary.Altman@CI.MINNEAPOLIS.MN.US]
Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 10:26 AM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Electronic Submissions
=20
Colleagues:
=20
We are considering moving from slide to electronic visual RFQ =
submissions. Any insights or guidelines you could forward to me would be =
appreciated.
=20
Thanks again.
=20
Mary
=20
Mary Altman
Public Arts Administrator
Minneapolis Community Planning
and Economic Development
210 City Hall
Minneapolis, MN 55415
612-673-3006
612-673-2728 (fax)
mary.altman@ci.minneapolis.mn.us

        charset="iso-8859-1"

<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>
  <o:DoNotRelyOnCSS/>
 </o:OfficeDocumentSettings>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>
  <w:DocumentKind>DocumentEmail</w:DocumentKind>
  <w:EnvelopeVis/>
  <w:Compatibility>
   <w:BreakWrappedTables/>
   <w:SnapToGridInCell/>
   <w:WrapTextWithPunct/>
   <w:UseAsianBreakRules/>
  </w:Compatibility>

  <w:GrammarState>Clean</w:GrammarState>
 </w:WordDocument>
</xml><![endif]-->
<style>
<!--
span.EMAILSTYLE17
        {mso-style-noshow:yes;}
 /* Font Definitions */
@font-face
        {font-family:Tahoma;
        panose-1:2 11 6 4 3 5 4 4 2 4;
        mso-font-charset:0;
        mso-generic-font-family:swiss;
        mso-font-pitch:variable;

From:         Julia Moore <jmoore@BLACKBURNARCHITECTS.COM>
Subject:      Re: Electronic Submissions
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
              boundary="----_=_NextPart_001_01C4B6D1.2F381080"

This message is in MIME format. Since your mail reader does not understand
this format, some or all of this message may not be legible.

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B6D1.2F381080
Content-Type: text/plain

As for the large file size, perhaps you could separate it according to the
panel sessions:  before lunch vs after lunch on day 1, day 2.  Therefore,
your one large file is now 4 smaller files. (just an idea)



My personal issue is conversion of slides to jpegs.  There is quite a large
variety in quality of scanned slides-can anyone recommend a good model of
slide scanner attachment that is economical to purchase?



I think there will be a transition period for a while wherein we are running
a half-digital, half-slide panel process until conversion is accomplished.
Not looking forward to that one!



Julia Muney Moore

Public Art Administrator--New Indianapolis Airport (opens 2008)

Blackburn Architects

3388 Founders Rd

Indianapolis, IN  46268

317.875.5500 x230

FAX 317.875.0544

jmoore@blackburnarchitects.com

  _____

From: Barbara Mercer [mailto:Barbara.Mercer@ARTSANDSCIENCE.ORG]
Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 12:39 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions



PROS

Storage is so much easier (on a cd)

Slides carousels and projects are getting harder to obtain (and maintain)

CONS

Size of file - if you have 200 applicants for a project, 2000 .jpg's on
PowerPoint is going to be a large file.  You'd have to separate into smaller
files.  Then navigation could be an issue when your committee wants to
review the shortlisted candidates.

Platform - Mac vs. PC?  This is why you would need to get .jpgs instead of
PP presentation.

Cost and availability to artist - if you are trying to reach out to local or
regional artists, you have to be concerned if they have the appropriate
hardware and software to meet your submittal requirements.



If any of you have successfully navigated these rapids I'd be interested in
your feedback.



Barbara Mercer

Associate Vice President, ASC Public Art Program

Charlotte, NC

704.372.9667 x232 (voice)

704.372.8210 (fax)





-----Original Message-----

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'>As for the large file size, =
perhaps you
could separate it according to the panel sessions:&nbsp; before lunch =
vs after lunch
on day 1, day 2.&nbsp; Therefore, your one large file is now 4 smaller =
files. (just
an idea)<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>=


<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3DArial><span =

10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:navy'>My personal issue is conversion of =
slides
to jpegs.&nbsp; There is quite a large variety in quality of scanned =
slides&#8212;can
anyone recommend a good model of slide scanner attachment that is =
economical to
purchase?<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span class=3DEmailStyle20><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DTahoma><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt'>PROS<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-indent:.5in'><span =
class=3DEmailStyle20><font
size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3DTahoma><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt'>Storage is so
much easier (on a cd)<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-indent:.5in'><span =
class=3DEmailStyle20><font
size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3DTahoma><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt'>Slides carousels
and projects are getting harder to obtain (and =
maintain)<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span class=3DEmailStyle20><font size=3D2 =
color=3Dblack
face=3DTahoma><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt'>CONS<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-indent:.5in'><span =
class=3DEmailStyle20><font
size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3DTahoma><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt'>Size of file
&#8211; if you have 200 applicants for a project, 2000 .jpg&#8217;s on
PowerPoint is going to be a large file.&nbsp; You&#8217;d have to =
separate into
smaller files.&nbsp; Then navigation could be an issue when your =
committee wants to
review the shortlisted candidates.&nbsp; =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-indent:.5in'><span =
class=3DEmailStyle20><font
size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3DTahoma><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt'>Platform &#8211;
Mac vs. PC?&nbsp; This is why you would need to get .jpgs instead of PP
presentation.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></font></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-indent:.5in'><span =
class=3DEmailStyle20><font
size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3DTahoma><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt'>Cost and
availability to artist &#8211; if you are trying to reach out to local =
or
regional artists, you have to be concerned if they have the appropriate
hardware and software to meet your submittal requirements.&nbsp; =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-indent:.5in'><span =
class=3DEmailStyle20><font
size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3DTahoma><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-indent:.5in'><span =
class=3DEmailStyle20><font
size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3DTahoma><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt'>If any of you
have successfully navigated these rapids I&#8217;d be interested in =
your
feedback.<o:p></o:p></span></font></span></p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B6D1.2F381080--
=========================================================================
Date:         Wed, 20 Oct 2004 11:21:29 -0700
Reply-To:     greg.esser@PHOENIX.GOV
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         greg.esser@PHOENIX.GOV
Subject:      Re: Electronic Submissions
Comments: To: Barbara Mercer <Barbara.Mercer@ARTSANDSCIENCE.ORG>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="=_alternative 0064D72F07256F33_="

This is a multipart message in MIME format.
--=_alternative 0064D72F07256F33_=
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

The City of Phoenix is currently embarking on a pilot project to test an=20
on-line application system.

The system has addressed the concerned raised below:

The system would be platform indepedent since applications would be=20
uploaded through the internet.  The system is designed for jurying and has =

more than adequate storage space.  Additionally, WESTAF is able to provide =

technical assistance to any artists that need it.

We'll keep everyone on the listserve posted as we proceed later this year.

More information can be found below:

WESTAF, in partnership with 10 major art festivals and the National=20
Association of Independent Artists (NAIA), has developed a web-based=20
artist application and jurying system called ZAPP.  The ZAPP system will=20
enable individual artists to apply online to multiple art shows, either=20
through a central Web site, www.zapplication.org, or through the Web sites =

of specific art shows. The online application process also allows artists=20
to directly upload digital images of their artwork for jury review. The=20
result will be that all artwork in the system will be in a consistent,=20
quality, digital format. High-resolution digital images of artwork will be =

presented to the jury of each show, and slide projectors will be replaced=20
with high-resolution projectors connected to a specialized digital media=20
player called a Roku HD1000. The online application system will also=20
enable jurors to score online.=20

The ZAPP system will serve as a basic template for the pilot project that=20
the City of Phoenix and the Arizona Commission on the Arts are embarking=20
upon with WESTAF.  For more information about the system, including the=20
digital image specifications for artists, click here:  http://www.zapplicat=
ion.org.  Greg Esser
Director, Public Art Program
phoenix.gov/arts
(602) 262-4637 phone
(602) 262-6914 fax





Barbara Mercer <Barbara.Mercer@ARTSANDSCIENCE.ORG>
Sent by: AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC=5FART-L@culturemail.org>
10/20/2004 10:39 AM
Please respond to Barbara Mercer

=20
        To:     PUBLIC=5FART-L@culturemail.org
        cc:=20
        Subject:        Re: Electronic Submissions


PROS
Storage is so much easier (on a cd)
Slides carousels and projects are getting harder to obtain (and maintain)
CONS
Size of file ? if you have 200 applicants for a project, 2000 .jpg's on=20
PowerPoint is going to be a large file.  You'd have to separate into=20
smaller files.  Then navigation could be an issue when your committee=20
wants to review the shortlisted candidates.=20
Platform ? Mac vs. PC?  This is why you would need to get .jpgs instead of =

PP presentation.=20
Cost and availability to artist ? if you are trying to reach out to local=20
or regional artists, you have to be concerned if they have the appropriate =

hardware and software to meet your submittal requirements.=20
=20
If any of you have successfully navigated these rapids I'd be interested=20
in your feedback.
=20
Barbara Mercer
Associate Vice President, ASC Public Art Program
Charlotte, NC
704.372.9667 x232 (voice)
704.372.8210 (fax)
=20

Date:         Wed, 20 Oct 2004 12:04:07 -0700
Reply-To:     "Sindelar, Denise" <DSindelar@CI.VENTURA.CA.US>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         "Sindelar, Denise" <DSindelar@CI.VENTURA.CA.US>
Subject:      examples of public art evaluation surveys
Comments: To: "AFTAPUBART-l@culturemail.org" <AFTAPUBART-l@culturemail.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"

I am interested in finding examples of  evaluation surveys used to measure
the success or value to the community of individual public art projects. We
are looking to track each project's impact on the greater community when the
project is unveiled, but also over time as the work settles in to its
surroundings. Any info or comments would be appreciated.

Denise Sindelar
Public Art Project Manager
City of Ventura
(805)658-4793
dsindelar@ci.ventura.ca.us
=========================================================================
Date:         Wed, 20 Oct 2004 14:16:35 -0500
Reply-To:     Kitty Pheney <kpheney@CRT.STATE.LA.US>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Kitty Pheney <kpheney@CRT.STATE.LA.US>
Subject:      Re: Electronic Submissions
Comments: To: Barbara Mercer <Barbara.Mercer@ARTSANDSCIENCE.ORG>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
              boundary="----_=_NextPart_001_01C4B6D9.50C25D52"

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B6D9.50C25D52
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

One problem that we are having is being able to represent the artist's =
images in the best light. Right now, we only accept slides. We set up =
five projectors and project each artist's slides five at a time (maximum =
per artist is 10). This makes it so much easier for the jury to get an =
idea of the artist's body of work as opposed to seeing them one at a =
time. In a powerpoint presentation, we could have five on a page, but =
the size and thus the details of the pieces are smaller. I know =
everything is moving more digitally, but because of our current process, =
we don't necessarily see going all digital as an advantage....though we =
recognize it is an inevitability.
=20
Kitty Pheney=20
Percent for Art Program Director=20
Louisiana Division of the Arts=20
1051 N. Third Street=20
Baton Rouge, LA 70802=20
225. 342. 8180=20
225. 342. 8173 Fax=20
kpheney@crt.state.la.us=20

Slides carousels and projects are getting harder to obtain (and =
maintain)
CONS
Size of file - if you have 200 applicants for a project, 2000 .jpg's on =
PowerPoint is going to be a large file.  You'd have to separate into =
smaller files.  Then navigation could be an issue when your committee =
wants to review the shortlisted candidates. =20
Platform - Mac vs. PC?  This is why you would need to get .jpgs instead =
of PP presentation. =20
Cost and availability to artist - if you are trying to reach out to =
local or regional artists, you have to be concerned if they have the =
appropriate hardware and software to meet your submittal requirements. =20
=20
If any of you have successfully navigated these rapids I'd be interested =
in your feedback.

  <DIV class=3DOutlookMessageHeader dir=3Dltr align=3Dleft><FONT =

  size=3D2>-----Original Message-----<BR><B>From:</B> AFTA Public Art =

  <P class=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle19><FONT face=3DTahoma =

  size=3D2><SPAN=20
  style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Tahoma; mso-bidi-font-family: =
Arial; mso-bidi-font-size: =
12.0pt">PROS<o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>
  <P class=3DMsoNormal style=3D"TEXT-INDENT: 0.5in"><SPAN =
class=3DEmailStyle19><FONT=20
  face=3DTahoma color=3Dblack size=3D2><SPAN=20
  style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Tahoma; mso-bidi-font-family: =
Arial; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">Storage=20
  is so much easier (on a cd)<o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>
  <P class=3DMsoNormal style=3D"TEXT-INDENT: 0.5in"><SPAN =
class=3DEmailStyle19><FONT=20
  face=3DTahoma color=3Dblack size=3D2><SPAN=20
  style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Tahoma; mso-bidi-font-family: =
Arial; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">Slides=20
  carousels and projects are getting harder to obtain (and=20
  maintain)<o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>
  <P class=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle19><FONT face=3DTahoma =
color=3Dblack=20
  size=3D2><SPAN=20
  style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Tahoma; mso-bidi-font-family: =
Arial; mso-bidi-font-size: =
12.0pt">CONS<o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>
  <P class=3DMsoNormal style=3D"TEXT-INDENT: 0.5in"><SPAN =
class=3DEmailStyle19><FONT=20
  face=3DTahoma color=3Dblack size=3D2><SPAN=20
  style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Tahoma; mso-bidi-font-family: =
Arial; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">Size=20
  of file &#8211; if you have 200 applicants for a project, 2000 =
.jpg&#8217;s on PowerPoint=20
  is going to be a large file.<SPAN style=3D"mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;=20
  </SPAN>You&#8217;d have to separate into smaller files.<SPAN=20
  style=3D"mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </SPAN>Then navigation could be an =

  your committee wants to review the shortlisted candidates.<SPAN=20
  style=3D"mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; =

-----Original Message-----
From: AFTA Public Art discusion list
[mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org]On Behalf Of Sindelar, Denise
Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 2:04 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: examples of public art evaluation surveys


I am interested in finding examples of  evaluation surveys used to measure
the success or value to the community of individual public art projects. We
are looking to track each project's impact on the greater community when the
project is unveiled, but also over time as the work settles in to its
surroundings. Any info or comments would be appreciated.

Denise Sindelar
Public Art Project Manager
City of Ventura
(805)658-4793
dsindelar@ci.ventura.ca.us
=========================================================================
Date:         Wed, 20 Oct 2004 15:20:25 -0400
Reply-To:     Nancy.Novell@TOWNOFCARY.ORG
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Nancy.Novell@TOWNOFCARY.ORG
Subject:      Re: Electronic Submissions
In-Reply-To:  <7C30A08D8A30A2418B7EA1A5C0B5DD090681CAD7@ANACLTMSG03.na.ireadyworld.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

We have an on-going call for artists for exhibitions in town venues and
review twice per year. The application form includes a slide/image list for
artists to complete and submit along with their application.  It states
that artists can submit 10 slides or a cd with 10 digital images.  Each
slide/image must be numbered, 1-10.  It also states "For cd:  Artist's name
should be clearly printed in permanent marker on the cd and on the case.
Images on the cd should correspond with the slide/image list.  For slides:
Each slide much be labeled with artist's name and title of work.  Indicate
the top of each slide by writing TOP on each slide. Number each to
correspond with the slide/image list."

We recieved 14 applications for the last review - six were by slides, 8
were by cds.  I did have to spend a little while transferring the cd images
into PowerPoint (my program of choice - and the only option can actually
do) and then saved it on a cd in Powerpoint for presentation.  What I
found, though, was that this was fairly easy to do and pretty clear to
understand as far as images corresponding numerically with the slide/image
list submitted.  I actually preferred working from cds rather than slides
and there was no worry about whether or not the slide was upside down or
backwards.  It probably took as long to organize the presentation cd with
all the images as it would have to insert slides and review them.  I
assigned each artist a number and separated each artists images with a
corresponding numbered Powerpoint slide, so it was easy to go back and
forth to review.  I was concerned that the Powerpoint presentation would be
too long with all in one file, so it was saved in two files on the
presentation cd.

We're not ready to do away with accepting slides just yet, and the jury's
still out about artists' opinions of jury by cd (ease of application and
quality of photos).  Would like to have some artists' opinions on this.
But we will continue to offer both ways for a while and will be able to
track how artists respond.  It's getting easier and more affordable to have
photos made into a cds now and can be done at most photo labs.

Hope this helps somewhat.
Nancy


Nancy Novell
Public Art Coordinator

             Barbara Mercer
             <Barbara.Mercer@A
             RTSANDSCIENCE.ORG                                          To
             >                         PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
             Sent by: AFTA                                              cc
             Public Art
             discusion list                                        Subject
             <PUBLIC_ART-L@cul         Re: Electronic Submissions
             turemail.org>


             10/20/2004 01:39
             PM


             Please respond to
              Barbara Mercer
             <Barbara.Mercer@A
             RTSANDSCIENCE.ORG
                     >






PROS


Storage is so much easier (on a cd)


Slides carousels and projects are getting harder to obtain (and maintain)


CONS


Size of file  if you have 200 applicants for a project, 2000 .jpgs on
PowerPoint is going to be a large file.  Youd have to separate into
smaller files.  Then navigation could be an issue when your committee wants
to review the shortlisted candidates.


Platform  Mac vs. PC?  This is why you would need to get .jpgs instead of
PP presentation.


Cost and availability to artist  if you are trying to reach out to local
or regional artists, you have to be concerned if they have the appropriate
hardware and software to meet your submittal requirements.





If any of you have successfully navigated these rapids Id be interested in
your feedback.



Barbara Mercer
Associate Vice President, ASC Public Art Program
Charlotte, NC
704.372.9667 x232 (voice)
704.372.8210 (fax)

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Call to Artists
Application Deadline: November 26, 2004

Lake D'Arbonne State Park
Interactive Outdoor Sculpture - Visitor Center Project
BUDGET: $49,504.00


Description of Commission
The purpose of this commission is to create new site specific work ? an interactive outdoor sculpture that will invite the public to approach the Visitor Center area by piquing curiosity and stimulating interest to explore.  The areas available for exploration are: the immediate area around the Visitor Center, nature exhibits (to be located within the Visitor Center Building), nearby trails, and other aspects of the park. While not an absolute criterion, members of the Committee have expressed interest in subject matter relating to natural characteristics of the park, or evocative of the historical resources of the area. The work should foster exploration by all visitors.

The project site  *  the grassy area is a "scalene triangle" (with curved line segments) with the following measurements:
*Point A-to-B equals 30 feet (base)
*Point B-to-C equals 35 feet (right length)
*Point C-to-A equals 33 feet (left length)
The cement walkways that encompass the grassy area form the curves.

The location for this sculptural work will be a grass median to the right-front of the Visitor's Center, that was created by the intersection of sidewalks linking the Visitor's Center, a nearby picnic pavilion, path to hiking trail, and Lake D'Arbonne State Park Visitor Center pier area.

The fabrication of the artwork will be done off-site by the artist.  The artist is also responsible for installing the work when completed.

The complete Call to Artists is available online at the Louisiana Division of the Arts web site www.crt.state.la.us/arts <http://www.crt.state.la.us/arts> at the Percent for Art Link -Lake D'Arbonne Project and related images.

For more information, contact: Judyth Demarest, Program Manager, jdemarest@crt.state.la.us <mailto:jdemarest@crt.state.la.us> ; or Kitty Pheney, kpheney@crt.state.la.us or call (225) 342-8180 between 8 AM-4 PM cst;
Mailing address: Louisiana Division of the Arts, 1051 N. Third Street, Rm. 420, Baton Rouge, LA  70802;






Judyth Demarest
Percent for Art Manager
Louisiana Division of the Arts
Department of Culture, Recreation & Tourism
PO Box 44247, Rm 420
Baton Rouge, LA 70804
(225) 342-8180
(225) 342-2846 Direct
www.crt.state.la.us/arts

-----Original Message-----
From: Sindelar, Denise [mailto:DSindelar@CI.VENTURA.CA.US]
Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 2:04 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: examples of public art evaluation surveys

I am interested in finding examples of  evaluation surveys used to measure
the success or value to the community of individual public art projects. We
are looking to track each project's impact on the greater community when the
project is unveiled, but also over time as the work settles in to its
surroundings. Any info or comments would be appreciated.

Denise Sindelar
Public Art Project Manager
City of Ventura
(805)658-4793
dsindelar@ci.ventura.ca.us

ARTIST OPPORTUNITY-Please Post
=20
Texas Tech Health Sciences Center, El Paso=20
Medical School Complex, Plaza Design, Phase I & II
Project #: 01-03A & 02-23A
Deadline: 4 PM CST, Friday, December 10, 2004
Project Budget: $300,000 (Phase I), $350,000 (Phase II)
=20
The Texas Tech University System seeks to commission an artist, or team
of artists, to develop and implement a two-phased site plan for a
central plaza that will be a gathering area and focal point for a new
four-year medical school complex in El Paso, Texas. =20
=20
The plaza design should reflect the colorful cultural heritage of the El
Paso community and complement Texas Tech's Spanish Renaissance
architectural traditions.
=20
The successful artist or team of artists shall incorporate durable, low
maintenance materials and design sites for public presentations,
seating, shade, and quiet study or contemplation.   Any artist-designed
water features must comply with local water ordinances and restrictions.
=20
For a copy of the Request for Qualification, please visit the Texas
Marketplace at www.marketplace.state.tx.us
<http://www.marketplace.state.tx.us/> .  The direct link to the RFQ is
http://esbd.tbpc.state.tx.us/1380docs/768/56157%5F1%2Edoc.
=20
Cecilia Carter Browne
Public Art Manager
Texas Tech University System
P.O. Box 42014
Lubbock, Texas  79409-2014
=20
(806) 742-1170  x 319
(806) 787-0284 (cell)
(806) 742-1169 (fax)
=20

traditions.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

style=3D'margin-left:0in;line-height:12.0pt;
mso-line-height-rule:exactly;mso-list:skip'><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy
face=3D"Century Gothic"><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Century Gothic";
color:navy'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoBodyTextIndent2 =
style=3D'margin-left:0in;line-height:12.0pt;
mso-line-height-rule:exactly;mso-list:skip'><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy
face=3D"Century Gothic"><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Century Gothic";
color:navy'>The successful artist or team of artists shall incorporate =
durable,
low maintenance materials</span></font><font color=3Dnavy =
face=3D"Century Gothic"><span
style=3D'font-family:"Century =
Gothic";mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;color:navy'> and</span></font><font
color=3Dnavy face=3D"Century Gothic"><span style=3D'font-family:"Century =
Gothic";
color:navy'> design sites for public presentations, seating, shade, and =
quiet
study or contemplation.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp;&nbsp; =
</span>Any
artist-designed water features must comply with local water ordinances =
and
restrictions.<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dnavy face=3D"Century =
Gothic"><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Century =
Gothic";color:navy'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></font></p>

Gothic"><span

the Request for Qualification, please visit the Texas Marketplace at <a
href=3D"http://www.marketplace.state.tx.us/"><font color=3Dnavy><span
style=3D'color:navy'>www.marketplace.state.tx.us</span></font></a>.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The direct link to the RFQ is =
http://esbd.tbpc.state.tx.us/1380docs/768/56157%5F1%2Edoc.<o:p></o:p></sp=
an></font></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 face=3D"Century Gothic"><span =

Subject:      Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys
Comments: To: Kitty Pheney <kpheney@CRT.STATE.LA.US>
MIME-Version: 1.0

This message is in MIME format. Since your mail reader does not understand
this format, some or all of this message may not be legible.

------_=_NextPart_000_01C4B6F6.306D5C60
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="iso-8859-1"

Here are a couple of examples we have used here in San Jose.  One is a local
branch library project where we asked the community to respond based on the
schematic the artist presented to them.  The other is a general survey we
send out to active community members each quarter and we report the findings
to City Council.  The question asked is not one we came up with!  The two
just provide a snapshot, but we have found them useful for reporting
purposes.

Brooke Jones, Public Art Program Coordinator
Office of Cultural Affairs
365 S. Market Street
San Jose, CA 95113
p 408-277-2809
f  408-277-3160
www.sanjoseculture.org/pub_art

of the responses you get?

Kitty Pheney

-----Original Message-----
From: AFTA Public Art discusion list
[mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org]On Behalf Of Sindelar, Denise
Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 2:04 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: examples of public art evaluation surveys


I am interested in finding examples of  evaluation surveys used to measure
the success or value to the community of individual public art projects. We
are looking to track each project's impact on the greater community when the
project is unveiled, but also over time as the work settles in to its
surroundings. Any info or comments would be appreciated.

Denise Sindelar
Public Art Project Manager
City of Ventura
(805)658-4793
dsindelar@ci.ventura.ca.us

------=_NextPart_000_0021_01C4B6E7.6A950C30
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

It sounds great to submit images digitally instead of using slides.  =
Question:  Would we see commissions going to the artists who are most =
deft at manipulating their images?

Shel Neymark
box 25
Embudo NM 87531
shelneymark.com
  ----- Original Message -----=20
  From: Kitty Pheney=20
  To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org=20
  Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 1:16 PM
  Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions


  One problem that we are having is being able to represent the artist's =
images in the best light. Right now, we only accept slides. We set up =
five projectors and project each artist's slides five at a time (maximum =
per artist is 10). This makes it so much easier for the jury to get an =
idea of the artist's body of work as opposed to seeing them one at a =
time. In a powerpoint presentation, we could have five on a page, but =
the size and thus the details of the pieces are smaller. I know =
everything is moving more digitally, but because of our current process, =
we don't necessarily see going all digital as an advantage....though we =
recognize it is an inevitability.

  Kitty Pheney=20
  Percent for Art Program Director=20
  Louisiana Division of the Arts=20
  1051 N. Third Street=20
  Baton Rouge, LA 70802=20
  225. 342. 8180=20
  225. 342. 8173 Fax=20
  kpheney@crt.state.la.us=20

    -----Original Message-----
    From: AFTA Public Art discusion list =
[mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org]On Behalf Of Barbara Mercer
    Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 12:39 PM
    To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
    Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions


    PROS

    Storage is so much easier (on a cd)

    Slides carousels and projects are getting harder to obtain (and =
maintain)

    CONS

    Size of file - if you have 200 applicants for a project, 2000 .jpg's =
on PowerPoint is going to be a large file.  You'd have to separate into =
smaller files.  Then navigation could be an issue when your committee =
wants to review the shortlisted candidates. =20

    Platform - Mac vs. PC?  This is why you would need to get .jpgs =
instead of PP presentation. =20

    Cost and availability to artist - if you are trying to reach out to =
local or regional artists, you have to be concerned if they have the =
appropriate hardware and software to meet your submittal requirements. =20

    =20

    If any of you have successfully navigated these rapids I'd be =
interested in your feedback.

    =20

    Barbara Mercer

    Associate Vice President, ASC Public Art Program

    Charlotte, NC

    704.372.9667 x232 (voice)

    704.372.8210 (fax)

    =20

    =20

    -----Original Message-----
    From: Altman, Mary L [mailto:Mary.Altman@CI.MINNEAPOLIS.MN.US]
    Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 10:26 AM
    To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
    Subject: Electronic Submissions

    =20

    Colleagues:

    =20

    We are considering moving from slide to electronic visual RFQ =
submissions. Any insights or guidelines you could forward to me would be =
appreciated.

    =20

    Thanks again.

    =20

    Mary

    =20

    Mary Altman

    Public Arts Administrator

    Minneapolis Community Planning

    and Economic Development

    210 City Hall

    Minneapolis, MN 55415

    612-673-3006

    612-673-2728 (fax)

    mary.altman@ci.minneapolis.mn.us

    =20

  and project each artist's slides five at a time (maximum per artist is =
10).=20
  This makes it so much easier for the jury to get an idea of the =
artist's body=20
  of work as opposed to seeing them one at a time. In a powerpoint =
presentation,=20
  we could have five on a page, but the size and thus the details of the =
pieces=20
  are smaller. I know everything is moving more digitally, but because =
of our=20
  current process, we don't necessarily see going all digital as an=20
  advantage....though we recognize it is an =
inevitability.</FONT></SPAN></DIV>
  <DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>
  <P><FONT face=3DArial size=3D2>Kitty Pheney</FONT> <BR><FONT =
face=3DArial=20
  size=3D2>Percent for Art Program Director</FONT> <BR><FONT =
face=3D"Comic Sans MS"=20
  size=3D2>Louisiana Division of the Arts</FONT> <BR><FONT face=3D"Comic =
Sans MS"=20
  size=3D2>1051 N. Third Street</FONT> <BR><FONT face=3D"Comic Sans MS" =
size=3D2>Baton=20
  Rouge, LA 70802</FONT> <BR><FONT face=3D"Comic Sans MS" size=3D2>225. =
342.=20
  8180</FONT> <BR><FONT face=3D"Comic Sans MS" size=3D2>225. 342. 8173 =
Fax</FONT>=20
  <BR><FONT face=3D"Comic Sans MS" =
size=3D2>kpheney@crt.state.la.us</FONT> </P>

Date:         Thu, 21 Oct 2004 16:03:01 +1000
Reply-To:     neonart@OPTUSNET.COM.AU
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         neonart@OPTUSNET.COM.AU
Subject:      Re: Electronic Submissions
Comments: To: liz & shel <lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM>
Content-Type: text/plain
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary
Mime-Version: 1.0

Only as much as we now see commissions going to artists who engage the services
of exceptional, creative photographers. Just because it's a slide doesn't mean that the
work in  the flesh has the same impact as the photographic image.

And if you REALLY want to get worried... there's always the possibility of digital-image-
to-slide transfer... "we HAVE the technology".

Digital images are cheaper to duplicate (free) and faster to mail-out (instantaneous).
Images are really only a 'foot-in-the-door'; the project proposals, design development,
concept development and maquettes will seperate the wheat from the chaff.

David Forbes
neonart@optusnet.com.au


> liz & shel <lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM> wrote:
>
> It sounds great to submit images digitally instead of using slides.
> Question:  Would we see commissions going to the artists who are most
> deft at manipulating their images?
>
> Shel Neymark
> box 25
> Embudo NM 87531
> shelneymark.com
>   ----- Original Message -----
>   From: Kitty Pheney
>   To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
>   Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 1:16 PM
>   Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions
>
>
>   One problem that we are having is being able to represent the
> artist's images in the best light. Right now, we only accept slides. We
> set up five projectors and project each artist's slides five at a time
> (maximum per artist is 10). This makes it so much easier for the jury
> to get an idea of the artist's body of work as opposed to seeing them
> one at a time. In a powerpoint presentation, we could have five on a
> page, but the size and thus the details of the pieces are smaller. I
> know everything is moving more digitally, but because of our current
> process, we don't necessarily see going all digital as an
> advantage....though we recognize it is an inevitability.
>
>   Kitty Pheney
>   Percent for Art Program Director
>   Louisiana Division of the Arts
>   1051 N. Third Street
>   Baton Rouge, LA 70802
>   225. 342. 8180
>   225. 342. 8173 Fax
>   kpheney@crt.state.la.us
>
>     -----Original Message-----
>     From: AFTA Public Art discusion list
> [mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org]On Behalf Of Barbara Mercer
>     Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 12:39 PM
>     To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
>     Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions
>
>
>     PROS
>
>     Storage is so much easier (on a cd)
>
>     Slides carousels and projects are getting harder to obtain (and
> maintain)
>
>     CONS
>
>     Size of file - if you have 200 applicants for a project, 2000
> .jpg's on PowerPoint is going to be a large file.  You'd have to
> separate into smaller files.  Then navigation could be an issue when
> your committee wants to review the shortlisted candidates.
>
>     Platform - Mac vs. PC?  This is why you would need to get .jpgs
> instead of PP presentation.
>
>     Cost and availability to artist - if you are trying to reach out to
> local or regional artists, you have to be concerned if they have the
> appropriate hardware and software to meet your submittal requirements.
>
>
>
>
>     If any of you have successfully navigated these rapids I'd be
> interested in your feedback.
>
>
>
>     Barbara Mercer
>
>     Associate Vice President, ASC Public Art Program
>
>     Charlotte, NC
>
>     704.372.9667 x232 (voice)
>
>     704.372.8210 (fax)
>
>
>
>
>
>     -----Original Message-----

>     Subject: Electronic Submissions
>
>
>
>     Colleagues:
>
>
>
>     We are considering moving from slide to electronic visual RFQ
> submissions. Any insights or guidelines you could forward to me would
> be appreciated.
>
>
>
>     Thanks again.
>
>

>     Mary

Date:         Wed, 20 Oct 2004 20:52:01 -1000
Reply-To:     Kathleen Meehan <kmeehan777@EARTHLINK.NET>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Kathleen Meehan <kmeehan777@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Electronic Submissions
Comments: To: Nancy.Novell@TOWNOFCARY.ORG
In-Reply-To:  <OF8C12B6E5.7938A7C5-ON85256F33.0069F29C-85256F33.006A4699@ci.cary.nc.us>
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v619)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

As an artist, I would much prefer to send images on CD...it's cheaper
and easier.  I can't imagine
that it would be a problem for artists that now spend the money on good
slide dupes,
as it will save money in the long run whether they have the slides
scanned at a photo lab or purchase a
CD burner.

Kathleen Meehan
>
=========================================================================
Date:         Thu, 21 Oct 2004 09:07:20 -0500
Reply-To:     Julia Moore <jmoore@BLACKBURNARCHITECTS.COM>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Julia Moore <jmoore@BLACKBURNARCHITECTS.COM>
Subject:      Re: Electronic Submissions
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
              boundary="----_=_NextPart_001_01C4B777.477CA9C0"

This message is in MIME format. Since your mail reader does not understand
this format, some or all of this message may not be legible.

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4B777.477CA9C0
Content-Type: text/plain

This is a very real concern, Shel, and one that has stopped a lot of digital
initiatives (and not just in public art, but throughout the visual arts).  I
believe that there is so much more to an artist's qualifications than the
images of their past work, and I feel that what we'll start to see is more
stress laid on asking the artist to demonstrate their success throughout the
development of a project as a supplement to the visuals-such as defining the
concept, working with the community, working with architects and engineers,
knowledge of materials, etc.  I think with digitization there will be a
concurrent rise in requirements for non-visual documentation, professional
references and statements made by the artists.  It will be up to selection
panels to weigh all these elements in order to determine who will get the
commission.





Julia Muney Moore

Public Art Administrator--New Indianapolis Airport (opens 2008)

Blackburn Architects

3388 Founders Rd

Indianapolis, IN  46268

317.875.5500 x230

FAX 317.875.0544

jmoore@blackburnarchitects.com

  _____

From: liz & shel [mailto:lizshel@CYBERMESA.COM]
Sent: Wednesday, October 20, 2004 9:58 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions



It sounds great to submit images digitally instead of using slides.
Question:  Would we see commissions going to the artists who are most deft
at manipulating their images?



Shel Neymark

box 25

Embudo NM 87531

shelneymark.com

Date:         Thu, 21 Oct 2004 11:59:20 -0400
Reply-To:     Jennifer McGregor <jennifermcgregor@EARTHLINK.NET>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Jennifer McGregor <jennifermcgregor@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Electronic Submissions
Comments: To: Kitty Pheney <kpheney@CRT.STATE.LA.US>
In-Reply-To:  <34A476CC23A0C04A803C99400CDB7868028227CD@mercury.crt.state.la.us>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

From a panelists perspective, I have noticed that viewing slides (espeically
with multiple projectors) tends to be faster and the resolution clearer.
Opening up the jpegs can takes more more time than flashing up mutliple
slides (particularly if they are really high recolution).  This seems to be
situation of the moment that might be resolved as things get more
standardized.  It seems to be a question of equipment available, requesting
information in a standardized format and size, and time to organize
materials into a powerpoint presentation.

Jennifer McGregor
=========================================================================
Date:         Thu, 21 Oct 2004 07:24:48 -1000

The supplemental materials concept you describe makes sense, Julia, and=20=

I would think that manipulation
of artist's images wouldn't  affect selection committee's decisions,=20
because it's always been important to have high quality images in slide
form. The supplemental information you describe could be inferred from=20=

an artist's resume on the first call; i.e., large budget
projects, brief description of project in slide annotation sheet, etc.=20=

One way some agencies handle that is by limiting artists on a
large budget project to a minimum completed project; for instance,  on=20=

a $200,000 budget limit the competition to those who have
completed a $100,000 project, which means the artist would have already=20=

addressed most of those issues. Adding a requirement
for references is a good idea, but it might be better if that's for the=20=

finalist proposal stage to keep administrators from being inundated
with requests for referrals.

Kathleen Meehan
91-1058 Kekuilani Lp,N1301
Kapolei, HI 96707
707-722-2249
KMeehan777@earthlink.net
KathleenMeehan.com

> This is a very real concern, Shel, and one that has stopped a lot of=20=

> digital initiatives (and not just in public art, but throughout the=20
> visual arts).=A0 I believe that there is so much more to an artist=92s=20=

> qualifications than the images of their past work, and I feel that=20
> what we=92ll start to see is more stress laid on asking the artist to=20=

> demonstrate their success throughout the development of a project as a=20=

> supplement to the visuals=97such as defining the concept, working with=20=

> the community, working with architects and engineers, knowledge of=20
> materials, etc.=A0 I think with digitization there will be a =
concurrent=20
> rise in requirements for non-visual documentation, professional=20
> references and statements made by the artists.=A0 It will be up to=20
> selection panels to weigh all these elements in order to determine who=20=

> will get the commission.

The supplemental materials concept you describe makes sense, Julia,
and I would think that manipulation

of artist's images wouldn't  affect selection committee's decisions,
because it's always been important to have high quality images in slide

form. The supplemental information you describe could be inferred from
an artist's resume on the first call; i.e., large budget=20

projects, brief description of project in slide annotation sheet, etc.
One way some agencies handle that is by limiting artists on a=20

large budget project to a minimum completed project; for instance,  on
a $200,000 budget limit the competition to those who have=20

completed a $100,000 project, which means the artist would have
already addressed most of those issues. Adding a requirement=20

for references is a good idea, but it might be better if that's for
the finalist proposal stage to keep administrators from being
inundated=20

with requests for referrals.=20


Kathleen Meehan

91-1058 Kekuilani Lp,N1301

Kapolei, HI 96707

707-722-2249

KMeehan777@earthlink.net

KathleenMeehan.com

<excerpt><fontfamily><param>Arial</param><color><param>0000,0000,8080</par=
am><x-tad-bigger>This
is a very real concern, Shel, and one that has stopped a lot of
digital initiatives (and not just in public art, but throughout the
visual arts).=A0 I believe that there is so much more to an artist=92s
qualifications than the images of their past work, and I feel that
what we=92ll start to see is more stress laid on asking the artist to
demonstrate their success throughout the development of a project as a
supplement to the visuals=97such as defining the concept, working with
the community, working with architects and engineers, knowledge of
materials, etc.=A0 I think with digitization there will be a concurrent
rise in requirements for non-visual documentation, professional
references and statements made by the artists.=A0 It will be up to
selection panels to weigh all these elements in order to determine who
will get the commission.</x-tad-bigger></color></fontfamily>

This brings up the issue of how to store digital images.  I have been
researching digital image management software.  Does anyone have a program
that they would recommend for storing and cataloging JPEG images?

-----Original Message-----
From: AFTA Public Art discusion list [mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org]
On Behalf Of Jennifer McGregor
Sent: Thursday, October 21, 2004 10:59 AM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: Electronic Submissions

>From a panelists perspective, I have noticed that viewing slides
(espeically
with multiple projectors) tends to be faster and the resolution clearer.
Opening up the jpegs can takes more more time than flashing up mutliple
slides (particularly if they are really high recolution).  This seems to be
situation of the moment that might be resolved as things get more
standardized.  It seems to be a question of equipment available, requesting
information in a standardized format and size, and time to organize
materials into a powerpoint presentation.

Jennifer McGregor

Date:         Thu, 21 Oct 2004 16:37:21 -0500
Reply-To:     Meridith McKinley <mckinley@VIAPARTNERSHIP.COM>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Meridith McKinley <mckinley@VIAPARTNERSHIP.COM>
Subject:      FW: Electronic Submissions
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

-----Original Message-----
From: Modica, S. Lee [mailto:LModica@dos.state.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, October 21, 2004 4:13 PM
To: 'Meridith McKinley'
Subject: RE: Electronic Submissions


We are currently looking at an image storage, management and presentation
software that will allow stored images to be batched in a temporary
collection or "gallery," which can then, at the panel meeting, allow the
submitted images be reviewed in the software's presentation mode.  One neat
thing, during the presentation, you can click and temporarily delete images,
which certainly makes the 'weeding out' run-throughs quick and easy.  It's
called Portfolio 7 by Extensis (www.extensis.com).  If we decide on this
software, we will ask artists just to send their images numbered to
correspond to their image ID sheet but not already composed into a
PowerPoint presentation.

As for file format, it does seem that the compressed JPG is becoming
standard.

I agree that, over the coming months, various technologies and ease of use
considerations should be thoroughly discussed and some general parameters
agreed upon for all our sakes but especially for the artists.  I know that,
in the past, some programs got so detailed in their individual requirements
that artists spent much too much time on prep work.  We have a chance now
with this digital transition period to devise a system that, while not one
of strict, rigid requirements, can still provide a generally agreed-upon
framework, the adherence to which can make life easier for all of us.

Looking forward to more discussion,

Lee Modica, Administrator
Florida's Art in State Buildings Program
500 South Bronough Street, Room 405
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0250
850 / 245-6476       fax 850 / 245-6437
lmodica@dos.state.fl.us <mailto:lmodica@dos.state.fl.us>
www.Florida-Arts.org <http://www.Florida-Arts.org>

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law. Most written
communications to or from state officials regarding state business are
considered to be public records and will be made available to the public and
the media upon request. Therefore, your e-mail message may be subject to
public disclosure.

Date:         Thu, 21 Oct 2004 15:56:33 -0700
Reply-To:     susan@acsbco.org
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Susan Rice <susan@ACSBCO.ORG>
Subject:      Public Art Process
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The following question was posed to me by a local city arts commissioner.  I
have directed her to several resources including PAN, but any insight from
the professionals would be deeply appreciated.
chair the Cultural Arts Commission for the City of Redlands, and my fellow
commissioners and I are determined to see the development of a Public Art
Ordinance for our City. Can you recommend any useful sources of help for
this process? We need to know potential snags, timelines, legal
considerations, recommended issues to address - whatever would be helpful in
this process.
Thank you very much


Susan Rice
Executive Director
Arts Council for San Bernardino County
                       We Support the Arts!

mailing address:
PO Box 1380
San Bernardino, CA 92402
909-388-4126 phone
909-388-4130 fax

Subject:      Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys
Comments: To: "Sindelar, Denise" <DSindelar@CI.VENTURA.CA.US>

this format, some or all of this message may not be legible.

--MS_Mac_OE_3181239115_2116822_MIME_Part
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

Dear Denise,

I conducted a really interesting survey assignment with my Urban Development
and Visual Art class at NYU last year.  It was based on the work of Harriet
Senie, who has spoken about evaluation at PAN conferences and

The assignment is attached along with the survey questions developed by the
class.  Their findings were very insightful and would have been more
conclusive with a greater number of responses, but that was beyond the
purview of the class.  Twenty-three students looking at 23 different works
ten times was definitely not enough to make a conclusive evaluation, but it
was a start.  You might look at ways of enlisting and training students in
your area to help with such a project.

Sincerely,

Jennifer McGregor



> From: "Sindelar, Denise" <DSindelar@CI.VENTURA.CA.US>
> Reply-To: "Sindelar, Denise" <DSindelar@CI.VENTURA.CA.US>

> To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
> Subject: examples of public art evaluation surveys
>
> I am interested in finding examples of  evaluation surveys used to measure
> the success or value to the community of individual public art projects. We
> are looking to track each project's impact on the greater community when the
> project is unveiled, but also over time as the work settles in to its
> surroundings. Any info or comments would be appreciated.
>
> Denise Sindelar
> Public Art Project Manager

Greetings:

At the University of Pennsylvania, several of us are engaged in
evaluative research on public art. I am attaching two papers, one based
on research my students (in the Department of City Planning) have done
on public perceptions on public art, and one on an evaluation of the
mural arts in Philadelphia done by Penn's Social Impact of the Arts
Project (http://www.ssw.upenn.edu/SIAP/)


--Apple-Mail-18--97655744

        name="Muralsummary.pdf"

        format=flowed



In my class, we have been trying various experiments for three years=20
(the paper I am attaching reflects the findings of only the first=20
year). Our goal is not so much to judge whether people like a piece of=20=

art or not, but to get to deeper understanding of how people value art,=20=

and how art impacts its physical surroundings  I have not summarized=20
our findings about survey instruments yet, but I can suggest some=20
general lessons:

1. Questions that probe "do you like or dislike" do not yield as=20
informative results as open-ended questions like "tell me what you=20
think about ..."
2. We have had success with a survey method that offers people a choice=20=

of descriptive words, such as "beautiful," "funny" etc. and asks them=20
to circle the words they associate with the project. Then the=20
interviewer can follow up with questions like "I see you said this is=20
'beautiful.' Can you tell me why?"

Getting at the "success" of a project is a tougher matter, because in=20
order to construct a survey, you have to decide for yourself what a=20
measure of success is, then develop a survey to test it. At this very=20
moment, my students are reading Ellen Dissanyake's article "Why Public=20=

Art is Necessary" (in the book New=95Land=95Marks) and developing survey=20=

instruments to test the 10 reasons that she lists.

I'll have more to share after the semester is over, but would be happy=20=

to review and comment on any survey forms people want to share.

Todd Bressi
Brown & Keener Bressi
Urban Design =95 Place Planning
2300 Chestnut St., Suite 400
Philadelphia, PA  19103

215-751-1133

--Apple-Mail-18--97655744--

Date:         Sat, 23 Oct 2004 12:59:14 -0700

Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Marc Pally <mpally@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys
Comments: To: Todd Bressi <tbressi@BKURBANDESIGN.COM>
In-Reply-To:  <A77A006E-2455-11D9-8DE5-00039399187C@bkurbandesign.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=windows-1252; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Todd

I am intrigued by the investigation you and your students are pursuing
vis a vis a conversation with viewers in regards to their experience of
public art. I'm curious how this information might be used. On the one
hand it represents the possibility for artists and their sponsors to
gather insights about various responses to existing work. This can be of
interest and perhaps of some relevance to makers and sponsors of art. Is
this a kind of market research that gives artists and sponsors various
data from a number of respondents? What is the purpose of this data?
Does it assist in the construction of "successful models" which artists
might be "encouraged" to consider or even emulate. Or, is it merely
another means of fostering civic conversation by offering respondents
opportunities to both think about and articulate their experience of
various public artworks. Needless to say, my hope is that the latter
model prevails and that art remain a messy unpredictable business,
driven more by internal logic and instinct than opinion polls. After
all, it is art's very ability to synthesize experience and offer
redirection and examination of our sensory and linguistic systems that
make it so frequently confusing and compelling. Freedom from the proven
is an utter necessity for progress in all the arts and sciences.

Regards,

Marc

Todd Bressi wrote:

> Greetings:
>
> At the University of Pennsylvania, several of us are engaged in
> evaluative research on public art. I am attaching two papers, one based
> on research my students (in the Department of City Planning) have done
> on public perceptions on public art, and one on an evaluation of the
> mural arts in Philadelphia done by Penn's Social Impact of the Arts
> Project (http://www.ssw.upenn.edu/SIAP/)
>
>
>
> In my class, we have been trying various experiments for three years
> (the paper I am attaching reflects the findings of only the first
> year). Our goal is not so much to judge whether people like a piece of
> art or not, but to get to deeper understanding of how people value
> art, and how art impacts its physical surroundings I have not
> summarized our findings about survey instruments yet, but I can
> suggest some general lessons:
>
> 1. Questions that probe "do you like or dislike" do not yield as
> informative results as open-ended questions like "tell me what you
> think about ..."
> 2. We have had success with a survey method that offers people a
> choice of descriptive words, such as "beautiful," "funny" etc. and
> asks them to circle the words they associate with the project. Then
> the interviewer can follow up with questions like "I see you said this
> is 'beautiful.' Can you tell me why?"
>
> Getting at the "success" of a project is a tougher matter, because in
> order to construct a survey, you have to decide for yourself what a
> measure of success is, then develop a survey to test it. At this very
> moment, my students are reading Ellen Dissanyake's article "Why Public
> Art is Necessary" (in the book NewLandMarks) and developing survey
> instruments to test the 10 reasons that she lists.
>
> I'll have more to share after the semester is over, but would be happy
> to review and comment on any survey forms people want to share.
>
> Todd Bressi
> Brown & Keener Bressi
> Urban Design  Place Planning
> 2300 Chestnut St., Suite 400
> Philadelphia, PA 19103

Date:         Sat, 23 Oct 2004 14:18:05 -0700
Reply-To:     Helen Lessick <hlessick@JPS.NET>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Helen Lessick <hlessick@JPS.NET>
Subject:      Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys
Comments: To: mpally@EARTHLINK.NET
In-Reply-To:  <417AB812.2060204@earthlink.net>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Colleagues:

What precisely is being evaluated?  Does the notion of response tie to
purpose?  The survey is interesting but, like any poll, is contingent on
those willing to respond.

In examining how people value art, there is a presumed awareness of context,
and value in public spaces.  The perceived value of art in front of the
Rodin Museum may be quite different from the perceived value of a street
installation at the Philadelphia Fringe festival. Does the sample population
perceive nuances in funding sources?

I hope you will also look at how the original commissioning agencies value
public art.  One significant indicator is maintenance.  Even with the best
intentions and contracts, commissioned public art agencies rarely value
their works enough to maintain, conserve, or even condition report the
pieces.  Does this impact perceived value?

Per Marc's comment about freedom from the proven, the messy notion of
artists working will lead to art in public places.  But it may not be
publicly funded, or permanent, and it may not be valued by the general
public.  This is not a popularity contest, but an awareness of one's
surroundings.  I look forward to seeing your report Todd.

best,

Helen Lessick

> From: Marc Pally <mpally@EARTHLINK.NET>
> Reply-To: mpally@EARTHLINK.NET
> Date: Sat, 23 Oct 2004 12:59:14 -0700
> To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
> Subject: Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys
>
> Todd
>
> I am intrigued by the investigation you and your students are pursuing
> vis a vis a conversation with viewers in regards to their experience of
> public art. I'm curious how this information might be used. On the one
> hand it represents the possibility for artists and their sponsors to
> gather insights about various responses to existing work. This can be of
> interest and perhaps of some relevance to makers and sponsors of art. Is
> this a kind of market research that gives artists and sponsors various
> data from a number of respondents? What is the purpose of this data?
> Does it assist in the construction of "successful models" which artists
> might be "encouraged" to consider or even emulate. Or, is it merely
> another means of fostering civic conversation by offering respondents
> opportunities to both think about and articulate their experience of
> various public artworks. Needless to say, my hope is that the latter
> model prevails and that art remain a messy unpredictable business,
> driven more by internal logic and instinct than opinion polls. After
> all, it is art's very ability to synthesize experience and offer
> redirection and examination of our sensory and linguistic systems that
> make it so frequently confusing and compelling. Freedom from the proven
> is an utter necessity for progress in all the arts and sciences.
>
> Regards,
>
> Marc
>
> Todd Bressi wrote:
>
>> Greetings:
>>
>> At the University of Pennsylvania, several of us are engaged in
>> evaluative research on public art. I am attaching two papers, one based
>> on research my students (in the Department of City Planning) have done
>> on public perceptions on public art, and one on an evaluation of the
>> mural arts in Philadelphia done by Penn's Social Impact of the Arts
>> Project (http://www.ssw.upenn.edu/SIAP/)
>>
>>
>>
>> In my class, we have been trying various experiments for three years
>> (the paper I am attaching reflects the findings of only the first
>> year). Our goal is not so much to judge whether people like a piece of
>> art or not, but to get to deeper understanding of how people value
>> art, and how art impacts its physical surroundings I have not
>> summarized our findings about survey instruments yet, but I can
>> suggest some general lessons:
>>
>> 1. Questions that probe "do you like or dislike" do not yield as
>> informative results as open-ended questions like "tell me what you
>> think about ..."
>> 2. We have had success with a survey method that offers people a
>> choice of descriptive words, such as "beautiful," "funny" etc. and
>> asks them to circle the words they associate with the project. Then
>> the interviewer can follow up with questions like "I see you said this
>> is 'beautiful.' Can you tell me why?"
>>
>> Getting at the "success" of a project is a tougher matter, because in
>> order to construct a survey, you have to decide for yourself what a
>> measure of success is, then develop a survey to test it. At this very
>> moment, my students are reading Ellen Dissanyake's article "Why Public
>> Art is Necessary" (in the book NewLandMarks) and developing survey
>> instruments to test the 10 reasons that she lists.
>>
>> I'll have more to share after the semester is over, but would be happy
>> to review and comment on any survey forms people want to share.
>>
>> Todd Bressi
>> Brown & Keener Bressi
>> Urban Design  Place Planning
>> 2300 Chestnut St., Suite 400
>> Philadelphia, PA 19103
>>
>> 215-751-113
>> 3
