Date:         Mon, 25 Oct 2004 09:22:39 -0400
Reply-To:     Tim Collins <tcollins@ANDREW.CMU.EDU>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Tim Collins <tcollins@ANDREW.CMU.EDU>
Subject:      evaluation  and autonomy
Comments: cc: mpally@earthlink.net, Todd Bressi <tbressi@BKURBANDESIGN.COM>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Good Morning,
I've taken a few minutes to very quickly review Professor Bressi's work,
after Marc Pally's provocative comments, which got me engaged. In the
opening paragraph in Bressi's paper "Public Reaction to Public Art:
Preliminary Findings from the Field" I find what I think is the primary
goal of most progressive public art today."Increasingly, art projects are
regarded as integral to urban design, public infrastructure and
neighborhood revitalization initiatives." Unquestioning integration into
urban design and revitalization is the golden calf of public art. With
networked integration a public art program is robust with sustained long
term financing and political support.

Marc suggests that art must remain a "...messy unpredictable business with
its own internal logic" and "freedom from the proven." But the range of
response - is quite constrained by integration isn't it? To actually take a
critical and intentionally transformative stance on -urban design, -public
infrastructure, and/or -urban revitalization initiatives would run counter
to the goals of integrated long term public art programming. Wouldn't it?
Besides that the fact of the matter, is the art is an amenity brought to
the table of the primary designers who are themselves invested in the
intent of the development plan.

I would argue that artists need to consider models like any other
discipline or area of practice. Having colleagues and research initiatives
like the ones that support T.Bressi's work, and the work of the original
"Going Public" group is of utmost import. However you can't see the limits
of institutionalized public art programs by looking within the confines of
that realm of production alone. We need public art research models that
process and analyze social and environmental art practices as a whole.
Programs that provide artists and future administrators with a critical
overview of the limits and intent of institutionalized programs. We live in
a critical juncture in world history, civic discourse has collapsed,
environmental threats are global and global corporate interests are only
overshadowed by one of the most robust military industrial interests the
world has ever seen.

In this world we live in, artists and administrators NEED MODELS to help us
see beyond the limits of existing systems. We need to actively think and
dream new programs, new artworks that have real impact and effect,
contributing to the diversity of voices in dialogue. The social sciences
spend a lot of time considering those public art models that embrace and
enhance the dominant growth/development paradigm in U.S. Cities, while
ignoring he greater social-political impact of artists like John
Heartfield, Joseph Beuys, Paolo Friere, Hans Haacke, Suzanne Lacy, the
Harrisons, Wochenklausur, Kristof Wodiczko, Platform, the Critical Art
Ensemble, HaHa, Temporary Services... the list goes on and on. Artists with
recognized and robust public practices. By the way I wouldn't characterize
these artists for Marc's provocative guidelines of  "internal logic" or
their "confusing but compelling" products. The work listed above has clear
intent, method and product.

The Institutionalization of public art has led to a limited but clear
intent. In the words of Mr. Bressi the ideal is public art that supports
"urban design, public infrastructure and neighborhood revitalization
initiatives".

In response: The question isn't one of academic evaluations pushing this
area further into risk averse behavior, the question is how can the
institutional/funding model be transformed to provide the autonomy that
might lead to more diverse and critical intent?

t


--On Saturday, October 23, 2004 12:59 PM -0700 Marc Pally
<mpally@earthlink.net> wrote:

> Does it assist in the construction of "successful models" which artists
> might be "encouraged" to consider or even emulate. Or, is it merely
> another means of fostering civic conversation by offering respondents
> opportunities to both think about and articulate their experience of
> various public artworks. Needless to say, my hope is that the latter
> model prevails and that art remain a messy unpredictable business,
> driven more by internal logic and instinct than opinion polls. After
> all, it is art's very ability to synthesize experience and offer
> redirection and examination of our sensory and linguistic systems that
> make it so frequently confusing and compelling. Freedom from the proven
> is an utter necessity for progress in all the arts and sciences.



Timothy M. Collins, Research Fellow
Project Director, 3 Rivers 2nd Nature
The STUDIO for Creative Inquiry
Rm 111, College of Fine Arts
Carnegie Mellon University
Pittsburgh PA, 15213
412-268-3673

http://3r2n.cfa.cmu.edu
http://slaggarden.cfa.cmu.edu

Date:         Mon, 25 Oct 2004 10:30:31 -0400
Reply-To:     Todd Bressi <tbressi@BKURBANDESIGN.COM>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Todd Bressi <tbressi@BKURBANDESIGN.COM>
Subject:      Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys
Comments: To: mpally@earthlink.net
In-Reply-To:  <417AB812.2060204@earthlink.net>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=WINDOWS-1252; format=flowed
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v553)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Marc:
Good to hear from you.
A quick response: I stress that my research, at this point, has no
predictive value. I am not certain, in the field of public art, whether
it is possible to apply past experience to future endeavors. As of now,
I would be dubious of such claims because there are so, so many
variables that cannot be controlled.
The purpose of this research, at this point, is humanistic. We want to
learn more about how the art that already surrounds us enters into
people's lives -- how do people engage with it? Does it help them
engage with others? Does it help them make connections of any sort --
to their own selves, to the workings of the world, to the layout of the
city?
As we do this more and more, we may reach certain conclusions that
would guide future decisionmaking, but I think it would be more at the
level of where projects might be located, rather than how artists might
work expressively.

Todd Bressi
Brown & Keener Bressi
Urban Design  Place Planning
2300 Chestnut St., Suite 400
Philadelphia, PA  19103
215-751-1133

> to gather insights about various responses to existing work. This can

> data? Does it assist in the construction of "successful models" which

>> (the paper I am attaching reflects the findings of only the first
>> year). Our goal is not so much to judge whether people like a piece

>> art, and how art impacts its physical surroundings I have not
>> summarized our findings about survey instruments yet, but I can
>> suggest some general lessons:
>>

>> informative results as open-ended questions like "tell me what you
>> think about ..."
>> 2. We have had success with a survey method that offers people a

"I am not certain, in the field of public art, whether
it is possible to apply past experience to future endeavors. As of now,
I would be dubious of such claims...."

In response to Todd's quote above...the only thing we take with us from one project to the next is the process and our knowledge of how we were engaged, what we learned , what we intend in next step etc.

Would also like to encourage viewing the movie, "What the bleep do we know?"....intention, observers, evolution...all factors in the process.

con christeson

-----Original Message-----
From: AFTA Public Art discusion list
[mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org] On Behalf Of Marc Pally
Sent: Saturday, October 23, 2004 1:59 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys

Todd

I am intrigued by the investigation you and your students are pursuing
vis a vis a conversation with viewers in regards to their experience of
public art. I'm curious how this information might be used. On the one
hand it represents the possibility for artists and their sponsors to
gather insights about various responses to existing work. This can be of
interest and perhaps of some relevance to makers and sponsors of art. Is
this a kind of market research that gives artists and sponsors various
data from a number of respondents? What is the purpose of this data?
Does it assist in the construction of "successful models" which artists
might be "encouraged" to consider or even emulate. Or, is it merely
another means of fostering civic conversation by offering respondents
opportunities to both think about and articulate their experience of
various public artworks. Needless to say, my hope is that the latter
model prevails and that art remain a messy unpredictable business,
driven more by internal logic and instinct than opinion polls. After
all, it is art's very ability to synthesize experience and offer
redirection and examination of our sensory and linguistic systems that
make it so frequently confusing and compelling. Freedom from the proven
is an utter necessity for progress in all the arts and sciences.

Regards,

Marc

Todd Bressi wrote:

> Greetings:
>
> At the University of Pennsylvania, several of us are engaged in
> evaluative research on public art. I am attaching two papers, one
based
> on research my students (in the Department of City Planning) have done
> on public perceptions on public art, and one on an evaluation of the
> mural arts in Philadelphia done by Penn's Social Impact of the Arts
> Project (http://www.ssw.upenn.edu/SIAP/)
>
>
>
> In my class, we have been trying various experiments for three years
> (the paper I am attaching reflects the findings of only the first
> year). Our goal is not so much to judge whether people like a piece of
> art or not, but to get to deeper understanding of how people value
> art, and how art impacts its physical surroundings I have not
> summarized our findings about survey instruments yet, but I can
> suggest some general lessons:
>
> 1. Questions that probe "do you like or dislike" do not yield as
> informative results as open-ended questions like "tell me what you
> think about ..."
> 2. We have had success with a survey method that offers people a
> choice of descriptive words, such as "beautiful," "funny" etc. and
> asks them to circle the words they associate with the project. Then
> the interviewer can follow up with questions like "I see you said this
> is 'beautiful.' Can you tell me why?"
>
> Getting at the "success" of a project is a tougher matter, because in
> order to construct a survey, you have to decide for yourself what a
> measure of success is, then develop a survey to test it. At this very
> moment, my students are reading Ellen Dissanyake's article "Why Public
> Art is Necessary" (in the book New*Land*Marks) and developing survey
> instruments to test the 10 reasons that she lists.
>
> I'll have more to share after the semester is over, but would be happy
> to review and comment on any survey forms people want to share.
>
> Todd Bressi
> Brown & Keener Bressi
> Urban Design * Place Planning
> 2300 Chestnut St., Suite 400

Date:         Mon, 25 Oct 2004 12:23:10 -0400
Reply-To:     Todd Bressi <tbressi@BKURBANDESIGN.COM>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Todd Bressi <tbressi@BKURBANDESIGN.COM>
Subject:      Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys
Comments: To: "con-sult@juno.com" <con-sult@juno.com>
In-Reply-To:  <20041025.075237.504.214627@webmail11.lax.untd.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v553)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I suppose I should be more clear about what I write in e-mail.
What I mean is, I am not certain yet how the findings of our evaluative
research could be put to use by public art program managers in
organizing / commissioning future projects. I am not certain what the
predictive value of our research is.
For example, my students have found that some projects are relatively
opaque to people who encounter them. The people who use or visit the
areas where the art is located have a hard time expressing an emotional
or intellectual connection to the artwork. The art doesn't seem to have
much of an impact on their experience of the place.
To me, that is an interesting finding. But I don't know yet how to turn
that into a prescription for future action, nor am I certain that such
a finding should be turned into a prescription for future action. All I
can say is that we have much more work ahead of us in developing
approaches to eliciting public reactions to public art before we can
understand where our findings can lead us.
I do believe, of course, that individuals -- artists, arts
administrators, planners -- can learn from experience. As individuals,
though, we take our knowledge of past experience to form hypotheses
that shape our next steps. We work in a nuanced, conditional,
transformative and iterative manner.
That is different from using past experience to project future
prescriptions or rules. When I report that my students find that public
art projects seem to register more in people's minds because of where
they are located, rather than how they are designed, I offer that as a
gleaning, but I don't suggest what to do with it. Accept the finding,
question it, filter it through your own experience, test it in your own
research, experiment in future projects.
Todd Bressi

Date:         Mon, 25 Oct 2004 11:47:55 -0500
Reply-To:     Carol Laufer <carol@CACHH.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Carol Laufer <carol@CACHH.ORG>
Subject:      Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys
Comments: To: "Grant, John G. - MOACF" <John.Grant@CI.DENVER.CO.US>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

I don't think I started this search for evaluations but I think I chimed in
to assert my interest in the findings.  Perhaps it is ironic that what I was
actually looking for were evaluations not of the projects from the point of
view of John and Joanne Q. Public, but actually, evaluations from artists,
architects, client department reps, community reps and other stakeholders
regarding the process of specific projects.

While I'm not sure I'm as negative about the concept of getting valid
responses from passers-by, I'm really more interested in finding out what
those involved with a specific project think the highs and lows in there
process are.

As for getting accurate input from the public, social scientists (ie.
Psychologists, sociologists etc.) have developed methods for evaluating and
statistically analyzing results of written/oral response-based evaluations.
If the ability to evaluate results is such a concern, rather than throwing
the baby out with the bath water, perhaps working with methods already
established by academia would be useful.

So, my appeal again is for assistance finding meaningful evaluation of
program methods.

Thanks in advance for any help.

Carol Laufer
Director, Civic Art + Design
Cultural Arts Council of Houston and Harris County
3201 Allen Parkway
Suite 250
Houston, Texas  77019
713.527.9330 x13
f 713.630.5210

-----Original Message-----
From: AFTA Public Art discusion list
[mailto:PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org] On Behalf Of Marc Pally
Sent: Saturday, October 23, 2004 1:59 PM
To: PUBLIC_ART-L@culturemail.org
Subject: Re: examples of public art evaluation surveys

Todd

I am intrigued by the investigation you and your students are pursuing
vis a vis a conversation with viewers in regards to their experience of
public art. I'm curious how this information might be used. On the one
hand it represents the possibility for artists and their sponsors to
gather insights about various responses to existing work. This can be of
interest and perhaps of some relevance to makers and sponsors of art. Is
this a kind of market research that gives artists and sponsors various
data from a number of respondents? What is the purpose of this data?
Does it assist in the construction of "successful models" which artists
might be "encouraged" to consider or even emulate. Or, is it merely
another means of fostering civic conversation by offering respondents
opportunities to both think about and articulate their experience of
various public artworks. Needless to say, my hope is that the latter
model prevails and that art remain a messy unpredictable business,
driven more by internal logic and instinct than opinion polls. After
all, it is art's very ability to synthesize experience and offer
redirection and examination of our sensory and linguistic systems that
make it so frequently confusing and compelling. Freedom from the proven
is an utter necessity for progress in all the arts and sciences.

Regards,

Marc

Todd Bressi wrote:

> Greetings:
>
> At the University of Pennsylvania, several of us are engaged in
> evaluative research on public art. I am attaching two papers, one
based
> on research my students (in the Department of City Planning) have done
> on public perceptions on public art, and one on an evaluation of the
> mural arts in Philadelphia done by Penn's Social Impact of the Arts
> Project (http://www.ssw.upenn.edu/SIAP/)
>
>
>
> In my class, we have been trying various experiments for three years
> (the paper I am attaching reflects the findings of only the first
> year). Our goal is not so much to judge whether people like a piece of
> art or not, but to get to deeper understanding of how people value
> art, and how art impacts its physical surroundings I have not
> summarized our findings about survey instruments yet, but I can
> suggest some general lessons:
>
> 1. Questions that probe "do you like or dislike" do not yield as
> informative results as open-ended questions like "tell me what you
> think about ..."
> 2. We have had success with a survey method that offers people a
> choice of descriptive words, such as "beautiful," "funny" etc. and
> asks them to circle the words they associate with the project. Then
> the interviewer can follow up with questions like "I see you said this
> is 'beautiful.' Can you tell me why?"
>
> Getting at the "success" of a project is a tougher matter, because in
> order to construct a survey, you have to decide for yourself what a
> measure of success is, then develop a survey to test it. At this very
> moment, my students are reading Ellen Dissanyake's article "Why Public
> Art is Necessary" (in the book New*Land*Marks) and developing survey
> instruments to test the 10 reasons that she lists.
>
> I'll have more to share after the semester is over, but would be happy
> to review and comment on any survey forms people want to share.
>
> Todd Bressi
> Brown & Keener Bressi
> Urban Design * Place Planning
> 2300 Chestnut St., Suite 400
> Philadelphia, PA 19103
>
> 215-751-113
> 3
=========================================================================
Date:         Mon, 25 Oct 2004 14:04:12 -0700
Reply-To:     mpally@earthlink.net
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Marc Pally <mpally@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: evaluation  and autonomy
Comments: To: PAN listserv <aftapubart-l@culturemail.org>
In-Reply-To:  <76933214.1098696159@[192.168.1.47]>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Thanks to Tim for a thoughtful line of thinking - the final paragraph
contains the key question:
"... how can the institutional/funding model be transformed to provide
the autonomy that
might lead to more diverse and critical intent? "
My hunch is that funding for a more open ended art must be found beyond
the existing structure.  The current public art funding model is
primarily tied to civic enterprises in which art is one of many systems
at play.  These systems have complex goals and objectives in which art
must play the role of a good neighbor.  There is an enormous amount of
exemplary art being produced under this model; it does however have
limits to its tolerance for deviance.  This is where funding from
foundations and individuals can be most useful in supporting the most
adventurous, probing and subversive work.  The problem is not the limits
of one model over another -  each is part of the funding ecology and
each contributes to a richer public life.
Marc Pally

Tim Collins wrote:

> Good Morning,
> I've taken a few minutes to very quickly review Professor Bressi's work,
> after Marc Pally's provocative comments, which got me engaged. In the
> opening paragraph in Bressi's paper "Public Reaction to Public Art:
> Preliminary Findings from the Field" I find what I think is the primary
> goal of most progressive public art today."Increasingly, art projects are
> regarded as integral to urban design, public infrastructure and
> neighborhood revitalization initiatives." Unquestioning integration into
> urban design and revitalization is the golden calf of public art. With
> networked integration a public art program is robust with sustained long
> term financing and political support.
>
> Marc suggests that art must remain a "...messy unpredictable business
> with
> its own internal logic" and "freedom from the proven." But the range of
> response - is quite constrained by integration isn't it? To actually
> take a
> critical and intentionally transformative stance on -urban design,
> -public
> infrastructure, and/or -urban revitalization initiatives would run
> counter
> to the goals of integrated long term public art programming. Wouldn't it?
> Besides that the fact of the matter, is the art is an amenity brought to
> the table of the primary designers who are themselves invested in the
> intent of the development plan.
>
> I would argue that artists need to consider models like any other
> discipline or area of practice. Having colleagues and research
> initiatives
> like the ones that support T.Bressi's work, and the work of the original
> "Going Public" group is of utmost import. However you can't see the
> limits
> of institutionalized public art programs by looking within the
> confines of
> that realm of production alone. We need public art research models that
> process and analyze social and environmental art practices as a whole.
> Programs that provide artists and future administrators with a critical
> overview of the limits and intent of institutionalized programs. We
> live in
> a critical juncture in world history, civic discourse has collapsed,
> environmental threats are global and global corporate interests are only
> overshadowed by one of the most robust military industrial interests the
> world has ever seen.
>
> In this world we live in, artists and administrators NEED MODELS to
> help us
> see beyond the limits of existing systems. We need to actively think and
> dream new programs, new artworks that have real impact and effect,
> contributing to the diversity of voices in dialogue. The social sciences
> spend a lot of time considering those public art models that embrace and
> enhance the dominant growth/development paradigm in U.S. Cities, while
> ignoring he greater social-political impact of artists like John
> Heartfield, Joseph Beuys, Paolo Friere, Hans Haacke, Suzanne Lacy, the
> Harrisons, Wochenklausur, Kristof Wodiczko, Platform, the Critical Art
> Ensemble, HaHa, Temporary Services... the list goes on and on. Artists
> with
> recognized and robust public practices. By the way I wouldn't
> characterize
> these artists for Marc's provocative guidelines of  "internal logic" or
> their "confusing but compelling" products. The work listed above has
> clear
> intent, method and product.
>
> The Institutionalization of public art has led to a limited but clear
> intent. In the words of Mr. Bressi the ideal is public art that supports
> "urban design, public infrastructure and neighborhood revitalization
> initiatives".
>
> In response: The question isn't one of academic evaluations pushing this
> area further into risk averse behavior, the question is how can the
> institutional/funding model be transformed to provide the autonomy that
> might lead to more diverse and critical intent?
>
> t
>
>
> --On Saturday, October 23, 2004 12:59 PM -0700 Marc Pally
> <mpally@earthlink.net> wrote:
>
>> Does it assist in the construction of "successful models" which artists
>> might be "encouraged" to consider or even emulate. Or, is it merely
>> another means of fostering civic conversation by offering respondents
>> opportunities to both think about and articulate their experience of
>> various public artworks. Needless to say, my hope is that the latter
>> model prevails and that art remain a messy unpredictable business,
>> driven more by internal logic and instinct than opinion polls. After
>> all, it is art's very ability to synthesize experience and offer
>> redirection and examination of our sensory and linguistic systems that
>> make it so frequently confusing and compelling. Freedom from the proven
>> is an utter necessity for progress in all the arts and sciences.
>
>
>
>
> Timothy M. Collins, Research Fellow
> Project Director, 3 Rivers 2nd Nature
> The STUDIO for Creative Inquiry
> Rm 111, College of Fine Arts
> Carnegie Mellon University
> Pittsburgh PA, 15213
> 412-268-3673
>
> http://3r2n.cfa.cmu.edu
> http://slaggarden.cfa.cmu.edu
>

Date:         Mon, 25 Oct 2004 16:35:28 -0500
Reply-To:     Julia Moore <jmoore@BLACKBURNARCHITECTS.COM>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Julia Moore <jmoore@BLACKBURNARCHITECTS.COM>
Subject:      Re: evaluation  and autonomy
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

The practitioners and funding sources named by both Marc and Tim have one
thing in common:  the artwork resulting from the efforts is temporary.  I
feel that more risks can be taken with temporary work than permanent work
because of the nature of both the funding sources and the structure that has
been set up to facilitate them.  While I, too, would like to see more daring
permanent works, I'm afraid that the "good neighbor" model must continue to
apply because of the many diverse and often conflicting interests (many of
them stemming from the nature of the democratic system, which is to create
elected officials who are continually campaigning for re-election!) tied to
the idea of committing to a new element in the urban fabric.  "Freedom from
the proven," when permanent artworks can take up to 15 years to realize, is
an admirable goal but, I fear, an impossible one.

Julia Muney Moore
Public Art Administrator--New Indianapolis Airport (opens 2008)
Blackburn Architects
3388 Founders Rd
Indianapolis, IN  46268
317.875.5500 x230
FAX 317.875.0544
jmoore@blackburnarchitects.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Marc Pally [mailto:mpally@earthlink.net]

Thanks to Tim for a thoughtful line of thinking - the final paragraph
contains the key question:
"... how can the institutional/funding model be transformed to provide
the autonomy that
might lead to more diverse and critical intent? "
My hunch is that funding for a more open ended art must be found beyond
the existing structure.  The current public art funding model is
primarily tied to civic enterprises in which art is one of many systems
at play.  These systems have complex goals and objectives in which art
must play the role of a good neighbor.  There is an enormous amount of
exemplary art being produced under this model; it does however have
limits to its tolerance for deviance.  This is where funding from
foundations and individuals can be most useful in supporting the most
adventurous, probing and subversive work.  The problem is not the limits
of one model over another -  each is part of the funding ecology and
each contributes to a richer public life.
Marc Pally

Date:         Mon, 25 Oct 2004 17:58:46 -0500
Reply-To:     Carol Laufer <carol@CACHH.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Carol Laufer <carol@CACHH.ORG>
Subject:      Re: evaluation  and autonomy
Comments: To: mpally@earthlink.net
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

It seems to me that those of us who work for private entities as consultants
to government agencies are in a unique position to create sub-programs; we
have access to the creative capital, know the bureaucratic idiosyncracies of
the gov't agency, and know the field.  I'm trying to create a
non-governmentally funded experimental art program by using these assets.

Carol Laufer
Director, Civic Art + Design
Cultural Arts Council of Houston and Harris County
3201 Allen Parkway
Suite 250
Houston, Texas  77019
713.527.9330 x13
f 713.630.5210

Date:         Tue, 26 Oct 2004 22:37:39 -0400
Reply-To:     Jennifer McGregor <jennifermcgregor@EARTHLINK.NET>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Jennifer McGregor <jennifermcgregor@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      FW: WEATHER
In-Reply-To:  <E2549687AA52D4118C24001083FC68C3BECAD7@WAVEHILL>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

Dear Collegues,

A diversion from the topic of evaluation.  Next summer we are planning an
exhibition about weather at Wave Hill.  If you have any artists to suggest,
please forward their names (and if possible contact info) to me.

Meteorologic Phenomena (working title),  June 8 - August 28, 2005, this
exhibit in Glyndor Gallery and on the grounds will look at a variety of
artistic responses to the weather, that elemental force that shapes all
human relationships to nature.  Atmospheric conditions influence ecological
and biological progress as well cultural and technological development.
Artists in this exhibition take weather as a psychological condition, source
of scientific information, and aesthetic inspiration.  The exhibit
will include 10 - 15 artists working in a range of mediums.

Thanks for your interest and assistance.

Jennifer McGregor

Visual Arts Curator
Wave Hill
675 West 252 Street
Bronx, NY  10471
718-549-3200 x204
jenniferm@wavehill.org <mailto:jenniferm@wavehill.org>
www.wavehill.org <http://www.wavehill.org>

to participate in a special audioconference opportunity

Postelection Analysis and Impact on the Arts at the Federal, State, and
Local Levels

About the Program

Join your colleagues in a live opportunity to discuss election results
and their impact on the arts on Friday, November 5, 2004, from 2:00 to
3:30 p.m. (EST).=20

Americans for the Arts President and CEO Robert L. Lynch, Vice President
of Government
<http://www.magnetmail.net/images/clients/ArtsUSA/bob.jpg> and Public
Affairs Nina Ozlu, and our entire Government Affairs team will host an
informative and interactive audioconference to discuss the election and
its implications on arts funding and policy at the federal, state, and
local levels. They will give a short analysis of election results and
open the conversation up for audience participation in a question and
answer session.=20

This moderated, interactive, and LIVE audioconference opportunity is
offered at a special
<http://www.magnetmail.net/images/clients/ArtsUSA/nina.jpg> discounted
rate of $50 per site to Americans for the Arts organizational and
individual members; the nonmember rate is $75 per site. Invite your
constituents to share the experience with you at your site. Include your
board, staff, and community partners to hear our analysis and ask
questions about the election results and their impact in your community.


For more information on this program and to view our speaker
biographies, please visit our postelection audioconference website

        font-family:"Times New Roman";}
p.bumped, li.bumped, div.bumped
        {margin-top:0in;
        margin-right:0in;
        margin-bottom:7.5pt;
        margin-left:7.5pt;
        font-size:12.0pt;
        font-family:"Times New Roman";}
p.sectiontitle, li.sectiontitle, div.sectiontitle
        {margin-right:0in;
        margin-left:0in;
        font-size:9.0pt;
        font-family:Verdana;
        color:white;
        font-weight:bold;}
p.addr, li.addr, div.addr
        {margin-right:0in;
        margin-left:0in;
        font-size:7.5pt;
        font-family:Verdana;
        color:#666666;}

        {font-family:Verdana;

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D2 color=3Dblue face=3DArial><span =
style=3D'font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:blue'>Please take a look at this
opportunity.&nbsp; It is a great chance to share election results with =
your
staff, board, partners or constituents.</span></font></p>

  <td colspan=3D3 bgcolor=3Dwhite =

  <p align=3Dcenter style=3D'text-align:center'><em><b><i><font size=3D5
  face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-size:18.0pt;font-weight:bold'>Last
  Chance to <a
  =
href=3D"http://www.magnetmail.net/ls.cfm?r=3D9130594&amp;sid=3D290035&amp=

s.nsf/art8866-0"
  target=3Dnew><span =
style=3D'background:white'>Register</span></a></span></font></i></b></em>=
<em><b><i><font
  size=3D4 face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt;font-weight:bold'>
  </span></font></i></b></em><b><i><font size=3D4><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt;
  font-weight:bold;font-style:italic'><br>
  <em><i><font face=3D"Times New Roman">to participate in a special
  audioconference opportunity</font></i></em></span></font></i></b></p>
  <p align=3Dcenter style=3D'text-align:center'><strong><b><font =
size=3D5 color=3Dnavy
  face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-size:18.0pt;color:navy'>Postelection
  Analysis and Impact on the Arts at the Federal, State, and Local =
Levels</span></font></b></strong></p>
  <p><strong><b><font size=3D3 face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-size:
  12.0pt'>About the Program</span></font></b></strong></p>
  <p><font size=3D3 face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-size:12.0pt'>Join
  your colleagues in a <strong><b><font face=3D"Times New Roman">live =
</font></b></strong>opportunity
  to discuss election results and their <em><i><font face=3D"Times New =
Roman">impact
  on the arts</font></i></em> on Friday, November 5, 2004, from 2:00 to =
3:30
  p.m. (EST). </span></font></p>
  <p><font size=3D3 face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-size:12.0pt'>Americans
  for the Arts President and CEO Robert L. Lynch, Vice President&nbsp;of
  Government </span></font><img width=3D100 height=3D100
  src=3D"http://www.magnetmail.net/images/clients/ArtsUSA/bob.jpg" =
align=3Dright
  border=3D0 NOSEND=3D1>and Public Affairs Nina Ozlu, and our entire =
Government
  Affairs team will host an informative and interactive audioconference =
to
  discuss the election and its implications on arts funding and policy =
at the
  federal, state, and local levels. They will give a short analysis of =
election
  results and open the conversation up for audience participation in a =
question
  and answer session. </p>
  <p><font size=3D3 face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-size:12.0pt'>This
  moderated, interactive, and LIVE audioconference opportunity is =
offered at a <em><i><font
  face=3D"Times New Roman">special </font></i></em></span></font><img =
width=3D100
  height=3D100 =
src=3D"http://www.magnetmail.net/images/clients/ArtsUSA/nina.jpg"
  align=3Dright border=3D0 NOSEND=3D1><em><i><font face=3D"Times New =
Roman">discounted
  rate</font></i></em> of $50 per site to Americans for the Arts =
organizational
  and individual members; the nonmember rate is $75 per site. =
<strong><b><font
  face=3D"Times New Roman">Invite</font></b></strong> your constituents =
to share
  the experience with you at your site. <strong><b><font face=3D"Times =
New Roman">Include</font></b></strong>
  your board, staff, and community partners to hear our analysis and =
<strong><b><font
  face=3D"Times New Roman">ask</font></b></strong> questions about the =
election
  results and their impact in your community. </p>
  <p><font size=3D3 face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-size:12.0pt'>For
  more information on this program and to view our speaker biographies, =
please
  visit our <a

audioconference
  website</span></a>.</span></font></p>

=========================================================================
Date:         Fri, 29 Oct 2004 11:57:07 -0400
Reply-To:     Courtney Patterson <cpatterson@ARTSUSA.ORG>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>
From:         Courtney Patterson <cpatterson@ARTSUSA.ORG>
Subject:      Correction to posting - Barbara Jordan Statue
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
              boundary="----_=_NextPart_001_01C4BDCF.F13CDCC8"

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------_=_NextPart_001_01C4BDCF.F13CDCC8
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

It's just come to my attention that the web site address in this posting
is incorrect.  This is the same posting that was on the listserv last
week, with the exception that the web site has been corrected to read
http://www.utbarbarajordanstatue.org
<http://www.utbarbarajordanstatue.org/> .  Thanks!

BARBARA JORDAN STATUE PROJECT

CALL FOR ARTISTS  The University of Texas at Austin Barbara Jordan
Statue Project Committee and The University of Texas System Board of
Regents invite three-dimensional visual artists with a history of
creating and executing large-scale outdoor works to apply for
consideration in the development of a commemorative outdoor bronze
statue in honor of the late Barbara Jordan, to be sited on the
University of Texas at Austin campus.  Barbara Jordan was the first
African-American woman from the South to serve in the U.S. congress.
Her passion for her country's ideals and her rousing oratory style
brought her success as a politician, a champion of civil rights, and a
professor, and made her a national treasure.

PROJECT PROCEDURES   Initial review will be made based on past work.
Three to five artists will be invited to develop maquettes for the
proposed statue. Each of the selected artists will receive $5,000 to
produce a maquette, which will become the property of the University of
Texas at Austin.  Artists who qualify for this phase will be expected to
travel to Austin and present their concept orally to the committee.

SUBMISSION GUIDELINES   Artists who want to be considered must submit
the following materials:
********A completed application form. You may apply online by going to
http://www.utbarbarajordanstatue.org
<http://www.utbarbarajordanstatue.org/>=20
********Submissions should not be bound.
********Up to twenty (20) 35 mm slides of recent relevant work.  Slides
must be submitted in a 9" x 11" plastic sheet.  Each slide must be
labeled with artist's name, indication of the top of the slide and
numbered in order you wish to have them projected.  Glass mounted slides
will not be accepted.  An applicant may send a CD containing up to 20
high-resolution images of their work in lieu of slides.
********An annotated typewritten slide list on 8 1/2" x 11" paper,
identifying slides by number and including title, date, medium, size
(HxWxD) and a brief description of the work.=20
********A current biography/resume on 8 1/2" x 11" paper. A single copy
of articles or other supplemental materials may be enclosed.
********An artist statement not to exceed one 8 1/2" x 11" page. The
statement should reflect the artist's aesthetic and/or concept for this
project.=20
********A self-addressed, stamped envelope for the return of slides.
Materials will not be returned without a self-addressed, stamped
envelope.
********Artists are discouraged from submitting videotapes or numerous
catalogues.

SUBMIT TO
The Barbara Jordan Statue Competition
Texas Commission on the Arts
920 Colorado Street, 5th Floor
Austin, Texas 78701
Attention: Laurel Butler

DEADLINE   Must be received by 5:00 pm on November 15, 2004

INQUIRIES  Laurel Butler at Laurel.Butler@arts.state.tx.us (512)
936-6570. =20
To apply or for more information, please visit our website at
www.utbarbarajordanstatue.org <http://www.utbarbarajordanstatue.org/> .

Reply-To:     Beatrix Barker <beatrix@BARKER-PUBLICART.COM>
Sender:       AFTA Public Art discusion list <PUBLIC_ART-L@CULTUREMAIL.ORG>

Subject:      Call for Artists - Burbank RFQ - Please forward
In-Reply-To:  <D669934D0F451F4BA7DFC23D7926DA8F86BBC1@ponyexpress.artsusa.org>

------=_NextPart_000_0031_01C4BD96.7B5CCD40
Content-Type: text/plain;
        charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

REQUEST FOR QUALIFICATIONS
CITY OF BURBANK
 Public art for a Neighborhood Recreation Center and Community School
 SUBMISSION DEADLINE:  NOVEMBER 15, 2004

 ARTWORK BUDGET: $60,000

ROBERT R. OVROM PARK Recreation Center and Community School will be located
in the City of Burbank's South San Fernando Boulevard area. Construction is
scheduled to start in March 2005 and substantial completion in March 2006.



Park space will include a basketball court, play equipment areas, swing
areas, picnic tables, shade shelters, and open turf areas.



The Recreation Center will include classrooms, computer lab, conference
rooms, assembly room, and lounge space.  It will provide facilities for an
alternative school for trouble youth, a satellite site for easy access
employment programs, and on-site counseling by Burbank Family Services.
Recreation providers will include the Boys and Girls Club, YMCA, and
Community Services Clubs.



Interested artists/teams must have strong public art project credentials and
possess the ability to involve and engage the community/public.



All media, traditional and non-traditional forms will be considered: artwork
integrated into the existing architecture, functional elements, and artwork
with interactive component.

Installation, maintenance, public safety and durability issues must be taken
into consideration.



All submittals must be received by 5PM, November 15, 2004:

 Eric Hansen, Interim Director, Park, Recreation and Community Services
Department
275 East Olive Avenue, Burbank, CA 91502

Applicants are required to include qualifications, slides of recent
projects, and annotated slide list.

For further information, please contact the project art consultant:
Beatrix Barker -Barker + Associates Public Art Advisory-
beatrix@barker-publicart.com


We look forward to your interest in this project.

size=3D3>We look forward to your interest in this=20
project.</FONT></SPAN></SPAN></P></DIV></FONT></DIV></BODY></HTML>

Dear Colleagues,



This week's pan weekly is attached as a word document.



Best wishes,





Renee Piechocki

Public Art Network Manager

Americans for the Arts

T: 412-281-1770

E:  <mailto:pan@artsusa.org> pan@artsusa.org



 <http://www.AmericansForTheArts.org/PAN> www.AmericansForTheArts.org/PAN



Americans for the Arts is the nation's leading nonprofit organization for
advancing the arts in America. With more than 40 years of service, it is
dedicated to representing and serving local communities and creating
opportunities for every American to participate in and appreciate all forms
of the arts.
